PETITION.TITLE: Watsonia Army Barracks, Victoria
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that:

1. The Watsonia Army Barracks contains a satellite communication dish, that sends to the United States the information, gathered by the ``joint high frequency stations'' in Australia and New Zealand, indicating the position of the Soviet naval ships and submarines. This information from Watsonia is combined with data from satellites and underwater sensors to calculate the location of the Soviet vessels with great accuracy.

2. This would make it possible for the US nuclear naval ships and submarines to destroy all nuclear Soviet naval ships and submarines, while the US nuclear submarines, naval ships and bombers launch their missiles in a ``first strike'' attack.
3. This makes Watsonia a potential nuclear target. A nuclear attack on Watsonia would have a disastrous effect on Melbourne.
4. The `joint U.S.-Australia' bases in Australia endanger rather than protect us. They also add a new menace to the nuclear arms race, that must be stopped.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should close the `joint Australian-U.S.' electronic communication facilities in the Watsonia Army Barracks.

PETITION.TITLE: Superannuation Schemes
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That we consider the 2% discounting of Commonwealth Occupational Superannuation Scheme pension adjustments on 10 October 86 to be a serious breach of trust by the Government. The Commonwealth has reneged on an established commitment as incorporated in Commonwealth legislation and benefit promise pensions are not being paid in full. In particular we resent the long-term effect of the discounting. The pension loss is compounded throughout the life of a pensioner and surviving dependants-into the 21st century for many. We consider this Government-induced penalty to be out of all proportion to the short-term ``extraordinary circumstances of the economy'' given as the reason for the discounting.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should urge the Government to:

1. limit the pension discounting effect of the Superannuation and Other Benefits Legislation Amendment Act 1986 to the period 10 October 86 to 1 July 87 so that pensions are restored to the 9 October 86 level as a base for the 1987 pension adjustment; and
2. consult with organisations representing pensioners before changing the terms and conditions of Commonwealth Occupational Superannuation Schemes.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Identity Card Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
We, the undersigned citizens, respectfully showeth:
That we are totally opposed to the introduction of the Labor Government's Identity Card;

PETITION.TITLE: X-Rated Video Material
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that:
1. There is no legal barrier to the importation of x-rated videos in the A.C.T. or to their sale in the A.C.T.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, should:
urge the government to use its proven constitutional powers to halt sand mining on Moreton by supporting the Moreton Island Preservation Bill.

PETITION.TITLE: How to Vote Cards
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

millions of dollars of taxpayers money is spent at each Federal election in Australia in the drafting, production and distribution of How-to-Vote cards which are unnecessary and pollutant and that this waste is not desirable or essential in assisting the electorate to vote informatively for their parliamentarians.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, should:

PETITION.TITLE: Smoke Free Air Travel
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
We the undersigned,
(i) are greatly disturbed by the dangers to health posed by passive smoking, and evidence of which is being documented daily by medical authorities around the world;

(ii) note that environmental tobacco smoke has been identified as the major pollutant in aeroplane cabins, and that its direct threat to health is recognised in the special leave provisions for flight attendants specifically on grounds of upper respiratory infections;

(iii) appreciate the government's undertaking to legislate for smoke-free travel on aeroplanes, but are dismayed at the apparent reluctance to follow up the Minister for Aviation's December announcement with action; and

(iv) call upon the government to make smoke-free aeroplane travel a reality without further delay, and to ensure that smoke-free areas which cannot be contaminated by recycled pollutants, are available at all aerodromes.

PETITION.PARA: We, the undersigned, would like to voice our protest at the proposed legislation for the Australia Card. This petition of Australian citizens shows:

The speeches read as follows-

Australia has long had a proud history of achievement on matters of electoral equality and reform. Secrecy was a feature of Australian electoral systems long before it became accepted in most other democratic countries. The Australian colonies began to introduce secret ballots in 1856, the last one doing so in 1877 some 20 years and more before they were introduced by most other western countries.

Voting for all adult men was granted early in the history of the self-governing new colonies in the mid 1850's, although it must be noted that until the turn of the twentieth century people who owned property generally had more than one vote. We can quite proudly point to the fact that women in Australia won the vote at about the turn of the century, 25 years ahead of their sisters in Britain.

In terms of voting for the Senate, the proportional representation system was introduced in 1948 to overcome the unfairness of the first-past-the-post system and preferential voting system. The proportional representation system is widely recognised as the fairest electoral system and its introduction as the mechanism of election of Senators was a feather in Australia's cap at the time.

Despite these notable achievements in the early history of Australian political life and subsequent corrections of grossly undemocratic electoral practices, such as giving aboriginal people the long overdue right to vote in 1977, there is still an urgent need for further reform on matters of electoral equality to facilitate the operation of good and effective government in Australia.

There are still major stumbling blocks which must be removed to create a fairer and more informed political environment. The frequency and uncertainty of the timing of elections is a matter of vital importance to the whole nation. The existence of electoral systems which do not give people the same valued vote when electing their political representatives is disgraceful and must be rectified. The inability of citizens to have a direct input in the legislative process can and should be changed. The increase in the size of parliament as a result of outmoded requirements in the Constitution must also be addressed.

Indeed the relevance and applicability of our Constitution has in recent years been the subject of considerable public debate. So much so that in December 1985 the federal government established the Constitutional Commission to inquire into and report on a possible revision of the Constitution. The Committee which will report by June 1988 was asked to review the Constitution in order to:
``(1) adequately reflect Australia's status as an independent nation and a federal parliamentary democracy;
(2) provide the most suitable framework for the economic, social, and political development of Australia as a federation;
(3) recognise an appropriate division of responsibilities between the Commonwealth, the States, self-governing Territories and local government; and
(4) ensure that democratic rights are guaranteed.''

Despite the work of the Constitutional Committee and the publicity generated by the five Advisory Committees reporting to the Commission, there is still widespread ignorance about the existence of a Constitution, let alone knowledge of its place in the political and social landscape and its actual meaning. The Advisory Committee on Executive Government referred to the language of the Constitution and said it was ``less straightforward than that of most Constitutions.'' Their report went on:

``This makes the Constitution difficult or impossible to teach in schools or to become an acknowledged part of the political culture of the nation, as Constitutions can in other societies. Our Constitution remains too much of a mystery to those who should be its masters.''

This I believe is a very unfortunate situation and a sad reflection generally on the education of people about their government and political institutions in this country. Only by introducing studies of government into all schools will this situation be rectified. Only when we have a well informed population with a working knowledge can we expect a better standard of political debate and activity in Australia.

Over the last 10 years the Australian Democrats have been to the forefront of the public debate on the state of our Constitution and its reform. In this new parliament my colleagues and I will continue in our efforts to publicise its existence and facilitate avenues for its reform with the aim of encouraging better and more effective government.

To this end I am introducing a package of legislative initiatives which are designed to attend to some oversights of our founding fathers when they drew up the Constitution. The necessity for reform has been recognised by a series of federal governments of all political persuasions and a wide range of public and private institutions concerned with the good government of Australia. I will therefore be seeking the support of such groups and individuals and most importantly of my colleagues in this Chamber to see that this legislative package is debated and passed into law.
CONSTITUTION ALTERATION (DEMOCRATIC ELECTIONS) BILL 1987

The first of this package of cognate bills is the Constitution Alteration (Democratic Elections) Bill 1987. This is a revised version of a bill first introduced to this Parliament on 2 April 1984. Extensive discussions since that time, including examination of the bill by the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform and debate and passage of a motion at the Australian Constitutional Convention in Brisbane in 1986 calling for the bill to be put to the people at a referendum, have led to revisions being incorporated to clarify and improve certain aspects of the Bill. The revised Bill has the same intention as the original Bill-namely, to guarantee the right to vote and to guarantee that every citizen's vote will be treated equally.

Of course, as many honourable senators would recall, a substantially similar Bill was introduced on 8 November, 1973 by the then Prime Minister, Mr Whitlam on behalf of the Australian Government at the Australian Constitutional Convention held in Sydney in September of that year. While that Bill had the same aim as this one, the then Opposition, under the leadership of Mr Snedden, opposed the Bill. Basically, it appears to me, because it felt that the stated principle was not being implemented by Mr Whitlam's Bill. The Opposition argued, quite correctly I believe, that by making electorates equal in the sense that they were to have an equal number of people in them, would not give votes equal value.

The argument advanced by some people is that from a work load point of view these members will have to represent people who are not registered to vote and consequently should be allowed to have them counted in the numbers. From my point of view, this is going about things the wrong way around. Indeed, I believe that we would be far better off encouraging these people to become Australian citizens, if they are not already, and to register to vote.

Given the strong feeling exhibited in 1973 about whether electorates should be divided on the basis of electors or people, I had waited until the Electoral Legislation Amendment Bill had passed through Parliament before raising the matter again. I had thought that we might see a debate at that time on whether electorates should continue to be divided along current lines-that is, number of electors-or whether the Government would take up the Whitlam proposal again and attempt to divide electorates along the lines of numbers of people in them. No debate arose and I take heart from the fact that the present Labor Government is quite happy to accept what I take to be the Opposition line, that things remain the way they are. As a result of this, I have amended Mr Whitlam's original Bill so that the numbers ascertained in respect of divisions shall be, as nearly as practicable, the same in respect of the numbers of electors rather than the numbers of people in each electorate.

In its first report the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform stated that demographic data presently available to Commonwealth and State governments meant that the minimum tolerance between the number of electors in electorates was ten per cent. The Committee's conclusion was the basis for current Commonwealth legislation which permits a maximum tolerance of 10 per cent deviation between the number of electors in electorates.

It is reasonable to assume, however, that improvements in demographic data in later years will enable the present tolerance of 10 per cent to be gradually reduced. In some states of the United States, for example, the tolerance has been reduced to under one per cent. In short, what in 1987 may seem like a reasonable level of deviation will, in 2087, be an intolerable distortion. Given the difficulty that governments have experienced in changing the Constitution it is important for legislators to draft bills which not only enshrine and protect basic Constitutional rights but which also provide federal and state governments with sufficient latitude to achieve further advances in protecting democratic rights without constant referenda on the matter.

It is for this reason that sections 125a and 29 of my bill not only establish a maximum tolerance of 10 per cent between electorates at both the federal and state level it also permits the Commonwealth to reduce (and only reduce) the margin between federal seats by simply amending the Commonwealth Electoral Act. Any reduction by the Commonwealth of electoral margins in federal electorates through alterations to the Commonwealth Electoral Act would also mean that state governments would be required to make identical reductions to their electoral margins in their respective state electoral systems. Thus, if the Commonwealth legislated at some point in the future to reduce Commonwealth electoral tolerances from 10 per cent to 5 percent, all states with the exception of those with margins below 5 per cent would also be required to reduce their tolerances to 5 per cent. Of course a state with tolerances already below 5 per cent would not be required to increase those tolerances merely for conformity with Commonwealth laws.

This approach has a number of advantages. For example, small states such as Victoria would in the future be able to reduce, if their state governments wish, the present electoral margins within their electoral system without having to wait for other governments, including the Commonwealth, to catch up. Conversely, larger states such as Western Australia, which may experience difficulty in matching the advances of the smaller states, need not immediately order an electoral redistribution simply because a smaller state has been able to capitalise on demographic changes unique to that State.

This concept should now have the support of the vast majority of senators and members in this Parliament. Although it is a principle which appears to have the almost complete support of federal parliamentarians, and indeed the people of Australia, it is a principle which is obviously not supported by all parliamentarians at the State level.

I believe that the time has come for the people of the States and the self-governing Territories to have their say on whether or not their current situation should be allowed to continue. Unfortunately, no State Parliament requires a vote of electors in order to change its own Constitution in this regard. Indeed, not even the Federal Constitution requires that change. But I believe it is time that we enshrined the principle in the Federal Constitution so that future governments are not persuaded for purely political gain to change the principle once established.

There are two other changes which have been made to Mr Whitlam's original Bill which I will mention briefly here before moving on to changes made to the Bill I introduced in 1984. The first of these is a purely technical one to rectify an inconsistency in Mr Whitlam's wording of clause 5 and clause 7 of the Bill. As to the substances of clause 5, which has become clause 4 in this revised version of the Bill, the proposed alteration to section 30 of the Constitution has been refined to ensure that the Parliament may provide for the continuing operation of laws relating to the enfranchisement of non-citizens who are currently entitled to vote.

The second change to Mr Whitlam's Bill was to allow parliaments to decide to grant the right to vote to people under the age of 18 if they so desire. Arguments in favour of providing for a younger voting age remain the same as when this Bill was first introduced-although I recognise that the proposal may be controversial. My reason for incorporating the provision is quite simple. Given the difficulties in making amendments to the Constitution, I do not believe that we should enshrine the 18-year-old age limit into the Constitution as the time may well come-even if it is 20 or 30 years away-that we may wish to give 17 or even 16-year-olds the vote. This issue was raised in particular relation to 17-year-olds being conscripted to fight in Vietnam, even though they did not have the vote. It is one thing to force 6 to 15-year-olds to go to school, whether or not it is one of their own choosing, but it is quite a different matter to ask a 17-year-old to fight in a war which he or she might wish to oppose by voting for a political party which opposed such a war if he or she were entitled to vote. A vote of 17-year-olds might well have made the difference in 1969 as to who governed this country and as to whether or not this country continued to conscript people to go to Vietnam.

When this Bill was last introduced in Parliament, the question was raised as to whether the Bill would allow proportional representation and whether or not the Government of the day supported that proposal. Unfortunately, the Government did not, as it still does not; but the Bill does allow for that type of system to exist, as it already does in Tasmania. As I said in my second reading speech on the Commonwealth Electoral Legislation Amendment Bill, the fact that proportional representation for the House of Representatives was missing from that Bill effectively means that the Bill did not really grapple with the last major task of reform in the electoral process. This is a bitter disappointment to many people in the community who feel that it is a necessary move that we must take. I hope that in the future it will be seen to be a necessary reform and that eventually it will be taken. The acceptance of this Bill will certainly do nothing to hinder that development.

As my colleague, ex-Senator Jack Evans, said in his second reading speech on the aforementioned Bill, the omission of proportional representation means that Australia continues with the very lop-sided, winner takes all system of having governments elected. `Winner takes all' follows automatically from a system under which there is a single candidate elected for an electorate and a candidate has to attract only 50 per cent of the vote, plus one, to win. There is no justice and no fairness in that kind of system. I think most people in Australia are now aware that the newer countries which have been formed since this country was federated have opted for proportional representation.

I now wish to draw honourable Senators' attention to certain other provisions in the Bill. Provision for the repeal of section 25 has been retained from the earlier version of the Bill. Section 25 of the Constitution provides that if by law of any State any persons of any race are disqualified from voting at elections for the more numerous houses of the State, then in reckoning the number of people of the State or of the Commonwealth, persons of that race resident in that State shall not be counted. This is an archaic and objectionable provision. It is not within the spirit of the wishes of any political party in this place and the Bill provides for the repeal of that section.

The proposed repeal of section 41, which was not included in the original version of the Bill, arises for two reasons. First, section 41 has ceased to have any practical operation following a High Court decision in 1983; second, if retained in the Constitution, section 41 would conflict with the proposed amendment to section 30.

The original Bill proposed amendments to section 75 to confer original jurisdiction on the High Court in relation to matters arising in the electoral provisions of State or Commonwealth law and to ensure that the electors are able to take action to enforce those provisions. The proposed paragraph in this revised version of the Bill has been altered in two respects. First, the words ``or involving the interpretation of'' have been inserted to make section 75 consistent with section 76. Secondly, the jurisdictional safeguards, which originally applied in relation to elections for the House of Representatives, have now been extended to include Senate elections and elections for representatives of the Territories in the Commonwealth Parliament.

Proposed new section 106a, originally dealing with the election of members of State parliaments, has now been altered in several respects. First, the proposed section now extends to the parliaments of self-governing territories. This change is reflected in the alteration to the long title of the Bill. The provisions of the section now apply to both general and by-elections-apart from the penultimate paragraph which applies to general elections only. The revised wording makes it clear that people can only vote at elections in the State or Territory in which they are normally resident, but does not, of course, prevent them from voting due to temporary absence from home. As with section 30, revisions to the proposed section 106a ensure that Parliament may provide for the continuing operation of laws enfranchising non-citizens who are currently entitled to vote.

In the event of non-compliance with the `one-vote, one-value' principle of section 106a, a further amendment provided for the whole State or Territory to be deemed one electorate for the purposes of a general election. This covers the situation where there is insufficient time for a re-distribution before an election. The amendment also explains why a commencement date, which had been included in the original Bill, has now been omitted. The inclusion of the `fall-back' position obviates the need to give the States some time to comply with the Bill's provisions. In addition, the amendment addresses the argument that the Bill in its original form might have empowered the Commonwealth to redraw State electoral boundaries which had been declared invalid.

The final amendment to proposed section 106a ensures that the Senate voting system would be adopted in a situation where a State general election was held in accordance with the penultimate paragraph of the proposed section.

One final point, proposed new section 122a imposes similar requirements to elections for representatives of the Territories in either House of the Commonwealth Parliament as those applicable to elections for representatives of the States.
CONSTITUTION ALTERATION (FIXED TERM PARLIAMENTS) BILL 1987

This Bill will give effect to proposed changes to the Constitution endorsed by the Australian Constitutional Convention at its Adelaide meeting in 1983. In particular, the Bill provides for the present three-year term for the House of Representatives to be increased to four years and for the new four-year electoral cycle to be fixed.

There is general agreement within the community that the present electoral arrangements have resulted in Australia having far too frequent elections. The Constitution allows the Prime Minister of the day to call an election virtually at whim for the House of Representatives and to demand a double-dissolution once the Senate has twice rejected a bill.

Not surprisingly early elections have occurred so regularly as to have become the rule rather than the exception. The average term of Parliaments post-war has been two years five months and in the 21 year period from 1953 to 1984 there were no fewer than 13 separate national elections. There has been increasing public unease about the lack of sufficient continuity and stability in Government, with a resultant atmosphere of uncertainty and controversy and strong pressure on governments to adopt short-term expedient policies to ensure electoral success.

Of course, as the Business Council of Australia observed, the frequency of elections is not only simply a nuisance or an irritation, it also has major ramifications for sound government decision-making, for budgetary policies and therefore, for the economic climate in which business operates. Indeed, Mr Eric Mayer, the Chairman of the Business Council's Government Expenditure Committee, argued that frequent elections have an adverse effect on government planning and decision-making and this, in turn, adversely affects private sector planning and business confidence.

There is ample evidence to sustain this view. For instance, if the present Parliament runs for its full term, it will be the first time since 1980 that a Federal Government has delivered three budgets during its term of office. It will be only the second time since 1972 that a government has brought down three budgets in its three-year term of office.

In the face of evidence such as this, it is difficult not to conclude that under our present unfixed, three-year parliamentary term system, governments of all colours have had enormous difficulty reconciling careful and deliberate economic policies with the electoral imperatives of political survival. Undoubtedly, this helps explain why the four-year parliamentary term proposal has received such impressive support from all political parties, from a variety of institutions and political commentators and increasingly, strong support from the business sector and the public at large.

The Reid Committee of Review into Commonwealth Administration in 1982 expressed support for a four-year term for reasons of `better management and a more sensible lifestyle'. The 1983 Constitutional Convention in Adelaide endorsed a motion that the terms of Parliament be extended to four years (with Senators' terms equal to twice the term of the House of Representatives). A Bill to that effect was passed by Parliament, but was never submitted to referendum. In 1983 the present government introduced a bill for fixed term parliaments but the legislation was subsequently withdrawn. More recently, the Constitutional Commission has formed the provisional view that it should accept the proposals of the Adelaide meeting of the Australian Constitutional Convention.

Of course, this considerable support for Constitutional reform counts for nought if the people are never provided with an opportunity to enshrine the fixed four-year parliamentary term in the Constitution. Clearly, the task for those in favour of electoral reform is to ensure that the question of fixed four-year terms is put to the people as soon as possible.

A frequent reason advanced by Governments for not pursuing Constitutional reform is that the task of reform is too difficult. The Australian Democrats do not dispute that Constitutional reform has proved difficult in Australia. But this difficulty in turn also highlights the need for Governments to be continually sensitive to opportunities for Constitutional reform.

As noted earlier, there is at the moment considerable public unease with the frequency of elections and the difficulties which Governments experience in implementing consistent and responsible economic policies under the present electoral arrangements.

This dissatisfaction is reflected in the results of qualitative research recently conducted by the Roy Morgan Research Centre for the Business Council of Australia. A survey conducted during the month of August 1986 showed that a referendum to extend the term of the House of Representatives from three to four years would have succeeded. Fifty-six percent of electors said they would have voted `Yes', including a majority in five of the six States.

A similarly impressive level of support was detected in 1983 for the notion of fixed terms and an end at last to the early election syndrome. These poll results indicate a growing appreciation within the electorate that a three-year maximum term is too short. It is also probably indicative that electors in States whose Parliaments have already been extended to four years are comfortable with the reform and are happy for the Federal Parliament to follow suit.

If Australians are given an opportunity to extend the Federal Parliamentary term then this country will, according to a study by the Inter-Parliamentary Union, join 25 other democratic countries with four-year terms. There are, incidentally, 24 democratic countries (including Canada and Great Britain) with five-year terms.

The fixed four-year proposal will not prevent a government from going to the people should a genuine deadlock occur between the House and the Senate but it will certainly remove the present incentive for governments to call an election when they believe the moons of fortune are in alignment. It will certainly provide for greater continuity and stability in the electoral cycle, since the average span of Parliament may be expected to increase substantially. Given the strong bi-partisan support of Federal Members of Parliament for this proposal and the support of at least four State Governments, there is no reason why Australians should not be given an early opportunity to vote on this proposal in the interests of better government in Australia.
CONSTITUTION ALTERATION (PARLIAMENT) BILL 1987

This is a Bill of immense importance but of not great complexity in itself. It is designed to prevent a Constitutional crisis created by a deadlock in the Senate by breaking the nexus-a term which we have all come to understand-and which is created by section 24 of the Commonwealth Constitution. I want to state this matter with all possible clarity because I think that is vital to an understanding of it.

The House of Representatives shall be composed of members directly chosen by the people of the Commonwealth, and the number of such members shall be, as nearly as practicable, twice the number of the senators.
With these words, the then Prime Minister of Australia, and founder of the Liberal Party, Sir Robert Menzies, first introduced this Bill.
In his concluding speech he stated that:

`I profoundly hope and I deeply believe that when this [Bill] is adequately explained to the people of Australia they will say ``Yes'' and they will change this rule and thereby make a tremendous contribution to making this Parliament an effective agent of the popular will.'

Sir Robert was supported in his speech by the next speaker, the then Leader of the Opposition, Mr Calwell, who stated that `We regard it as vitally important to the well-being of the people and the welfare of the nation and the health of democracy that they [the two Constitution Alteration Bills being debated] should be carried. On their merits they deserve overwhelming endorsement'.

The bill passed both houses on the 2nd December 1965 but the matter was not put to the people within the required period of time and so was re-introduced by the then Prime Minister, Mr Harold Holt on 1 March 1967. The Bill was substantially the same as that passed in 1965 except that the minimum number of people to be represented by each House of Representatives seat was increased from 80,000 to 85,000 people. In concluding his speech, Mr Holt stated that if the proposals contained in the Bill were approved by the people `this will constitute a significant advance in the efficient working of our parliamentary system.'

The next speaker was none other than that great statesman, the then leader of the Opposition, Mr Gough Whitlam. In his opening remarks Mr Whitlam stated that `I can assure honourable members and all of our fellow citizens that my Party, in the Parliament and outside the Parliament, will support this Bill and the referendum without reservation, equivocation or qualification.'

It would appear then, from the Hansard record, that there was strong support from all parties on this matter on the two previous occasions when it was debated in Parliament. Indeed, this bill with the support of Labor, Liberal and Democrat Senators passed the Senate in 1983 but the government failed to act on the bill.
Despite this the arguments so ably put by political leaders in 1983 and earlier still apply.

In sponsoring this Bill the Australian Democrats seek to both allow an increase in the number of members in the lower house and to limit the powers of Parliament in the extent to which it can increase its size.
Unless we do so then the present number of senators means that at either the next or subsequent half-Senate election there is a very high probability of a hung Senate occurring.

Under half-Senate election conditions there is a total of six Senators per state to be elected. Under the present system for Senate elections this would almost guarantee in every state the election of three government Senators and three opposition Senators and so we would produce a deadlocked Senate with every motion and every amendment defeated.

A deadlocked Senate would not be any good to a government elected by the people, because nobody could pass a resolution and nobody could pass an amendment. Therefore, if there is to be a Senate in which a clear majority becomes possible, the numbers of the Senate would need to be such under the existing Constitution that an odd number would be elected every three years.

Constitutionally, we can enlarge the membership of the House of Representatives indefinitely and at will. The Constitution imposes no restriction on the numbers, In fact, it is to the contrary, as it insists that if the numbers in the House of Representatives are increased then we must also increase the numbers in the Senate in the ratio of one to two. Under the proposal before us now, that burdensome necessity would be ended.

And this Bill also goes further. It proposes, for the first time in our history, that there shall be a restriction placed on the size of the House of Representatives, by establishing that there will be `not less than' 100,00 people for each seat. That is 100,000 men, women and children-whether they be voters or not. It could at the discretion of Parliament be higher than 100,000-120,000 or even more; but it cannot be less than 100,000. At present there is no such restriction.

Let me emphasise that currently there is nothing in the Constitution to prevent us from deciding that there shall be one seat for every 30 to 40 thousand people, or whichever figure we might choose. As long as we also simultaneously and proportionately increase the Senate we can make the other house as large as we like. I do not think anybody wishes to do that, If this proposal is carried, we shall not be able to do it.
CONSTITUTION ALTERATION (ELECTORS' INITIATIVE) BILL 1987
The right of the people of a country to make law independent of politicians should be a basic and independent right-this is known colloquially as citizens' initiative.
This is not only because the system has worked so well and effectively in other countries, but because there seems a particular need for it in Australia.

Time and again national problems appear to be intractable because of the entrenched and largely self-interested position of the long-established political power groupings. In fact it suits these traditional power groupings very well not to find solutions, but merely to indulge in a variety of complex cosmetic operations, designed to demonstrate that the problem is being dealt with, when in fact it is not. The real losers are always the people.

In a sense this is inevitable, and even has a kind of rough justice-for many decades now the Australian people have surrendered their political powers to clique-like political groupings which fundamentally operate in their own interests and in the interests of those from whom they receive liberal election financial funding.

The answer is for the people to shoulder some of the responsibility again themselves, and to vote themselves the right to make legislation, not all the time, but where important and deeply controversial, even divisive, issues need to be debated and decided upon.

The machinery of citizens' initiative proposed in this bill is very similar to that operating successfully in other parts of the world. It is virtually identical to a similar bill introduced by the former Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats, Senator Colin Mason.

The bill proposes that if 5 percent of the electors petition the government to hold a referendum to create a law then that proposed law should be submitted not less than two months or more than twelve months after presentation of the petition to the electors in each state and territory who are qualified for the election of members of the House of Representatives.

Under the terms of the Bill, the people would acquire for the first time a potentially significant measure of control in the legislative process. The matters which would be proposed under the terms of the Bill are unlikely to be trivial. In recent times there has been no petition in the federal parliament which would have been large enough to secure a referendum-any issue would have to be of very considerable public interest to generate the number of signatures necessary to have it put to a national vote.

There has been much opposition expressed to this issue within Parliament itself. This opposition amounts mainly to the arguments which were historically presented against universal suffrage and later women's suffrage-the argument that the people whose lives are ruled by these laws are not knowledgeable enough to decide what is best for them. This patronising attitude, whilst it is prevalent amongst most parliamentarians, is overwhelmingly dismissed by the people it would affect. They see it for what it truly is-an argument for some type of dictator-ship or oligarchy.

Like every other right, there is a possibility that this one could be misused by powerful pressure groups. No freedom can be absolutely guaranteed. However, it must be borne in mind that the Australian electorate is essentially a conservative one. Historically, changes brought about by referendum are few and far between. It should also be pointed out here that the granting of this right would not affect the authority or usefulness of the parliament-far from it. In other countries with the initiative, the making of the vast body of law, especially in technical or complex areas, has remained the responsibility of the parliament, and I believe that would also be the case here.

The use of citizen-initiated referenda would not be costly in either real or relative terms. The Bill proposes that the referendum be held on the first Saturday of each December. It would cost about the same as a national election, amounting to about $1-15 per head of population. In addition, every three years the date of the referendum would coincide with the date of the national election, which would diminish the cost enormously in that year.

The right of the citizen to initiate referenda is practised already in several of the more enlightened countries, including Switzerland, Austria and the United States of America. This right is often found to be a long-standing one-the Swiss people were granted this right in 1892, and it has been adopted by progressively more States of the U.S.A. since 1890.
In Switzerland, about one-quarter of the initiatives put to referendum are adopted-the others being either rejected or withdrawn.

In the U.S.A., the most famous example of a citizen-initiated referendum is probably the Californian `Proposition 13' of 1977, which altered the taxation laws. Another proposition aimed at cutting a different area of taxation was rejected which indicates, I feel, that citizens can be trusted to judge a referendum topic on its individual merits and not just on whether it will result in personal gain.

In a future which is acknowledged generally to have difficulties, to present problems, to require some sacrifice from the community at large, is it not best to allow that community to involve itself in the issues, and to give it the means to study and know the facts?
Such a responsibility would, over a period, encourage the people to a more far-sighted attitude, and one which would be more healthy for Australia.

Australians today are better educated and more politically aware than in the past. The great media and public interest in politics and the rapid growth of citizen movements demonstrate this. The whole point of democracy is that it is the responsibility of the people to govern.
CONSTITUTION ALTERATION (APPROPRIATIONS FOR THE ORDINARY ANNUAL SERVICES OF THE GOVERNMENT) BILL 1987

The purpose of the Constitution Alteration (Appropriations for the Ordinary Annual Services of the Government) Bill 1987 is to resolve the extremely contentious issue of the Senate's power to block supply.

The task of reconciling the Senate's powers and obligations to scrutineer government appropriations with the Senate's power to block supply is not an easy one but clearly the issue must be confronted.

The two solutions proposed so far to the issue of the Senate blocking supply have been to require an immediate double dissolution of both houses and an election. At the other extreme is the proposal to remove entirely the Senate's power to block supply so that only the House of Representatives would have to pass the supply bills for them to be signed into law by the Governor-General.

The Constitution Alteration (Appropriations for the Ordinary Annual Services of the Government) Bill seeks to uphold the authority of the Senate to examine supply bills but in doing so to prevent the Senate from creating a Constitutional crisis of the magnitude of the 1975 episode and to prevent the Senate from forcing the House of Representatives to the people on its own. Reduced to its essence the bill specifies that once a supply bill has been passed by the Senate the amount specified in the supply bill will remain available to the government for that particular financial year.

In the unlikely, but nonetheless, serious event of the Senate blocking supply the government would still have at its command a base amount consisting of the previous year's appropriations funds. Thus, if a government appropriated $75 billion in 1985/86 and in 1986/87 appropriated $82 billion the maximum amount the Senate would be able to block through defeating supply would be $7 billion. The $7 billion being of course the difference between the 1985/86 and 1986/87 appropriation bills. In short, the only money in a supply bill that the Senate could oppose and defeat would be that amount that the Senate had not yet scrutineered. In the example above it would be $7 billion.
This would mean that in the event of supply being blocked the government could continue to operate although clearly it would have to weigh up the political and economic consequences of so doing.
I commend this package of Constitutional bills to the Senate.

(p) assess the likelihood of more cards and numbers being issued than there are entitled card-holders (as has already occurred with Medicare cards) and the implications of this if the Medicare number is to be used in the Australia Card system;

(q) determine the need for privacy protection legislation and a data protection agency and what form such protection should take, with particular reference to legal remedies for such matters as refusal to correct incorrect data; failure on the part of the Authority to perform its functions; and compensation for damage suffered;

(r) make a comparison of the costs and benefits of the Government proposal with the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card majority recommendation for using a high-integrity tax file number to combat tax and social security fraud;
(s) assess the appropriateness of linking sensitive personal information such as medical data with a system which is designed to address financial matters;
(t) examine the constitutional implications of the legislation's use of terminology such as `The Authority' and `card-subjects' in a common law country such as Australia;
(u) examine the problem of distinguishing between requiring someone to produce a card as a means of identification (which attracts a penalty if it is unauthorised) and `requesting' someone to do so;
(v) determine the adequacy of protections against misuse of the unique personal identification number, as distinct from misuse of the card;
(w) examine the appropriateness of fees being charged for card-subjects to have access to their details on the register, other than the annual inspection permitted under the legislation;
(x) assess the likelihood of increased access to the register by government departments and the private sector in the future;

(y) examine the ease of linkage between information on the register and information on the computer files of other government departments, agencies and private sector bodies where those bodies use the unique personal identification number for purposes required under the legislation;
(z) assess the usefulness of the card and numbering system in achieving the objectives claimed for it, with particular reference to the cash economy, organised crime and large-scale tax evasion;
(za) examine any matters relevant to the preceding; and''.
(6) At end of the proposed terms of reference, add the following paragraph:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Australia Card Bill 1986 [No. 3]. I have but a few moments, but let me first turn to the various penalties which are prescribed under the Australia Card legislation. An employer who fails to request the ID number of an employee is liable to a penalty of $20,000. I might point out that that covers even the most casual cases of employment, such as a baby-sitter. A penalty of $20,000 applies if an employer fails to request the ID number of a baby-sitter. For incorporated bodies the penalty is five times higher-$100,000-for simply neglecting to ask for the employee's ID number. In fact, virtually all areas where there is a requirement to record a person's number are covered by penalties of $20,000 for failing to do so.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a penalty of $500 for failing to report the loss of an identification card within 21 days. If somebody neglects to report the fact that he has lost or misplaced his card within 21 days he is subject automatically to a penalty of $500. In clause 154 there is a penalty of $2,000 or imprisonment for 12 months for anyone who fails to attend before the Data Protection Agency and provide information under oath. I remind the Senate that by contrast a person who gives false information to the Department of Social Security for the purpose of fraudulently obtaining benefits is liable to a fine of only $2,000.

One thing which is absolutely certain about the identification card is that the information which is collected and the access granted to it will inevitably and invariably expand with time. Of course, the bureaucracy and this Government intend that. They are currently engaged in a skilful game of tactics to ensure that everybody is numbered and provided with a card so that the range can be extended. When the Government made a submission to the Joint Committee on an Australia Card, which investigated and rejected the card, it proposed that 13 agencies have access to the Australia Card Register with a possibility of further extensions. Faced as the Government was with the inevitable outcry from the civil liberties groups, that number, for the time being, has been cut back to three. The reason is obvious. In a document published by the Health Insurance Commission called Outline Plan it is stated:

It will be important to minimise any adverse public reaction to implementation of the system. One possibility would be to use a staged approach for implementation, whereby only less sensitive data are held on the system initially with a facility to input additional data at a later stage when public acceptance may be forthcoming more readily.

What more surreptitious, insidious and pernicious method can one imagine a government using to seduce people into believing that the card will be harmless and the information held will be harmless when it is intended at a later date to expand the information base?

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course it will be expanded.
—Of course it will be. An officer from the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet chairing an interdepartmental committee on the card called for information in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: You could invite participants to outline briefly their views on the feasibility (of the scheme) . . . We suggest that acceptance of the need to introduce such a scheme is likely to be promoted if the Committee's report focuses on combating benefits and fraud.
Every move is designed to ensure that the public is seduced into the belief that the card will be harmless and that the information attaching to it and held by the Government will also be harmless.

In my view, the Australia Card will be draconian, intrusive and totally unnecessary. It is inevitable that there will be leaking of information stored under the identity card system. We have already seen leaks from the Health Insurance Commission which disclosed patients' medical records and recently doctors' income figures were produced in the Parliament by the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett). Of course, records of people's personal details have a market value. In the United States of America companies have paid to obtain these records and it is now not uncommon for people to receive quite unsolicited advice from companies that their wedding anniversary or their wife's birthday is around the corner--

TALK.START.PARA: —That is helpful.
—It is very helpful-with an invitation to make a purchase. Bad enough as that is, imagine what organised crime will do in terms of blackmail once in receipt of information which may embarrass people.

SPEECH.PARA: The far better, cheaper and less dangerous way of tackling the problem of tax and social security fraud is to enforce the powers that are already available. As for social security payments, the Department of Social Security can already cross-check income with income recorded with the Australian Taxation Office. The Liberal policy of introducing a work requirement for unemployment benefits would make sure that the recipients were genuine. As for income tax, we need only consult the 1984 Auditor-General's report or a subsequent report of 1986, in which he set out in very clear and fine detail methods for overcoming deficiencies in tax collections, which I understand are now being implemented.

My final reason for opposing the identity card is a philosophical one. The intellectual pygmies on the other side of the chamber may downplay philosophy, but I think in the very long term it is philosophy which ultimately shapes society. Our system has been based on the premise that one is born free and entitled to exercise a free will unless constrained by law. Where government wishes to limit the exercise of free will, it must be lawfully authorised to do so. The identity card system will virtually outlaw the means of modern existence unless a person obtains government consent for his actions in the form of an identity card. Under this system people will no longer be entitled to exercise free will. Free will will be effectively outlawed unless the Government specifically authorises it. This, of course, turns our entire legal thinking on its head. It is not a system under which I wish to live; it is certainly not a system under which I wish my children to live.

I condemn this Bill. It has no merit, it has no virtue, it has no necessity and it has no place in Australian society. I have no doubt that the vast majority of Australians are totally opposed to it. Notwithstanding the Government's insistence that the Bill proceed, ultimately the Government will be found wanting as a result of it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make a number of points in opposing the Australia Card, or the identity card. I think we should get away from this euphemistic term `Australia Card'. I believe that the Government does not have a mandate to introduce this legislation. I believe that there is a deficiency in the order of introduction of legislation dealing with privacy protection. I believe that there are serious deficiencies in the integrity of the data which will be used to establish the ID card. I believe that there are deficiencies in the physical integrity of the proposed system. Furthermore, I believe that there will be a serious shift in the balance of power between the bureaucracy and the citizen, which is a threat to civil liberties. Finally, I will make the point that the ID card legislation is unnecessary.

SPEECH.PARA: First of all, I turn to the matter of whether the Government has a mandate to introduce the ID card. The claim-we have heard this from both sides of the House at various times in the past-that the elected government has a mandate to carry out its whole program is arrant nonsense. It is quite clear that, when political parties put up a number of points at election time, different electors will vote for or against those points. There is no link between the election of a party to government and the idea that there is a mandate to carry out the whole of its program. The only way in which the government could claim that it had a mandate to carry out any particular part of its program would be if it were to conduct a referendum on that one issue alone. This, of course, is precisely the issue which the Australian Democrats have been raising for some time. We should have in this country an initiative procedure which would allow citizens the right to decide on a particular issue and then direct the government as to how it should behave with respect to that issue.

The fact that the Hawke Government does not have a mandate for the Australia Card was clearly recognised by Mr Hawke when he gave recognition to the fact that at the last election the conservation movement gave considerable support to the Government in certain marginal electorates. He recognised that there was almost a 2 per cent swing towards the Government in those electorates because of the activity of the conservation movement. It is quite specious to claim that those people, who voted principally on the ground of protecting the wet tropics, were also voting for the ID card. As a member of the conservation movement for a very long time, I know that many of those people are opposed to the ID card.

I might use my own voting experience as an example. When I voted I gave my second preference to the Australian Labor Party because I believed that, although its policies in relation to the protection of the environment were somewhat too little too late, nonetheless they were better than those of the Liberal Party of Australia. Recognising that it was not possible for an Australian Democrat to be elected in the lower House, my vote therefore went towards the election of the Australian Labor Party. Yet, here I am strongly opposing the ID card.

So, to claim that the Government has a mandate because it was elected is nonsense. If the Government claims in any sense that it has a mandate, surely it had a mandate not to sell uranium to France. Indeed, it has a mandate from this election to protect the wet tropics of north Queensland. But I am concerned to hear that despite very strong guarantees that that action would be carried out forthwith, we find nonetheless in the Governor-General's Speech that the Government will consult with the Queensland Government. That consultation has been carried on for a long time with very little result in relation to the protection of those areas. I also noticed that last weekend the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) said that he was unhappy with the arbitrary nature of the Australian Labor Party's three-mine policy in relation to uranium mining and that he would support mining against arguments put up only on ideological grounds. I remind Mr Kerin that he is in fact speaking against the ALP policy, a policy on which the electors voted this Government in and on which this Government has a mandate.

Furthermore, the Government argues that because it won a majority of seats in the lower House for some reason the Opposition-the Australian Democrats, the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia-must somehow fall in behind it on the matter of the ID card. But the Australian Democrats campaigned very strongly on the ID card and we improved our representation in this place. By the same logic we might argue that we therefore have a mandate given to us by our constituents to oppose the Australia Card.

During the election I contacted a number of my friends and colleagues-believe it or not I probably have more friends and colleagues in the Labor Party than in any other party-to ask for their support during the election in a number of different ways, including letterboxing and all the other things people do during elections. Naturally, I was somewhat concerned to broach with these Labor Party people the question of the ID card because I thought it might have been a sensitive area. But in every single case the conversation got around to the ID card at their instigation and in every single case they were strongly opposed to it and were very pleased to support me because I was opposed to it. I point out that that opposition extended not only to members and supporters of the ALP but also to members of Parliament both at the State and Federal levels.

It is a travesty of the process of representative democracy that Labor senators in this case are being more loyal to the Party than they are to their consciences. The system of binding individuals in government in Parliament means that a minority can control the legislative decisions. If one has a small group of eight or nine people and one can get a majority of one in that small group, that group is then bound in its decision when it moves into a larger group and that larger group then becomes bound. It then moves into the Parliament and the whole group becomes bound whereas in fact there may be a majority opposed to the decision. The only mandate which a government has is a mandate to form a government. The mandate which every individual who is elected to Parliament has-every senator has-is to exercise his or her conscience. I ask my fellow senators to do just that on this issue.

The second point I wish to raise relates to the order of the introduction of legislation dealing with privacy protection. In late 1987 Australia remains one of the very few advanced Western nations without information privacy and data protection laws. Despite contributions to the international guidelines on privacy protection at the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development by Australia, despite the fact that the OECD expert group was chaired by an Australian, despite the publication of the international guideline as long ago as 1980 and despite the Australian Law Reform Commission's report of 1983 which concluded that existing protections were inadequate, Australia does not yet have even the most fundamental information and privacy protection. If the Government is so concerned about privacy protection, why has it not, in the last four years, moved ahead with legislation in this area? One must assume either that the Government does not think that privacy protection, as a matter of principle, is all that important or that Australia has not reached that degree of sophistication when privacy protection is necessary. If the former, the Government was and is clearly wrong; but if the latter, we must note the absolute inconsistency in the Government's argument. Let us compare three statements. The first is:
Australia has not needed privacy protection legislation till now.
The second is:
Australia will now get the most stringent privacy protection legislation-
they are Senator Ryan's words-
to accompany the Australia Card legislation.
The third claim is:
The Australia Card poses no threat to privacy or civil liberties.

Those three statements prove the lie to the argument that the ID card poses no threat to privacy or civil liberty. The second point is that Australia does indeed need privacy protection. It needs it now, and it should be introduced well before there is any further consideration of an Australia Card. Only against the background of the successful operation of privacy protection legislation should an Australia Card be considered, and that is some years down the track.

The third point I should like to raise relates to the integrity of the data, and much has been said on this point. The data on which this card will be based lacks the integrity required to carry out the functions for which the card and its accompanying database will be created. Birth certificates as yet are not computerised. They are not as yet checked against death certificates, and indeed it is possible for anybody to walk into any of the State registries of births, marriages and deaths and collect a birth certificate on behalf of another person. When one applies for a passport or several of the other documents to which reference has been made, if those documents are based on birth certificates they have no more integrity than the integrity of the birth certificate. Moreover, there is a difficulty concerning the integrity of the use of that data. The accuracy of the information is related very much to the use to which that information is to be put. We all know that when information is collected for particular purposes and then used for other unrelated purposes, there is the real possibility that that data can be misinterpreted. For instance, the information which is collected by the Australian Taxation Office in relation to the terms `spouse' or `dependant' may well vary from the use of these same terms in the database used by the Department of Social Security or the Department of Community Services and Health. When those sources of information become merged, there is the real possibility that that data can be misinterpreted.

Fourthly, there is the matter of technical security and much has been made of this. The security of the system can be breached both with respect to people security and to technical security. We are told that some 2,000 people will have access to the central computer. Frankly, I believe that, with the best will in the world, failures will occur either through error or through deliberate corruption or breaching of that system. As for simple error, I point to an experience I had some years ago when helping my daughter who was then at high school. She had been doing her homework on the back of computer paper which had been given to the school to be used up. After doing some mathematical computations on the one side I turned the sheet over and there, on the other side, were the details of a visit by a woman to a gynaecologist, which included a considerable amount of personal detail. That computer paper had come from the then Medibank Private office. Clearly there had been a breach in security in that office which had quite innocently allowed that potentially extremely damaging information to get out. We also have the real possibility of corruption in the system: that people will quite deliberately divulge information for purposes of crime or personal advancement.

Some mention has been made of the use of a dedicated landline. Anybody who has looked at the possibility of breaching dedicated landlines knows that there is precious little security in those landlines to stop anybody who really wants to get into that system. Even the use of complicated ways of encoding information on that landline still does not guarantee that that information cannot be used for illegitimate purposes.

A point which I do not think has been mentioned as yet is the technical security of the data. In the event of a high level nuclear explosion in a nuclear war, computers and all other devices which are ultimately dependent upon transistors and printed circuitry for their operation are susceptible to complete damage by electromagnetic pulse, a pulse of very high voltage electricity which passes through these devices. So we must remember that we would be tying up much of our system in a way which would make it vulnerable to this sort of total loss in the event of a nuclear war. We must remember that in the event of war, a centralised computer system, with all this data on it, would enable an invading force to get a quick handle on every person in the country. We need only to remember what happened to the Jews in Holland during the Second World War. Holland had such a system, which allowed the nazis to arrest and exterminate a high proportion of the Jewish population in Holland, compared with France, which did have a system but, typical of the French, it did not work very well and most of the French Jews were able to escape and a much smaller proportion were caught. In the event of war it would be absolutely necessary that the first thing to be done would be to prevent enemy access to every computer and to ensure that data did not fall into the hands of the enemy.

The fifth point I would like to mention is the shift in balance between the elitists and those who are not so advantaged in our community posed by the introduction of this legislation. The people with less access to financial resources, the less well educated in our community and the people who are just naturally more timid will have more of their liberty removed by the introduction of the card than those who are more aggressive, who know how these systems work and who know how to intrude their own personalities into the system to get things done. I am reminded that most people in this chamber will have access to computers and will have some knowledge of how they operate. We have an enormous advantage over probably 90 per cent of other Australians who do not yet have that knowledge, that skill and that experience. Every time I watch the evening news and see how the international money market is operating and I realise the level of technical sophistication which serves those people in that area, I am reminded that, compared with the people in this chamber, they have access to much more sophisticated technology. The growth of technology has increased the relative disadvantage of those at the bottom of the scale and increased the advantage of the elites. The Australia Card would simply put into a bureaucratic straitjacket a concrete example of that difference.

Sixthly, I would also like to make the point that the Australia Card is quite unnecessary. If taxation is about redressing inequity, the main inhibition to that is not tax avoidance; it is the legal structures which this Government and previous governments have put in place which allow those with vast capital to avoid the payment of the tax which morally should be paid. I mention again the figures which I gave in my maiden speech the other day. Between 1984 and 1986 the number of Australians with more than $50m increased from 16 to 56. Their average wealth now stands at $125m each. Yet at the same time we have moved to a situation where just over 20 per cent of children in Australia live in families on welfare and in poverty. The absolute number of these children is approaching 750,000. Against that background, we have seen just in recent days the Government reintroduce negative gearing, giving tax relief to the wealthy. The problem is not one of identity; it is not a problem of tax avoidance; the problem is the structure in this country which allows the wealthy to get away without paying what morally they should be paying. I draw attention to a piece in yesterday's Age in which it is said:
Negative gearing: many have heard of it, few know what it means. Now that negative gearing is back in favour, how can the average investor profit from it?
That is the structure which this Government is setting up while it talks about tax cheats and social security fraud.

The Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card was presented with evidence from the Australian Taxation Office. After being pressed by that Committee, the Taxation Office agreed that a tax file number with a level of integrity similar to that proposed for the Australia Card would produce similar revenue gains to those estimated for the Australia Card without the photo option, with similar staff and equipment costs. The majority of the Committee then concluded that they could:

see no reason why the integrity of an improved tax-file number could not approach that of the Australia Card and hence attract similar revenue benefits to those estimated for the Australia Card without photograph.

The situation, quite simply, is this: the improved use of the tax file number could indeed achieve what the Australia Card sets out to achieve in the legitimate areas of curbing tax avoidance and evasion, and the Government has given nowhere any explanation as to why it is not prepared to adopt that strategy. We are still waiting to hear from the Government why the tax file number option is not as good as the use of the Australia Card-and it is far less intrusive.

I reiterate that the Government has no mandate to impose the Australia Card on the Australian people. It has a mandate to govern, and that does not include the introduction of the Australia Card. The Government is proceeding in the wrong order. Before it even considers an Australia Card, it has a duty-a responsibility which extends some years into the past and which has not been taken up as yet-to introduce privacy protection legislation. It is only against the background of the successful operation of such legislation that it should then consider an Australia Card.

As I have said, there is a problem with the integrity of the data which will be used in the build up of the data for the Australia Card. There is a problem with the physical integrity of the system and the protection of the data once it is collected. I believe it shifts very seriously the balance between the bureaucracy and the citizen which poses quite serious intrusions into civil liberties. Finally, the introduction of the Australia Card is quite unnecessary because there is a much better option which is tied specifically to those areas which the Government should legitimately seek to address-that is, to improve the integrity and use of the tax file number.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will concentrate primarily on the implications for the law enforcement agencies of the introduction of an ID card. In particular, I wish to address the Government's claim that an ID card is an essential tool in bolstering the effort against organised crime, the cash economy, tax avoidance and welfare fraud. All the evidence contradicts the claim on all counts. Firstly, the Government has repeatedly claimed that an ID card would play an important role in the wider battle against organised crime. Experienced royal commissioners, law enforcement agencies, criminals themselves and overseas evidence have all contested this view very strongly. For instance, former Royal Commissioner Frank Costigan, QC, and his senior counsel Douglas Meagher, QC, have expressed strong opposition to the ID card on the grounds that it will be of great potential benefit and use to organised crime. Mr Costigan, in evidence to the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card, indicated that he had:

SPEECH.PARA: some trouble in understanding, except at a low level of crime, how an Australia Card would help in the fight against organised crime.

Douglas Meagher, QC, argued that there were `less draconian' means than the ID card proposal for tackling fraud based on false identities. The Australian Federal Police (AFP) in its submission to the Joint Select Committee conceded that the card would be next to useless in the fight against organised crime. The Government's submission acknowledged this stating:
The AFP adds that there are no realistic grounds for anticipating any impact on the level of organised crime generally.
Furthermore, the National Secretary of the Australian Federal Police Association, Chris Eaton, stated:
A national identity card is not the answer to the type of fraud identified by the report.
He continued:
The Australia Card will only be misused to cover the trail of organised crime protected by the presumption of validity presented by the card.
The Chairman of the Law and Order Foundation, former New South Wales policeman Mr Merv Beck, said that the ID card could pave the way for corporate crime on a massive scale. He recently pointed out:
There is no way that government could police the thousands of public servants with access to people's private records from stealing or selling information to these organised crime groups.
He further warned:

Complete dossiers will be easily maintained by organised crime groups on police officers, magistrates, judges, lawyers, politicians and others in senior positions for the purpose of blackmailing or corrupting these officials for favours.

On the other side of the law, in his exposition of the activities of organised crime in this country, the former bagman for the mob, Frank Duggan, told of the consummate ease with which organised criminals had been able to obtain taxation records, false passports, drivers licences, medical certificates and currency. Referring to the ease with which the mob was able to find taxation files, Frank Duggan said:
We got Croc's whole file, which included letters from the Government Solicitor and a whole load of things like that. But you can get anything if you pay the right price.

Only last week in the Sydney courts, alleged crime figures Barry Bull and Snapper Cornwell again demonstrated that drug-runners and the like have no trouble in obtaining false passports, drivers licences or anything else. The overwhelming evidence demonstrates that the introduction of an ID card, the integrity of which cannot be guaranteed, will expand rather than inhibit the opportunities for fraud and illegal trade in and use of false identities. This is precisely what has occurred in other countries which have adopted forms of national identification systems. Studies by the United States Government have unanimously concluded that a system of national ID cards helps rather than combats the spread of organised crime.

Secondly, the Government has consistently claimed that an ID card is necessary to stamp out taxation fraud. Recent scrutiny has shown that the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) is still not serious about eliminating taxation fraud. This gross failure was documented recently in the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure titled Review of 5 Auditor-General's Efficiency Audit Reports into the Australian Taxation Office. The Committee revealed `serious shortcomings within certain ATO philosophies and operations', and suggested that `significant losses to taxation revenue were being incurred'. Further, the Committee stated:

. . . taxation revenue losses through non-detection of total taxpayer incomes could conceivably amount to several billion dollars each year . . . not simply because of highly organised evasion schemes. In large measures it can simply be attributed to ATO's own internal inadequacies.
This finding renders as complete nonsense the Government's claim that the civil conscription of the ID card is the key to the elimination of taxation avoidance.

Put simply, the Government is treating neither the symptoms nor the cause. Rigorous enforcement of existing taxation provisions is not happening. This is also the case in the area of welfare fraud which is the third area which the Government claims the ID card would clean out. The Federal Government has argued that the rejection of the ID card would hamper the apprehension of welfare cheats.

There has, however, been a succession of reports from a number of law enforcement agencies which have explicitly and implicitly criticised the Hawke Government for its lack of resolve in tackling welfare fraud using existing legislation. In November 1985, a Joint Task Force to Review Australian Federal Police Resources warned:

The group was presented with cases of serious criminal activities which are not being investigated because of staff shortages. As for the smaller criminal activities-such as many D.S.S. frauds-most of these are unable to be investigated. The Revenue implications of the overall situation are clear.

Almost a year later, the Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP) reinforced the Task Force's concern that thousands of welfare fraud cases were going uninvestigated. In his annual report 1985-86, tabled in October last year, the DPP stated:

The Australian Federal Police does not have the resources to cope with more than a few of the large number of cases referred to it. The A.F.P. seeks to concentrate its efforts on the very serious cases.
As a result, most middle range welfare frauds are not investigated with damaging effects on the `deterrent value of prosecution in the area'.

The Government is apparently willing to employ an extra 2,150 public servants to administer an intrusive form of civil conscription for honest, decent Australians, whilst refusing repeated pleas from the Australian Federal Police, the National Crime Authority, the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence and the Director of Public Prosecutions for support in the battle against the real criminals-drug traffickers, organised crime, tax avoiders and welfare cheats.
