What are the facts? Will the ID card stop or even hamper welfare fraud? By the Government's own reckoning, it will not. The Department of Social Security gave evidence to the Joint Select Committee that the introduction of the ID card proposal would result in no net savings. After all, the ID card will not address the principal means of welfare fraud-that is, the misstatement of personal incomes. And in any case, the Department of Social Security has indicated that an ID card will not be sufficient proof of identity for its purposes. What a stunning condemnation of the integrity of the proposed ID card.

For the purposes of argument though, let us assume that the ID card was successful in identifying welfare cheats. Judging by the Government's record to date, that is all that would happen. As we have already seen, even if the cheats were identified, the evidence suggests that they would not be prosecuted. Law without enforcement is useless. And the Hawke Government's record on enforcement is absolutely lamentable. Until the Hawke Government acts to repair its shocking record on law enforcement, it does not have one scintilla of credibility to back its drive for an ID card. A long sorry list of government law enforcement agencies have made repeated pleas for more adequate resources and investigative powers. In November 1985 the joint task force on the adequacy of the AFP found:
The Joint Task Group notes major resource problems in the drugs and intelligence areas of the AFP, the CIB functions and the organised crime units.
. . . unless there is a substantial lift in overall resource levels the AFP will be increasingly unable to discharge its priority functions effectively.

These resources have not been forthcoming. In November 1986 the Australian Federal Police Commissioner reiterated his earlier pleas for more resources and stated that airport security was at a `bare minimum, with little capacity to respond to a sudden increase in the level of threat'. Neither have resources been forthcoming for the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence (ABCI) which has been starved of staff and funding for its drugs database. In his report to the Australian Police Ministers Council, the Chairman of the ABCI management committee warned:
. . . the lack of support staff is having an adverse effect upon the efficiency and development of the organisation.

Also indicative of the low priority given to combating organised crime is the Government's apparent open door policy on illegal drug importation. A report prepared by the senior Customs inspector on the Melbourne waterfront found:
The criminal element has little to fear from Customs on the waterfront except through its own carelessness.

This report was backed by an International Narcotics Control Board report which identified Australia as an important link in the passage of heroin from South East Asia to Europe and the United States of America. At this point it is worth repeating the view of Australia's emeritus professor of crime fighting, Frank Costigan, that an ID card would aid rather than hinder the spread of organised crime. The Government's case for an ID card is irrevocably weakened by its gross failure to adopt the recommendations of successive royal commissions to strengthen the hand of law enforcement agencies in the war against crime. This failure has been devastatingly documented by the Australian Federal Police Commissioner and the National Crime Authority in their respective recent annual reports. In his 1985-86 annual report the Federal Police Commissioner stated:
Despite the publicity generated by the drug summit, little real progress has been made in the vital area of legislation essential for the effective fight against drug trafficking.

Such legislation included the forfeiture and confiscation of assets, police access to taxation records, police access to records of banks and other financial institutions, the creation of an offence to send drugs through the mail and model drug legislation.

In addition to the above the Government has also let down the National Crime Authority and other law enforcement bodies by procrastinating for four years on effective phone tapping powers, witness protection legislation, money laundering protection measures and even the extension of its very life. The Hawke Government will be powerless to justify civil conscription allegedly to combat tax and welfare fraud until all existing measures are pursued to the hilt. As the sorry record indicates, this is a long way off.

The message for the Hawke Government is clear: give your excellent law enforcement agencies a chance against the burgeoning organised crime in this country. Do not establish a new army of public servants while denying the law bodies their proper avenue-the staff to chase real criminals. Do not saddle ordinary decent law abiding Australians with an intrusive, expensive dog licence. Do not reverse the relationship between the individual and the State by issuing a card so that holders of the card will be, according to the Health Insurance Commission, `those identities entitled to operate in the Australian community'-a most distasteful phrase. Until the Hawke Government has expended all its energies in pursuing the frauds, tax and welfare cheats, the ID card will be rejected wholeheartedly by the people of Australia.

The Hawke Government is utterly confused about the revenue it expects to receive from the introduction of its national numbering system. It is simply a case of `pick a number-any number'. The original Blewett proposal submitted to the National Taxation Summit estimated savings, after four years, as $800m per year. Only six months later the then Minister for Health, Dr Blewett, wrote in the publication Civil Liberty that the revenue gain would be $500m per year. On this occasion Dr Blewett conceded that the original estimate of return of $800m per annum was incorrect. But the wheel turned again during the election campaign when Dr Blewett performed yet another somersault on the estimated revenue gain. In a Press release on 22 June 1987, Dr Blewett stated unequivocally:
It is conservatively estimated that the Australia Card will save almost $900 million in public funds which are now being lost through tax evasion and welfare fraud.

Then, of course, there was the Four Corners program and debate in which the Special Minister of State, Senator Ryan, argued that the ID card would reap $4.75 billion over 10 years. This comprised a total anticipated revenue of $5.5 billion less the establishment cost of $750m. However, on the same program, Senator Ryan contradicted herself when, as recorded on page 28 of the transcript, she stated:
The ordinary taxpayers would be prepared for us to lift the benefits and indeed, we'd have an extra $5,000 million a year to spend on them.
So the revenue gain from the ID card according to Senator Ryan on the Four Corners program would be approximately $5 billion every year.

Further disagreement and confusion came on 16 September when the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) spoke at the Australian Financial Review post-Budget dinner. The Prime Minister added yet another estimate of the expected revenue gain when he said:
None of the critics of the Australia Card has effectively questioned the estimate that it could raise nearly $1 billion of extra revenue.

Of course, he did not say over what period. That was yet another guess of the expected revenue gain. For the record, I for one challenge him, Dr Blewett and Senator Ryan to demonstrate this phoney, rubbery figure and give proper details of it. Clearly, the Hawke Government has no idea of the income it can expect from the ID card. It is an absurdity that the Hawke Government is expecting the Australian populace to accept a system of numbering when it has no idea of what the revenue gain will be. Certainly, the Government has no idea of the cost of the card, whether it be the cost to its own administration or to business, large, small or medium. It is apparent that Government estimates of projected income are hopeful and that estimates of cost to business are suppressed. Like the expected revenue gain, Government estimates of the costs to both itself and industry vary widely, ranging from as low as $49m to as high as nearly $800m. Even worse, the Government's most realistic estimate of the cost of the ID card has been badly underestimated. For example, the Government's costing contains no provision for replacement of sophisticated equipment over a 10-year period-an omission described by the experts as ludicrous. There are serious underestimates of the number of transactions and thus the costs involved in keeping records up to date. No provision is included for the levels of compliance required by State and local governments-a cost predicted to be very substantial indeed.

When will we hear from the prominent Government senators and supporters for freedom? I have looked at the list and have not found many of the Government senators who I would expect to be in the forefront of the debate. I refer to Senator Bolkus, Senator Cooney, Senator Childs, Senator Devlin and Senator Devereux. None of these has yet spoken. I trust that we will get their views before long. The Australian public needs to know what some of these people really believe about the ID card.

Senator Ryan categorically defends the integrity of the system. We do not really know which system, but she still defends it. I think that Frank Duggan is closer to the mark when he says that the system is no better than the operators. He has proved his point. Dr McGoldrick found out all about the integrity of a system with the naming of his patients, which was deemed to be in the public interest. A little while ago hackers cracked the Pentagon system. I noticed headlines in yesterday's paper that hackers broke into the network of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. Still Senator Ryan extravagantly, foolishly and incorrectly makes claims that she cannot deliver. She knows, as we know, that the system is not in absolute total integrity.

I believe it was on or about 1 September that, to further the debate, Senator Ryan said that she would welcome comment. In order that I could participate in this debate and use the best information available, I wrote to Senator Ryan on that day stating that I wished to participate in the debate and asking for the answers to 10 simple questions. Three weeks later, and after another follow-up letter-surprise, surprise-I still have not had a response to the simple information that I sought.

In view of the fact that it has not been possible to get a response, I will now ask those questions and ask Senator Ryan to provide me with the information I seek, at least in the summing up of the debate unless she is able to supply it for me today. The 10 questions are: firstly, did the Department of Social Security advise that only 0.6 per cent of its losses were based on false identity? Secondly, what is the official agreed figure for departmental overpayment and how is it arrived at? Thirdly, what allowance has been made for the new false identity fraud that will be treated by an official ID card? Fourthly, what is the official agreed figure for tax evasion for the 1986-87 year, and how is it arrived at? Fifthly, has the Commissioner of Taxation taken all possible steps to implement the present laws? Sixthly, if not, why should the Government believe that the new laws would be implemented any more fully? Seventhly, has tightening up produced an improved recovery from evaders and, if so, how much for the 1986-87 year? Eighthly, which law enforcement authorities have agreed that an ID card will eliminate social security fraud or tax fraud? Ninthly, what additional resources are planned for the Australian Federal Police to police and prosecute offenders under the Act? Tenthly, what percentage of the total population does the Government assess to be cheating under tax or social security laws? These questions are very simple. I would like to get answers to them even though it has not been possible to get them in time for the debate, as I requested.

To summarise, every Minister seems to be giving different information. I regret only that so far we have not heard Senator Evans speak in the debate. I am sure that he could have confused us all further. No law enforcement authority agrees that a card would do the things claimed by the Government. The Government's record on law enforcement over its four years in office could not make anyone believe that it would change now. The costs of the card are not established. The grossly rubbery recovery figures are stated with no backing of any sort. Real criminals will be the major beneficiaries of this brand new form of criminal enterprise. Probably 15 million decent, honest Australians will be numbered, carded and recorded as an excuse for the Government not carrying out the provisions that already exist, in the name of chasing a handful of wrongdoers. The card will not change the operation of the black, or cash, economy. No other Western country has found it necessary or desirable to inflict such a system on its people.

I oppose the Bill. I oppose its philosophy. I oppose its presentation. I particularly oppose the terminology it applies to people. Now that information-as distinct from bland political statements-is being made public already 60 per cent of Australians are opposed to the card. Decent Australians are offended by the assumption that they are all crooks. Criminals embrace the card enthusiastically for the new profitable opportunities it will provide. I oppose the Bill and support the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the third time this chamber has debated the Australia Card Bill at great length. I must say that some of the thrill of the debate has gone. Very little that is new has been added in the last 15 or so hours in this, the third debate. Possibly the intrusion of the safety of dedicated landlines that Senator Coulter referred to earlier is one of the very few new factors that have been introduced. What we have heard in the last 15 or so hours of debate has been a regurgitation of previous arguments. Most of the arguments do not focus on each other. They are like ships passing in the night.

SPEECH.PARA: We on this side of the chamber have put forward certain propositions that have rarely been counteracted by the other side and probably vice versa. What this has meant, apart from a drop in Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio ratings over the last few days, is that we are wasting about 25 hours debating the issue here, when the intention all along has been to refer the issue to a select committee that will, in a more concise way, go away, confront the issues and discuss them one by one. So what we have indulged in here is a belief, at least by the Opposition, that some political brownie points can be attributed by having a long debate on this issue.

I refer any honourable senator who is interested-I do not recommend it-to my previous half-hour contribution on the Australia Card. I could be like others, get it out of the drawer and regurgitate it for half an hour. That not only would be boring but also would not be at all productive, so I do not intend to do that. I just want to go to two or three issues. The first issue which has come across a lot in this debate is whether the Government has a mandate. Some honourable senators on this side of the chamber feel passionately about this. I do not. Some honourable senators on the other side contest whether we have a mandate. I, for one, have never understood what a mandate is. It seems to me that a mandate is something one claims after an election to justify putting something through. It is denied by the other side by a whole series of devices.

Ultimately, the only validity of a mandate, I would suggest, is whether one gets something through this chamber by constitutional means. The ultimate test of a mandate will probably be in March next year when, for one of the few occasions, we troop across to the House of Representatives, we all sit there and we have one big division. That will be the mandate. That will be what determines what the people think because it will be the combined views of the people as expressed in the result of the House of Representatives and the Senate.

The last election was called on the issue of the Australia Card. No one could argue that it was fought exclusively on that issue. People will argue around the edges as to what extent it featured in the campaign. From a Government point of view, we do not have to set the agenda for most of the campaign. We are in government. We are being judged on our record when we go to the people of Australia. It is up to the Opposition-and it was up to the Opposition, the Australian Democrats and others-to raise what it regarded as the major issue. Our very first campaign advertisements-full page ads costing about $5,000 a page-appeared across this nation, I think, three days after the election was announced, announcing our support for the Australia Card. So we ran our colours up the mast very early. There was virtually no response from Liberal Party members, from their brothers in the National Party or from the Democrats on this issue. The challenge was launched. We called an election on the issue. We put in our full page ads. There was virtually no response from the Opposition.

There were a variety of reasons for that. I think the Opposition squibbed the debate. It thought that it would be an electoral liability to fight an election on the Australia Card, and it refused to do so. Opposition members had other problems at the time. They were scrambling to get a tax policy ready. They were scrambling to get a health policy ready. They were scrambling to get a communications policy together which, by the way, has not been released yet. They did get an education policy together but refused to release the costings. So they had other problems that may have distracted their focusing on the Australia Card issue. But it certainly was not taken up by them. So the later claim by people such as Senator MacGibbon that the Opposition got 16,000 more votes Australia-wide than the Labor Party and that, therefore, we do not have a mandate to introduce the card and it has a mandate to oppose the card is not justified on the basis that the Australia Card was not a major issue raised by the Opposition in the election period.

Let me go to the second point and consider why people are opposing the card. It takes a number of levels. One of the first levels, which is a very practical level, is for some Opposition members to say that it will not work. Senator Archer is an example of that. He said that it will never raise the money we are talking about. When it comes to predictions of revenue raising, Budget deficits, employment growth and the rest of it, we have the runs on the board. When we claimed when we were elected in 1983 that we would create 500,000 jobs in the first three years of government we were laughed at. But we did it. When we set targets for the Budget deficit year by year we were laughed at, but we achieved them or came in even lower. When we introduced the fringe benefits tax, opposed by the Opposition in this chamber, and said, `Here is the minimum revenue we will get', again, in snide remarks and attacks in this and the other chamber we were told that we would never meet our targets.

So, with respect, when we say that the Australia Card will bring in an X amount of dollars, we are really saying that we think that is the minimum that it will bring in. The `won't work' argument running through many of the Opposition speeches lacks credibility. It cannot be counted. It cannot be contradicted absolutely, of course, because we have to suck it and see. We will have to find out when the revenue comes in whether it matches the target. I just point to our track record of fairly accurate predictions in a whole range of areas.

The second level of argument comes from the civil libertarians. I will come back to them in a moment, but there must be some valid concerns about civil liberties in this regard. However, we point to the protections we are providing through the privacy legislation and through the Data Protection Authority. We have even been criticised in this debate for not doing this earlier as a general issue. If we are to be criticised for this, I think members of the Opposition have to take part of the blame. After all, they ruled for 30 out of 34 years. However, very little complaint has been heard here about the lack of protection for the data that already exists in the community. Most members of the community-not all, but most-are the subject of immense amounts of data stored in computers, whether it be through the American Express card, Bankcard, or anything else. Whatever happens in the end with the Australia Card, even if for some reason it falters, we still must proceed with the privacy aspect and the Data Protection Agency, because there is an area of information storage which is running riot with no coverage and no restrictions.

A third section of people who oppose the Australia Card are some of those who belong to what I describe as the broad labour movement. That has been pointed out by Opposition senators. To me it is one of the great ironies that many of the people to whom I talk in the labour movement agree with the basic concept of the Australia Card, its aims, et cetera, but they always raise one more point. They say, `We trust you to keep the privacy aspects, to restrict the card's use and not to misuse it. Those we don't trust are the conservatives. They will misuse it when they get into power. They will extend its use, they will give it a police function and we will become a fascist state'. I think a little more of those opposite here than to think that they would do that, but that is essentially why some people in the labour movement, the Australian Council of Trade Unions and even the Australian Labor Party have expressed doubts about the Australia Card. They are doubtful not about this Government's ability to see it up and running as a good measure but about what may happen in the future with a Liberal-National Party coalition government, be such a government hard to imagine at the moment. The labour movement opposes the card for that reason.

I come back to the civil libertarians. I have some sympathy for them. They are now embroiled in a campaign with a whole series of allies who are their traditional enemies. The whole ratbag Right-I do not include anyone in this chamber in this-is out there now doing the same thing as it did with the Bill of Rights legislation, taking parts of clauses, or one clause, ignoring their relationship to other clauses and then totally distorting them. We have claims on talkback radio and in letters to newspapers and newsletters about all sorts of uses of the Australia Card that have never been envisaged, never been contemplated and never been intended. The same thing happened with the Bill of Rights legislation. Clause after clause was taken totally out of context and totally distorted. The victims of that campaign were the very civil libertarians that are running a campaign against the Australia Card. I feel a little sorry for them that they have to be associated with such a distorting campaign.

There is no direct linkage between what I regard as the ratbag Right and the civil libertarians. They are not combining generally on platforms. But I am a little disappointed that the civil libertarians, in their haste to oppose the Australia Card Bill, will not at least examine some of the arguments being used against the Australia Card by the ratbag Right and dismiss them. They do the service of civil liberties in this country a great disservice by not exposing those ratbag arguments and having them pushed off the agenda. They should have done so much earlier.

I move to a third point. A lot of points have been made as to whether there is public support for the Australia Card. People look at opinion polls, et cetera. That is very hard to gauge, because the opinion polls show that ostensibly support for the Australia Card has dropped off. That is not a new function in politics. What has happened is that the issue has been politically polarised. Many people whose support is dropping away from the Australia Card and who initially thought it was a good idea are responding to Liberal or National Party leadership. That is a political reality. It is not so much that they have been disaffected with the Australia Card one way or the other-they may or may not have been; it is hard to determine-but once an issue becomes polarised, support drops. It drops because of what is said by the political leadership of one party and the loyalty of the voters responding to that. It happens in referendums. If the market research were undertaken into four-year terms and we in this chamber were all agreed on four-year terms, that would be reflected in a referendum, but the moment Mr Howard or someone else in Opposition-or, if the position were reversed, we on this side-opposed the proposition, support would drop from 80 per cent to 50 per cent automatically. That accounts for a lot of what is shown in the polls.

The Government has been criticised by a few speakers in this chamber for not doing enough already about tax evasion. No government has been more diligent in attacking tax avoidance and evasion-and, quite frankly, we have not had enough co-operation from those opposite in that task. Those opposite, when in government from 1975 to 1983, did not do anywhere near enough to stop the haemorrhaging of tax revenue through tax avoidance. Those opposite really came to the party on only one occasion-in 1982, when the report of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union hit with its full impact. There was a massive panic and the then Government decided to introduce the bottom of the harbour legislation. Even then, not all of those opposite supported the principle of the legislation. But, to save their political hide, a majority of Liberals opposite and in the other chamber voted for retrospectivity. The moment they lost the election, they disavowed that principle. But if we want to stop tax avoidance at least, adherence to the principle of retrospectivity-I talk to Senator Coulter in this respect-is the one way of removing it once and for all. When a principle is established in this chamber to attack tax avoiders retrospectively, there is no point in people avoiding tax because they will eventually have to pay out the lot, whereas, as the law exists now, until they are discovered they can pocket their ill-gotten gains.

Much play has been made on the leaking of information. I make the point that no information is to be kept under the Australia Card that does not already exist. I point out that 10 million Australians are already on one file, called the electoral roll, where their name, address, date of birth and occupation are all recorded. I have not heard any objection to having an electoral roll-at least, not from a majority of senators.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some people still manage to vote twice.

—We might come to that in a big way, later in the day, but not many people do that. Very few cases have ever been proved. In the Nunawading case in Victoria in 1985, 12 allegations of double voting were made by the Liberal Party in its submission to Justice Starke. We disproved every one, I think to the satisfaction of the Liberal Party. But we will get on to that on another occasion. I just make the point that no extra information is to be kept. All systems are somewhat vulnerable in some ways; this one, though, as a result of the dedicated approach taken, will be less vulnerable than any of the existing ones.

SPEECH.PARA: I sum up as to why we need an Australia Card. I feel sorry for those people in the community who have no ability at all to exploit the system, who are absolute victims of the system. There is very little sympathy for the tax cheats because they are cheating on their fellow citizen. They are taking money out of the pocket of their fellow citizen. There is very little sympathy for those involved in welfare fraud, because they are depriving those in need of extra income. There is very little sympathy for those illegal immigrants who are in fact jumping the queue. Many people overseas who are lawfully waiting their turn simply have to wait longer because illegal immigrants are taking their spots in this country.

I am almost tempted-I was almost diverted into doing so-to repeat the speech that I gave a year or so ago during the second reading debate on this legislation. Senator Brownhill is not going to tempt me into doing so. I conclude by saying that nothing really new has been introduced into this debate. I suspect, if I can count correctly, that a select committee inquiry is anticipated. I will be very interested in the results of that and where we go from there.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Sen J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to congratulate all of my National Party colleagues who have taken part in this debate on the Australia Card Bill 1986 [No. 3] on the very firm and unflinching position that they have taken against the Australia Card legislation. Although this is my first speech in this place on this issue, many of them have spoken on three occasions in opposing this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: It should be pointed out clearly that these men and the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Sinclair) spoke out against this legislation during the election campaign. The Rt Hon. Ian Sinclair issued no fewer than eight formal statements and releases on the identity card. Indeed, a recent editorial in the New South Wales rural newspaper, the Land, gave Mr Sinclair credit for speaking out against the ID card, particularly during the election campaign. For my part, I took out a full page advertisement in Melbourne newspapers-the Sun, the Age and several ethnic newspapers-opposing the ID card. So it is false to allege that the National Party has not been campaigning actively, consistently and unflinchingly against this legislation.

Why should the National Party not take this position? Its traditions lie with the rural community. As we campaigned across the great State of Victoria we got the message straight and clear from rural Australia that it does not want the ID card. As I said, the National Party is entrenched in its tradition of representing rural people and our stand on this legislation is another fine example of it. This Bill is another example of the way in which the Government is weighing down the rural community with administrative requirements and placing rural people at the beck and call of the bureaucracy. That is what this Government is dishing up to the rural community once again.

This Government is avoiding the relevant issues within the rural community. With the Budget, the ID card is another example of why the Government in the last five years of its administration has been termed `bush basher'. It is impractical for the rural community. It is an insult to rural Australia. Farmers and their families will be required to travel to card authorities to be identified and to have their already fragile economic circumstances subject to further investigation. The ID card will dehumanise the life of the rural community. It will take out the human element-that quality of life that we all respect in rural Australia.

I would like to give one of the best examples of how the ID card will place numbers on the relationships between people in rural Australia. I refer to those quaint and charming but very businesslike areas, the cattle yards, which are so often the heart of the rural community. Relationships which were based on a handshake between men who trusted one another and sales and deals done by a look in the eye will now be reduced to an exchange of a plastic identification card. It is a disgrace that the card will replace all the honesty and trust, the very natural ways of life, that have been built up in rural Australia. The quality of life which we know the rural community enjoys and which most Australians respect and envy will be lost with the introduction of this card.

I make these points to show clearly that the senators from the Government side, unlike those from the National Party, do not come to this debate with clean hands. Last Monday Senator Bolkus from the Labor Left had to give a personal explanation to the Senate for his public comments opposing the ID card. While it was a contorted explanation, in substance it was really saying, `Well, I do oppose this card but I apologise for my public comments because the Caucus is my conscience and conscience is the Caucus. I will toe the line'. These comments by Senator Bolkus, these double standards, merely highlight the dishonesty of this whole debate.

The truth is that the Labor Party is far from agreement on this piece of legislation. It is an issue that is causing deep concern in the rank and file of the Labor Party, the Party's branches, the Party machine and, most particularly, the State parliamentary Party of New South Wales. The Premier of New South Wales has the deepest concern. He not only faces an election in the next six months, and he has made that quite clear to his New South Wales colleagues, but also faces the prospect of losing it as a result of this and many other issues. This issue is a very disturbing factor for him. He is pulling in every favour that he has ever done for members of the New South Wales right wing in this chamber. The phones are running hot and he is very worried about his prospects. I would not be surprised if, within the next couple of days, or very soon, we heard an announcement from that Premier. We can expect a sudden announcement of an election while this piece of legislation is being considered by a committee. No doubt the Premier hopes that this issue will die down and be lost. I can assure the Premier, Senator Ray, Senator Richardson and anyone else who cares to listen that it will not die down, because I will still be campaigning very strongly against this card right around the great State of Victoria. I will even go up to New South Wales if I am invited.

The Opposition's stance on this legislation goes further than that typical opportunism-and we have come to expect this from the New South Wales right wing-which is being displayed by the Premier, Mr Unsworth, in his opposition. It is a genuine opposition based on the integrity of privacy, an opposition which is displayed by the thousands of people who are sending in petitions, and which is shown by all the grassroots groups that are now springing up in opposition to this ID card.

I can only hope, for this nation's sake, that the words of my colleague Senator Boswell come to pass. The honourable senator said the other day that, because of the great and forceful opposition to the card, we are going to witness the greatest retreat since Napoleon fled Moscow. They are very honest words. And leading that retreat, he said, would be Senator Ray. Of course Senator Richardson would be giving him a piggyback. That is what we are going to witness as a result of this Moscow card. This will come to pass-in fact, the retreat is on now. The ID card is a gross and unnecessary invasion of the privacy of the Australian people, and that is something we will never tolerate in this country.

The mere language of the Australia Card Bill sends shivers up my spine-and that of anyone else who has been able to get hold of the legislation. It is the language of the high and low in society. It describes the administrative body of the ID card in terms of `the Authority'. When describing the card users, everyday Australian citizens, it uses the word `subject'. In short, the subject is beholden to the Authority and it is a very sad day when such language is used to describe Australians. It is even sadder when it is used in a time when we are preparing to celebrate our bicentennial year-a year to reaffirm our traditions and beliefs for which we fought so hard. Freedom and privacy have always been at the front of those beliefs. While accepting that there will always be a price and a balance for privacy in a democratic society, this piece of legislation goes beyond the balance. It is an extreme intrusion into our privacy. The only people who really fear this legislation are the bulk of honest Australians to whom the card has the least relevance. The directors of organised crime in this country are completely unconcerned about the Australia Card Bill. The drug runners and the bag men will welcome the Australia Card as a universal method by which they can conceal more easily their seedy ways. In addition, the Australia Card could, as Inspector Merv Beck has said, pave the way for corporate crime `on a massive scale'. It will add to crime.

It is very opportune now for me to turn to the report of the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card to quote several other authorities in crime-namely, the submission by the Australian Federal Police (AFP) Chief Inspector Brown. He only adds weight to Merv Beck's comments. The report says:

The AFP adds, however, that there are no realistic grounds for anticipating any impact on the level of organised crime generally . . . Organised crime, particularly in the drug trafficking area, would be quick to identify the possible methods of avoiding the inconvenience caused.
I, like everyone else in the Opposition, would like to quote Mr Frank Costigan, who deserves to be quoted time and again. He said:

It might have inhibited at a very low level some of the practices which I came across in the early part of the Commission. I do not believe it would have inhibited the more important matters that I was looking at in the last couple of years.

In essence, the Australia Card Bill before us now will serve to tighten the thumbscrews on the vast majority of law abiding Australians-taxpaying Australians-and give greater liberties to the crime network. This debate has really now reached the absurd. The Government cannot guarantee, even at a technical level, the security of the system it seeks to impose upon Australians. Yet there is even a greater concern relevant to this debate than the question of technical security which has been properly outlined by my colleagues. The concern relates to the rightful powers of the state in regard to its citizens. It is only in truly extraordinary circumstances that we ought to hand governments added authority in matters of this type. This legislation is not worthy of handing over such powers. It just does not match up.

I would like to consider the history of the secrecy provision of section 16 of the Income Tax Assessment Act. This provision has been amended so often since 1936 that seemingly every man and his dog have access to personal financial information once thought to be securely held within the vaults of the Australian Taxation Office. My concern here is not so much the erosion of section 16 itself but the importance of the parallel. Who in 1936 would even have believed that personal financial dealings would be available to a long list of characters who now have access to this information under section 16. It just highlights that the future is unpredictable. For that reason the creation of a national identification system with a central database is testing the faith of all Australians in this Government. More importantly, it is testing the faith of Australians in the bureaucracy and its willingness to restrain its ambition, particularly in relation to many of the appointments that this Government has made in the bureaucracy. If we heed the ambitions of the head of the Department of Veterans' Affairs, the veterans will soon have their privacy invaded and their rightful entitlements, as a result of service to their country, scrutinised and questioned. This comes on the eve of the Vietnam veterans' march to be held in Sydney next weekend. I really hope that no member of the Labor Government has the discourtesy to show his or her face at that march.

TALK.START.PARA: —We didn't send the troops to Vietnam.

—Well, do not go to that march. The Government's central justification for the Australia Card legislation resides in its mistaken belief that the Bill will bring about social justice. If this Government really wants to bring about justice within its social welfare system, if it really believes that, it ought to start by cutting taxes. It ought to start creating new opportunities for growth and enterprise in the small business sector. If this Government wants social justice it ought to be concerned about creating new job opportunities.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australia Card is an admission of broad failure of the Government's broader economic strategy. That is why, for example, on page 58 of Budget Statement No. 2 we find that without even a glimmer of shame from this Government, it states blandly that Australians must once again anticipate an unemployment rate of 8.3 per cent in the coming year. In addition, people also look to this Parliament to set an example, to stand clearly and resolutely for democratic values-values this institution was created to give voice to and above all to protect. Therefore, some of those people who are most concerned with this legislation are those who themselves or whose parents came to this country in the immediate post-war years and whose willingness to work hard within a free and tolerant society helped to produce the standard of living which we now take as commonplace. It is these people who fear the introduction of an Australia Card most. For them it holds bitter memories of a past which they or their parents would wish to forget; a past which was either spent during the war years in Europe or more potently in the post-war Eastern bloc countries. These are the states that have continually called upon their citizens to account, to make them servants of the government. Those people in this country who know exactly what I am talking about reject the Australia Card as some sort of reminiscence of the past and fear of some political program of the future. I classify the selective leakings of Dr McGoldrick's case which has been stated many times in this chamber, the leaking of confidential information on particular individuals or groups as the first sign of the potential of the Australia Card to be misused.

In conclusion, I ask the Government when it will come to understand that this nation is either a defender of the principles of democracy and privacy or it is not. On matters of this kind whatever this Government thinks, it cannot have it both ways. I reject the Australia Card legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is an English proverb which says that the way to hell is paved with good intentions. There is a lot of truth in that proverb when it comes to the Australia Card and our consideration of it. I wish to dwell on six major points in debate on the Australia Card Bill. First, I refer to the obvious problems with regard to the card itself; secondly, the direction of government in Australia since the last election; thirdly, the confusion in debate on the ID card between means and ends. Why has the Government chosen to solve the problem via this ID card program when departmental action would suffice? Fourthly, it is obviously aimed at small time crooks and the general populace, because surely determined criminals within the community will circumvent this card. What effect will the card have on organised crime? Fifthly, I refer to the Government's contempt for the process of Parliament. What is to stop the Government from steamrolling further provisions of the Bill through the Parliament? Finally, I shall address a number of issues which relate to people living in remote parts of Australia, such as those in my electorate in the Northern Territory.

SPEECH.PARA: The obvious problems are as follows: First, the Australia Card will not stop welfare fraud. Secondly, it will not stop taxation fraud. Thirdly, it will not deter organised crime. Fourthly, it will not stop illegal immigration. Fifthly, it will not be a 100 per cent secure system. Sixthly, the Government will not obtain an extra $4.7 billion. Seventhly, the Government does not have a mandate for the card. It is interesting to look at the direction of this Government, this Hawkespeak Labor Government, and at the differences between traditional Labor governments throughout history, the trends and where they are going. There is a certain centralisation of power and this Government certainly takes a lot on itself.

The genesis one needs to have in mind when examining the Hawke Government is always to remind ourselves of the Boyer Lectures by Bob Hawke, whose publication is ironically entitled `The Resolution of Conflict'. If we go to the section in the publication entitled `How We are Governed', we see the following statement:

. . . Australians would be better served by the elimination of the second tier of government-that is the States-which no longer serve their original purpose and act as a positive impediment to achieving good government in our current community. This would give us, like the great majority of other countries, one Parliament with powers available to the government to match the responsibilities upon it of protecting and advancing the interests of Australian citizens.

That was part of the lecture by R. J. Hawke. What has been happening with the real reduction in State powers that we have seen through the cuts in real expenditure in that area? Are we heading for an Eastern European or Yugoslavian type of community?

The Government has been looking at the reduction of fraud at both ends of the income ladder-the welfare fraud in the area of the have-nots, the tax fraud in the area of the haves. It has been looking at a crackdown on illegal groups in the community, illegal immigration, and organised crime. But the ID card-the Australia Card-is not the answer. There are other more conventional, proper places to look at those issues in both State governments and the Federal Government. If we address the means and the ends, why use a blanket solution to solve these problems? Why not solve specific problems with precise measures? The card will not solve any of its target problems in the areas of tax, social security or immigration. In effect, this card will cause many new problems. The paper cost to industry is estimated to be around $2 billion. What about the plastic cost to individuals, the administrative fines of $20,000 and more to industry and other groups; the fine of $500 for the non-reporting of loss; the encroachment into the privacy of individuals and business? These newer problems are causing widespread community discussion and debate. I am aware that to date the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly has put up this subject as a matter of public importance and an interesting debate is going on there.

I am aware of comments made on this topic by the Deputy Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, Ray Hanrahan, particularly those in a recent speech. He discussed the costs attributable to the card and the fact that in 1985 the Labor Government changed its mind and estimated the cost at some $827m. Let me quote from Mr Hanrahan's speech:
. . . the real total cost will be much higher. The Government does not include the costs to Territory, State and local governments of putting I.D. numbers on the payrolls.
Nor does it take account of the private sector compliance costs.

The Confederation of Australian Industry claims private sector compliance costs of $540 million. The Australian Bankers' Association says that compliance costs for the banks alone will be $60 million-so you can expect some increased bank charges.
And every small business can expect costs in the order of $2,000, according to the Small Business Association.

The Government estimates totally exclude the costs to business of updating staff records and computer software to include the I.D. numbers, and of meeting the demand for data on financial transactions, rents collected, sales of luxury items, real estate, dealings in precious metals, deposits in trust funds, bank accounts, cash management funds, overnight deposits, share transactions, future exchange transactions and all the other activities of the market.
The Australian National University Department of Information Systems believes those costs will be in the order of $653m.
The consensus among independent observers is that the total public and private sector cost will be $2 billion.

The extra cards, beyond one's personal card, will also be a complicating factor. What about women who run businesses under their maiden names? What about the involvement of sporting clubs with their own small bank accounts? What about business areas, and the effects on visitors who wish to stay in Australia for more than six weeks and who wish to be financially active, or who perhaps have the misfortune to be sick?

The aim of the card may stop some petty small time fraud by amateurs; it may stop illegal immigrants from working off the books; but the card will not even dent organised crime. Mr Merv Beck, the senior New South Wales policeman renowned for closing Sydney's illegal casinos, has said that the Australia Card could pave the way for corporate crime `on a massive scale'. This card is really aimed at increasing government power over and controlling middle income, pay as you earn Australians. The report of the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card contains an addendum by my colleague, Senator Puplick, in which he draws attention to the surreptitious social engineering contained in the proposal. I quote from Senator Puplick's report:

The term `social engineering' I have borrowed from the writings of the British philosopher Sir Karl Popper. He uses it to describe any system which seeks to make wholesale changes in our social institutions and relationships enacted by governments in order to achieve some alleged greater good or benefit. He characterises it as an approach based on always appealing `to our emotions rather than to reason', surely a correct description of the propaganda for the Australia Card. He concludes however that-
and here he again quotes Popper-
even with the best of intentions of making heaven on earth it only succeeds in making it a hell-that hell which man alone prepares for his fellow-men.

It has also been mentioned that the Australia Card would be an imposition on to the Australian public of the socialist ideal. The proposal gives the State supremacy over the individual and the ability to monitor individual behaviour. Does anyone really believe that the ID card will in any way stop corporate tax fraud or really control the black economy?

Let me deal with the areas of contempt. There is contempt for the recommendations of the Committee, which were rejected and are not in the present Bill. There has been contempt for the public by the Government claiming that it has a mandate. There has been contempt for parliamentary debate. We are all aware of the number of quorums that have been called in this chamber over the last few days because the Australian Labor Party has had hardly anyone present. In fact there are only four members of the Labor Party in the chamber now. The numbers of honourable senators who have participated in the debate are rather remarkable. Out of 34 Opposition senators, 26 will be participating in the debate on this Bill. All of the members of the National Party of Australia have participated. To the credit of the Australian Democrats, all their six members have participated. Two of the three independents have participated, and Senator Wood has given his support and is still waiting to make his maiden speech, and he will be supporting this side of the chamber. Eight members on the Government side have participated in the debate, and Senator Ray has the audacity to say that the thrill has gone out of it. If we take out Senator Ray and Senator Ryan, who have ministerial responsibility, and take out the three new senators who, to their credit, are being blooded in debate-we can certainly give them credit-how many does that leave? Only three members of the Labor Party have made a decent contribution to this debate, compared with 34 members on the other side of the chamber. What a bloody disgrace!

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I am not unused to abuse and so on, but I dislike the use of certain language in the chamber. It might be fashionable and trendy but I do not like it and it is highly disorderly. I would like the honourable senator to withdraw it.
—Order! There is nothing for the honourable senator to withdraw. It was an inappropriate remark but it was not out of order.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy President. Where are the members of the Left in the Labor Party who should be taking part in this debate? We have not heard from Senators Bolkus, Burns, Childs, Coates, Devereux, Gietzelt, Giles, McKiernan, Reynolds and Zakharov. Senator Zakharov may be away, but the rest of them have not participated in the debate. They have not given us any idea of how they feel. They must all be part of that group of 31 in the Labor Caucus who are running away from this issue. Talk about contempt of Parliament! What about contempt for the future? Justice Michael Kirby, one of our eminent jurists, said:

SPEECH.PARA: If there is an identity card, people in authority will want to put it to use . . .
What has Senator Susan Ryan said? On the AM program on 17 September she said:
Anyone who's familiar with legislation would know that legislation that's 130 pages long is always going to be susceptible to a minor improvement here or in the future.
Can we trust the honourable senator? The Government, with the best of intentions, will cause Australia to become a police state, and we will all have to rely totally on our 10-digit ID card.

What about the people living in the remote parts of Australia? The introduction of this card will be an administrative nightmare. Imagine the costs incurred by those people and the inconvenience caused to them. Those living in the remote areas, far from big cities, will have to travel far to have their photographs taken, to fill in their forms and to produce forms of identity in order to get their card. Many Aboriginal communities in the Northern Territory have already been put on to the Medicare system and received their Medicare cards. But why do they need an ID card as well? What purpose will the card serve? Are there going to be social security problems, tax problems or immigration problems in Arnhem Land or in central Australia? There will be no need for those people to rely on it. They already have their piece of plastic to cover certain requirements. I believe that those people will be seriously disadvantaged by the introduction of this legislation. I conclude by quoting the following verse from a ballad by the Australian poet, Les Murray, which I think carries a timely warning:
Hey True Blue, they are slipping it to you,
They'll do it in the end in all positions.
They are sliding in a card, while you are off your guard,
Between you and your traditions.

Australia, and particularly the Northern Territory, takes pride in its freedom, its easy going nature and its tolerance to live and let live style. What sort of future can we hope for with an Australia Card?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to refer yet again to the 1986 Australian Labor Party conference, which has been in the spotlight somewhat this week. But this time I would like to quote the Hon. Neal Blewett. The following is an oft used quotation, but I think it is important that it be stated and restated:

SPEECH.PARA: Let me say as a Socialist that it is the interests of the community that should come before the individual right. We shouldn't get too hung up as Socialists on privacy because privacy in many ways is a bourgeois right that is very much associated with the right to private property.
That is indeed the essence of this debate. Those who are opposed to the identity card are committed to the individual, to the rights and freedoms of the individual. Those who support it are not.

I would like to deal with the history of the Liberal Party's opposition to the entire concept of an identity card, and of this identity card in particular. There has been much criticism that this issue was not raised to saturation point during the election campaign and that somehow the Opposition has a new found opposition to this concept. In truth, our opposition goes back in the party structure prior to 1986 to the State Council debates, to State convention debates and to the Federal Council debate. I remember very well the impassioned speech when Sir William Knox, from Queensland, reminded people at that convention that the most popular act of repeal following World War II had been the repeal of the existing identity card which had been a wartime measure.

I come to the question of why the issue did not gain the saturation coverage that it is now gaining in the post-election period. First of all, the concept of this identity card is a very difficult one. Most people are not familiar with how computers work and how databanks are put together and the sort of intrusion that is possible into their lives. When they were told a simple shibboleth that the card would somehow stop tax avoidance, tax evasion and sponging on the social welfare system, that seemed an attractive proposition. It is only since there has been an in-depth debate that people have begun to realise the sort of intrusion that the card really does represent. In the heat of the election campaign, which was as short as we have now come to expect them to be, there were certainly no photo opportunities to explain in depth about the card. It is not a suitable subject for a 30-second grab, which is so typical of the campaigning style that we have these days. There was certainly not the saturation coverage in the print media that we are now getting. Although my cynicism may show just a little, perhaps some people who thought that the ID card must be prevented from being introduced also thought that they wanted the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) returned to office. So whereas some people are prepared to fight very hard to defeat the identity card in the post-election period, perhaps they were much happier to have it buried in other issues in the election campaign period itself.

As I said a little earlier, the identity card involves a complicated concept. Most Australians' acquaintanceship with the idea of a computer is just that-an acquaintanceship. Even for myself, and others, it is a learning process from the information age, which many of us still have to come to terms with totally. But I understand very well, as do most Australians, the Orwellian concept of Nineteen Eighty-Four.

One of the things of particular concern in the legislation is the fact that there is absolutely no right to a card; one has no right to be a citizen. At this stage, if one is born in this country or becomes a citizen by lawful means, one has the right to operate within our society. This card puts a barrier between that right and the ability to operate within our own society. In fact, if one is not granted an identity card, the only place one can possibly survive is in the cash economy.

To digress for just one moment, if we are serious about attacking those who operate in the cash economy or underground economy, let us examine a different proposition. If we made all and any wages payable a tax deduction against any source of income in the hands of the wage-payer, we would transfer many people who operate in that cash economy into the pay as you earn (PAYE) economy. This is for the very simple reason that we would be giving the wage-payer an incentive to make remittances of PAYE tax because they would be getting the deduction. It would open up new jobs, particularly in the domestic area, and indeed it would make the collection of the revenue more certain. It is certainly a matter that should be examined.

I would now like to turn to the Bill itself, because there are many proposed sections that I find of considerable concern, particularly because of the discretionary powers which are conferred by the Bill. Firstly, proposed section 10 deals with eligibility to apply. This is a non-discretionary power. The clause concisely sets out who is entitled to apply. But moving on we see that proposed section 11 says that the application is to be a prescribed form. This form has yet to be determined and therefore the information sought is subject to a discretion. Proposed section 12 deals with the question of whether a photograph is to be compulsory on the card. It says that, should there be an unreasonable amount of distress to the person or a member of the person's family, a card may be issued without the photograph on it. But that is a totally discretionary power that lies with the Authority which it may or may not choose to exercise and which is subject to an application for a reconsideration and finally for a determination by the Agency. But at no stage are there guidelines for how that discretion is to be exercised. It is freely to be exercised.

Proposed section 25 sets out what is to go on to the Register and it is very wide. That is prescribed in schedule 1, which is at the back of the Bill. It sets out many sources of information that may go on to that Register. Proposed section 13 gives further discretionary power to the Authority. It says that the Authority may require such information or documents which are reasonably required to verify the identity of the applicant, to verify the statements in the application for the card, and to enable the Authority to decide whether one is eligible for a card. So again the Authority has wide-ranging powers to seek additional information and to exercise discretionary power to determine whether or not an applicant will be granted a card.

Proposed section 14 gives further wide-ranging powers to require more information. Eight Acts administered by various departments are listed and the Authority has the power to require any information from any of those departments concerning any of those Acts which are so listed. It also has the power to seek information from the Australian Electoral Commission. Proposed section 15 deals with the actual issue of the card. It says that only when the Authority decides that four set out criteria have been satisfied will a card be issued. In other words, there is absolutely no right for a citizen of Australia to gain a card and therefore be able to operate within our own society.

Senator Puplick, in his opening remarks in this debate, drew well the imagery of the tragedy of our bicentennial year being set for the renumbering of the Australian people. I would like to address some random points which I think are fairly important. There is the Government's tactic of trying to set up straw groups of Australians to attack, and to promote the politics of greed and envy. This is pretty hypocritical coming from a government which has well known members of its own ranks who rort various systems themselves. But more worrying still is the specious argument which says, `I have nothing to hide; therefore I have nothing to fear'. Once the card is in place many things can flow from it. The access to information could be increased to include more and more departments and therefore more personnel within government departments. More and more computers can be networked and can talk to each other. Legislation can even be introduced for the confiscation of the card. In a rational debate in a rational period, one would think that those sorts of things could not happen in Australia. But I suggest to honourable senators that there were people in Europe in the 1930s who also believed that their freedom could not be threatened as it was by the rise of Hitler's Germany.

The question of the safety, security and foolproof nature of the system itself has also been attacked by many other speakers. It was interesting to read in the Australian of yesterday's date a report titled `Hackers breach NASA network'. This is also something we have been made vaguely aware of, but I thought the report was worth quoting. It said:

A group of West German computer hackers calling themselves the Chaos Computer Club succeeded in breaching NASA's restricted international computer network for at least three months before being discovered . . .
NASA's space . . . network . . . links 1000 computers in nine countries and provides about 4000 authorised scientists and engineers with information about . . . projects . . .
The group discovered a general access code which allowed them to penetrate the whole system, including the electronic mail boxes of users and sensitive data . . .
They said they were then able to make themselves invisible or present themselves as authorised users.
Further, to give them easy access, they introduced what they called `Trojan horses' into 135 of the 1,000 computers. The article said further:
The term Trojan horse is usually applied in computer circles to a program, often found on bulletin boards, which when loaded innocently by a user can destroy all data in loaded disks . . .
But it also means a program which can operate independently and can siphon information input by other programs.

To most ordinary Australians that sort of description is pretty much gobbledegook. But the long and the short of it is that the world's most sophisticated network program can be and has been breached and information can and has been used.

Another point that has been addressed in debate which I think is important is the mandate question, which Senator Robert Ray addressed a little earlier. In this chamber, where the majority of senators do not support the identity card, and coming as I do from New South Wales where seven of the 12 elected senators oppose it, I find it insulting to the 17 new senators who have come into this chamber but who have not previously been able to debate the matter here, to be told that this matter has already been debated once and really does not require recanvassing. True, many of us debated the issue during the election period; I personally did. But as I went through the difficulty of not getting saturation coverage for the issue, many of the contributions in that early stage would have been found in isolated reports or on radio programs which, while a large number of people would have heard them, would not have promulgated the message through to the masses.

Yesterday Senator Beahan said that he would like to abolish emotion from the debate. I am sorry but he cannot do that because individual freedom is a passionate and an emotional issue. Many of my constituents, the voters of New South Wales, are themselves passionate about the issue. In the pre-election period I had a phone call from a gentleman who was of European origin. He said that he had treasured memories of his wife. She had had an identity card and she had died in a concentration camp in Germany. He was very passionate and emotional about the identity card. On the Government's side, former Senator Jim McClelland said:
Even if the ID card would ensure that everyone that dodged tax would be caught in the net, I still don't think it is worth the price of making every citizen wear a dog collar.

That too is passionate language. I also find the analogy that is being drawn between the identity card and ordinary single purpose cards quite offensive. Every card that I carry, that I might choose to use-I have because I chose to apply for it. I could get by quite satisfactorily in my society without it. The identity card is a card which is being foisted upon us all. We do not have an option despite the language being used by the Government that we are being invited to apply. It is an invitation to treat. Very simply, it is said that we cannot get by without it. Therefore, the analogy is most misleading.

The cost to the private sector of this compulsory card is something that is yet to be calculated. We have heard much discussion from the Government about claims that individuals are rorting the system and costing the revenue money. I think it is probably more accurate to say that the imposition of this card will rort the private sector and collect money from useful investment to be used only for bureaucratic purposes and not to contribute to the overall economy. This leads me, finally, to the question of why the card is wanted. What is the hidden agenda? What is the underlying motive? There are no two ways about it: information is power. The ability to gather information, to target its use, is something that we are all learning to use in the latter part of the twentieth century.

It was interesting that during the election period the Australian Labor Party was said to have had a clever marginal seat strategy. Much of that strategy was to do with finding out information about various electors and targeting those electors, once their prejudices, their likes or dislikes had been identified, to persuade them which way their vote ought to be cast on the basis of a single issue. We spend millions of dollars in this country to teach people how to gather information and how to use it effectively so that we may promote our own causes. The capacity to link stored information and devise new purposes to which that information can be put by government has been best illustrated by the Swedish model where the power of the state has become so terrifying that the man charged with its administration has resigned in protest.

Information is power. I have been brought up in a free Australia. I consider it my obligation to preserve the rights of freedom that can be handed on to my children and my children's children. Freedom is precious. If I have a mandate it is to fight to see that freedom survives.
(Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Late last year, on the last occasion the Australia Card Bill 1986 came before the Parliament, I spoke in the second reading debate against the provisions of the Bill but I supported the Bill into its second reading stage. I indicated that the Bill required substantial amendments to meet the concerns which were being legitimately expressed by various sections of the community at that time. I suppose that in hindsight if everyone had done what I did, had the matter reached the committee stage and had discussion on the possible amendments taken place for a period of about three weeks, we would not have had the double dissolution. In fact, the Government could not have obtained the trigger for the double dissolution had the matter still been before the Parliament, as at 30 June 1987. Therefore, we would not be faced, as we are now, ultimately with the Government using its numbers in a joint sitting of Parliament under section 57 of the Constitution to ram this measure through the Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: Today I wish to place before the Parliament the views I have, philosophically, about the Australia Card Bill 1986 [No. 3]. It is my view that the Australia Card Bill ought to be opposed because it is like the Bill of Rights proposal. Ostensibly, it is designed to promote justice in our society. In reality, however, its potential for injustice is far more grave than the evils it is designed to deal with. It must be acknowledged at the outset that tax and social security fraud are serious problems. But an Australia Card is no way to deal with those problems. This is because the Australia Card has great potential to be an agent of state control over citizens.

Although the Government has claimed that the ID card will be used for certain precise and limited purposes, there is no reason to suppose that future governments will not legislate to create further circumstances in which the identification card must be used. Coming from the trade union movement as I do, I see a great danger in the identification card becoming a work permit by which the state can control who shall have work and who shall not. That power is totalitarianism.

In the best possible world, the Australia Card might be an unexceptionable proposal. But, of course, in Australia we do not live in the best possible world. In fact we live in a society in which the levers of government and bureaucracy are controlled increasingly by non-elected cliques who have no compunction about using the power of the state to reshape society after their own image and likeness; in other words to engage in their piece of social engineering. This itch to use power to manipulate public culture and private life has been demonstrated in recent times by certain actions of the Human Rights Commission in seeking to deny the fundamental human right to life to what it terms `defective newborns', by the passage of certain provisions of the sex discrimination legislation denying to individuals the basic right of freedom of conscience and by the attempt to foist on the country a deeply flawed Bill of Rights.

These moves have not been undertaken to cultivate human rights considered in the round. On the contrary, a machinery has been established to promote in an arbitrary manner a partial and at times eccentric selection of human rights. This kind of rearrangement of the order of human rights to suit prevailing ideologies or passing intellectual fads is always a threat to human rights.

To take the example of the sex discrimination provisions which refuse to recognise the rights of human conscience, in the last Parliament I put on notice my intention to move in the Senate an amendment to the Sex Discrimination Act drafted to correct this enormous injustice. However, the Government voted against my move to have the opportunity to discuss that amendment. Therefore, what the Government has done in those provisions of the sex discrimination legislation is to require Australians, under legal obligation, under pain of penalty, conscientious objection notwithstanding, to regard an unmarried state, a cohabiting state, as though it were a married state.

Let me take another example. I mentioned the Human Rights Commission. It showed its true colours when it published its discussion paper on the care of what it called `newborns;' in other words infant human beings. Behind that document was the eugenics principle that if human beings are born with serious health problems they can be culled from the human family by means of medical neglect. This is very relevant to this debate because many of the social engineers, many members of the non-elected clique, are to be found within the health portfolio. It is not without significance that the people who will administer the Australia Card, the identification card, belong to that non-elected clique in the health establishment.

Only recently we heard about the drug Depo-Provera being given to Aboriginal girls. Let me remind the Senate of my credentials in health matters. As far back as 1979 I raised in this Parliament in a question to the then Minister representing the Minister for Health the dangers of the drug Depo-Provera. The then Minister simply quoted back to me what the Department of Health establishment was telling her-that there was nothing to worry about. Had the Department of Health and the government at the time taken note of what I said, we would not have a problem with Depo-Provera at this time.

I am perfectly aware that amongst the health professionals is concern at the increasing and unexpected strains on health budgets. That has led some health administrators to argue that one way of cutting costs would be to enable or require persons with congenital disorders to go through an in-vitro fertilisation program and submit their human embryonic offspring to a filtering system if that can be devised. And it is being devised. A substantial number of DNA probes are now being developed in Melbourne to detect genetic abnormalities in the early human embryo. A fact that is not well known is that consideration is being given at this point by a committee appointed by the National Health and Medical Research Council to the establishment of registers of persons with genetic disorders. Why would that consideration be taking place? Certainly, one can think of some advantages. But the disadvantages would very greatly outweigh the advantages. At least two of those on the committee are on record as saying that genetic probes can be used as a search and destroy operation, that is, to search for genetic disorders and then not to cure the disease but to eliminate the bearer.

If such information were included in a person's Australia Card file, identification card file, how far down the track would we go? Let us assume that this material was available to the Department of Social Security. I am not saying that this Government would do such a thing, but it would need just a flick of a finger for a future government to say to a person whose family has a history of genetic disorders, of which there are some 4,000, `If you do not go through a program so that we can have a test done on your offspring, you are on your own. You will not be paid family allowance. You will not be paid a handicapped child allowance'.

The last time a register of genetic disorders was established was during the Third Reich in 1934. There is a very interesting book of about 400 pages by Robert Jay Lifton, published by Basic Books Inc in New York, entitled The Nazi Doctors: Medical Killing and the Psychology of Genocide. It details what occurred in 1934. A register-it was called a card index-was established of genetic taints. The persons who were found to have genetic taints were taken from the register and sent notification to go to court. As a result, hundreds of thousands of people were sterilised by the Third Reich. The courts which heard those applications were secret by orders of the state allegedly to protect the identity of those who were to undergo the sterilisation operation.

I would be very concerned if this vehicle, this identification card, were able to be used for that sort of purpose. I am not suggesting that it would be used for that purpose by this Government. It certainly would not be in the mind of anyone I know in this Government. However, let the Government not be surprised that it is in the minds of persons behind the push for the identification card, particularly the non-elected clique-I am glad to see that the Special Minister of State (Senator Ryan) is in the chamber. The non-elected health establishment clique is now ignoring the report of the Senate Select Committee on the Human Embryo Experimentation Bill 1985 and is attempting to stop its recommendations coming before Parliament. It wants to have a national body to be established to determine the ethics of the human embryo experimentation question and other questions, including euthanasia and the like. This non-elected clique is not answerable to this Parliament. It does not stand up for fundamental rights.

Unless this issue is determined on the fundamental premise that we are dealing with human subjects and that human life is involved, the pressure to extend the limits will become irresistible. Families, whether or not they have genetic disorders, now have some privacy. When the Australia Card is introduced there will be no escape.
