The Australia Card Bill raises the point: if the Government is not capable of respecting the consciences of the Australian people, as it was not capable of doing when I proposed my amendment to the sex discrimination legislation-honourable senators should bear in mind that I supported aspects of it-how can we be so naive as to imagine that it will respect the privacy of Australians, something far less valuable than their consciences? A bureaucracy which has no respect for consciences cannot be trusted to respect privacy. The Bill of Rights gave to tribunals and the bureaucracy star chamber powers and to judges a legislative power in regard to human rights, which properly is the responsibility of the Parliament. It is not surprising that bureaucrats who contrived the Human Rights Commission and sex discrimination legislation-aspects of which I talked about-and the Bill of Rights have come up with the Australia Card. It is another attempt at addressing real problems by creating dangers more threatening to society. The ID card has too much potential for social engineering and social control to put this instrument into the hands of a bureaucracy already committed to schemes of social engineering.

As I study the Australia Card Bill the dangers it contains clearly unfold. We find that without the card the conduct of routine essential business of ordinary life will be impossible. No important money transaction can be made without the ID card. More importantly, employers face a $20,000 fine if they do not require their employees to present their cards. Here we touch on the central problem of the Australia Card. To be at all relevant in the fight against tax evasion an instrument such as an identity card must play a necessary part in the relations between employee and employer. Yet this very necessity is what makes the ID card such a danger. To serve any useful purpose in regard to tax evasion the Australia Card must become a work permit. With a $20,000 fine hanging over an employer's head for not demanding presentation of the card, an employer is likely to refuse to employ persons who do not have or who refuse to use an Australia Card.

Those who refuse to register for the Australia Card will be effectively unemployable, except in the cash or black market economy, one of the chief areas of tax evasion and one which, by its very nature, the ID card cannot touch. Once contracting parties decide to opt out of the white economy and into the black economy the ID card becomes irrelevant. Indeed, precisely because the ID card is incapable of identifying transactions in the black economy, it will, if anything, encourage its growth. This is exactly what has happened in communist and authoritarian countries. Under these regimes people turn to the black economy, not just because it happens to be more efficient than the official economy, but also because in the obscurity of the black economy an underground culture forms in which many people seek to escape from the prying eyes of the state. In reality these people are refugees from the official society.

This rejection of official society by the underground society is a response to the falsehood at the heart of the official order. The state claims that it is a democracy but the people have no say in its running. The state claims to be a people's state when in fact it is a bureaucrat state. The state proclaims freedom of conscience and then imprisons those who exercise it. With the ID card Australia faces the prospect of building a lie of a similar kind, although of a less serious kind, into the fabric of our national life. What is the nature of this lie? The bureaucrats are attempting to create the impression that application for the Australia Card is voluntary. The Australian people are to be `invited' to take up the Australia Card. But the invitation to take up the Australia Card cannot be declined. Application for the card cannot be voluntary because failure to volunteer carries with it a penalty-the penalty of banishment from the sphere of everyday life. Furthermore, a non-registering citizen risks a $20,000 fine for being unable to present his card upon demand of the Commissioner of Taxation pursuant to his legal responsibilities.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: NEW PARLIAMENT HOUSE SITE: SEVERANCE PAY

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. I refer the Minister to Senator Walsh's description of the new Parliament House as `another scandal'. Does the Minister agree that it is scandalous for the Building Workers Industrial Union to demand the flow-on to the Parliament House construction site of the $20 a week severance pay agreement reached with some employers? —Fancy having the effrontery to ask that when you supported the doctors union in the ACT.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Home Affairs. Did the Minister see a letter in the Canberra Times yesterday from a person who claimed to have voted six times in the election on 11 July? Is the Australian Electoral Commission aware of this and what action, if any, has been taken to investigate these claims?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday the Canberra Times published a letter from Mr Haantjens of Broulee, New South Wales. In that letter, which, by the way, was received by the Canberra Times on 9 September, Mr Haantjens claimed to have voted at the Federal election five times in his own name and once in someone else's. Mr Haantjens's letter to the editor did not mention that on 2 September the Divisional Returning Officer for Eden-Monaro wrote to him, asking why he had appeared to vote more than once. Mr Haantjens replied to the Divisional Returning Officer on 7 September-that is, before the letter to the editor was received. In his reply Mr Haantjens stated that he had voted at Moruya, Mossy Point, Batehaven, Batemans Bay, Mogo and Bodalla-areas with which I am not totally au fait-and that he had taken this action to demonstrate the lack of safeguards against multiple voting. It is not impossible that Mr Haantjens's decision to write a letter to the editor almost two months after election day was connected to the inquiries made by the Electoral Commission.

ANSWER.PARA: Whilst it is possible to vote more than once on election day, I point out that such action is easily detected through the roll mark-back conducted by the Electoral Commission after the election. Under section 339 (1) (j) of the Commonwealth Electoral Act, multiple voting carries a maximum penalty of $1,000 or six months imprisonment or both. The Sydney office of the Electoral Commission has already referred Mr Haantjens's case to the Director of Public Prosecutions for examination.

I might add that from time to time allegations are made as to multiple voting, but all investigations, at least going back for the last 20 years, have shown that it is not a practice indulged in by the citizens of this country. It would certainly never be a practice that any major party would encourage, because if the electoral margin were narrow a court of disputed returns quite clearly would throw out any such election on those grounds. I just remind the Senate that these days the Electoral Commission itself can put a matter before the Court of Disputed Returns, irrespective of party viewpoints. The only alternative, if this practice became common, would be for the Government to provide individual computer terminals at every booth to make sure that people were not voting more than once. Multiple voting is not a practice that any major political party would want to encourage; it is one that the full force of the law will be used to stamp out.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Transport and Communications aware that, within a few weeks, not several months, of the coastal surveillance contract being awarded to Amann Aviation Pty Ltd, Amann requested certain significant changes to that contract? Is he also aware that the most significant change requested was an alternative to the type of aircraft that was to be used? Is he further aware that an aircraft change would have justified cancelling the contract? Given the serious concerns then expressed by the Department of Aviation about Amann's ability to meet the terms of the contract, which were well known to the Minister and documented in the papers he put down the other day, why did the Minister not cancel the contract forthwith?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no difficulty at all about answering this question. The tender specification did not identify particular makes or models of aircraft. It simply required the contractor to provide suitable multi-engined aircraft which met certain equipment and performance criteria. These criteria included, for example, a capability to perform on task for a minimum of five hours flying at a level of 500 feet and a speed within the range of 140 to 160 knots and still have sufficient in-flight fuel reserves for emergency situations.

ANSWER.PARA: The original tender by Amann was in terms of 14 Aerocommander 680F and FL aircraft which are piston-engined. It is perfectly true that a little further down the track Amann notified the Government that it was its intention to change from those aircraft to turbo-prop aircraft for reasons that were spelt out. So, there is no contractual question that arose. Whether that was a sensible economic or managerial decision for Amann Aviation to take is something that is, I suppose, debatable. Certainly, the question is by no means as open and shut as some self-titled experts on the subject who have been waxing lyrical in the nation's Press over the last few weeks would have one believe.

It is a matter of trading off, as I said in this place a little while ago, the advantages of low maintenance associated, as I understand it, with turbo-prop aircraft against the higher fuel consumption that is involved in using those aircraft as distinct from piston-driven ones. That is essentially a matter of the economic and managerial judgment of the firm concerned. There is no question of that being relevant to the literal requirements of the contract. It was a discretionary judgment which was available to the successful tenderer within the terms of the contract and there is no basis whatsoever on which that particular exercise of commercial judgment would have proved a sound basis for the termination of the contract.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question to the Minister for Transport and Communications relates to what appears to be an invasion of privacy of citizens who happen to work for the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC). Has the Minister seen a statement by the member for Parkes, Mr Michael Cobb, MP, in which he suggests that an Australian Broadcasting Corporation film crew may have used some or all of $1,000, drawn from a Commonwealth Bank branch in the New South Wales town of Brewarrina, to purchase beer and wine for local Aboriginal people prior to the riot that occurred in that town on Saturday, 15 August 1987? Is the Minister concerned about the possibility that Mr Cobb may have gained access to confidential bank data relating to transactions which took place at that time?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen Mr Cobb's statement and I have called for a full report from the Australian Broadcasting Corporation on the allegations contained in it. Specifically, I have asked the ABC to detail fully the activities of its television and radio news crews who were in Brewarrina at that time. The corporation's report to me will include details of expenses incurred by ABC personnel in Brewarrina and their contact with the local Aboriginal community. I have not yet received the full report I have asked for but I will be happy to make it available when I receive it which I hope will be before the end of this parliamentary week-although obviously I cannot guarantee that.

ANSWER.PARA: On the basis of the partial report that has so far been made to me and which deals specifically with the Four Corners crew, the specific target of Mr Cobb's allegations in the other place yesterday, I can say that that crew was in Brewarrina from Thursday night, 13 August, until mid-Saturday afternoon, 15 August. That crew consisted of the producer Deborah Richards, reporter Pamela Bornhorst, cameraman Chris Doig and sound man Chris Alderton. They were nearing the end of a three-week assignment on the recent spate of Aboriginal deaths in custody-an assignment which was to take them to Adelaide, Wilcannia and Cairns; I am not sure whether it was in that order. The crew members were in Wilcannia from 10 August on the second leg of that research. As it happened, they discovered that the funeral of Lloyd Boney was about to occur in nearby Brewarrina and they made their way there on Thursday, 13 August. Deborah Richards, the producer and crew leader, went to the local Commonwealth Bank on the Friday to cash her travelling allowance cheque for $1,778.70 which was determined as the appropriate TA for a three-week trip for herself. The bank would not cash the cheque in question and suggested that the only way in which she could get some cash in relation to it was to open a personal savings account and transfer the Reserve Bank cheque into it.

TALK.START.PARA: —An ABC cheque, and they would not honour it?

—I am not responsible for the idiosyncrasies of the Commonwealth Bank's cheque cashing procedures but this is the reality of the situation which has been confirmed by my office with the State management of the Commonwealth Bank. That is the way they operate. The sort of identification that is necessary to open an account and cash a cheque is not necessarily of the same order as the identification needed simply to cash a cheque. So be it. Whatever the idiosyncratic management practices of the Brewarrina branch of the Commonwealth Bank may be, the reality is that this was the only way in which she could get some cash for the perceived needs of herself and the crew. In other words, she had to open a personal savings account, transfer the Reserve Bank cheque into it and withdraw the amount she wanted. She deposited the cheque and immediately withdrew $1,000 which she envisaged would be necessary, not only for possible motel and living expenses over the weekend, but also in particular for the possible need to charter a light plane over the weekend to take film back to the city should that need have arisen. That was the particular reason why it was felt necessary to have a substantial amount of cash.

ANSWER.PARA: In fact, the money was not needed. The four-person Four Corners crew left Brewarrina mid-afternoon on Saturday, 15 August, for Sydney and the riot occurred later that night. When Deborah Richards arrived at work on the Monday for discussions about the future shape of the story, the decision was made to concentrate on a black death in one town, Wilcannia. Accordingly she returned $940 of the $1,000 that she had withdrawn to the unit production manager. Some $778 of the original cheque remained in the personal savings account of the Commonwealth Bank which she had opened. This was transferred to the Crows Nest branch. Later that week when the crew set out for a two-week shoot in Wilcannia, Ms Richards took with her both the $778 and the $940 as part of the new standard allocation for a shoot. It will be seen that this is all part of perfectly normal accounting practice and the allegations about the behaviour of the crew and the individual in question, whose name has been so scurrilously dragged through the mud by the scurrilous and contemptible National Party member in question, are most unfortunate.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr President: The description of the honourable member is clearly out of order.

—Is the Minister for Justice aware of the independent stance taken by the Tasmanian Minister for Police, Mr Geoff Pearsall, on the issue of uniform gun laws? How important is the establishment of uniform gun laws if recent tragedies are to be avoided in the future? Is the Minister aware that in the Press Mr Pearsall has accused police Ministers from the Labor States of an hysterical reaction to recent tragedies such as that in Hoddle Street? ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have had drawn to my attention statements attributed to Mr Pearsall, reported in the Mercury of 21 September, where, among other things, he says concerning the proposal that minimum uniform gun laws be established:

ANSWER.PARA: However, the Labor states, in a hysterical reaction to the recent tragedies, have, without advising me, decided to set up a committee to look into gun laws.

The fact is that I advised Mr Pearsall some weeks before a recent meeting of police Ministers that it was desirable that we have some discussions on this topic. He declined to take part in those discussions. He boycotted them and instructed the Tasmanian Attorney-General, Mr Bennett, not to take part in those informal discussions held in Melbourne on 10 September. I believe that it is extremely desirable that there be established some national gun laws of a minimum character-not an exclusive or exhaustive list but at least one which would take into account the fact that the transfer of persons and obviously of firearms around Australia is extremely easy. That is as it should be; we would not want to have border guards supervising every passage of a car or, for example, the docking of the Abel Tasman at Melbourne, to see what firearms might be on board that vessel or in cars crossing State borders. On the other hand, it is clear that we need to have an approach which does not allow such a fragmentation throughout Australia that those jurisdictions which have tried to take steps to make the acquisition of firearms less easy for their citizens are frustrated by their easy purchase in other jurisdictions without due deliberation or taking account of the desires of those jurisdictions where such purchases cannot easily be made.

This came to mind when I was in Western Australia attending a Labor lawyers meeting-unfortunately, I did not attend all sessions-last weekend, when I read a headline in the West Australian of Saturday, 19 September: `Death for sale across the counter'. It recounts the experience of the reporter from the West Australian who had gone to Launceston and purchased a semi-automatic rifle with the same ease, as he said, as `buying a bag of lollies'. He went into the shop called Gun Sales and Service in Launceston, and told the manager he wanted to buy a gun, something military. His article states:
`Would we need a licence for that?' I asked the manager pointing to a semi-automatic on the wall.
`No. No licences here,' was the reply.
`You are over 16 aren't you?' he asked. We all laughed-
and settled on the 0.223 semi-automatic made by the Tasmanian firm, Australian Automatic Arms Pty Ltd.
It would be banned in Western Australia and most other States because it is a semi-automatic, centrefire weapon and can hold more than eight rounds.
I handed over $840 and the manager threw in three packets of Chinese ammunition on the house.

The only requirement was that the person be assessed by the manager to be over 16 years of age. We cannot have in Australia this fragmentation and protection of turf by State Ministers who are not prepared to co-operate in trying to bring about minimum national supervision of the acquisition of firearms by Australians and residents in this country. Indeed, the simple proposal by the Labor Ministers-I do not regard it as an hysterical reaction but as a well-considered and understandable reaction to recent tragedies-is that a working party be set up to look at proposals, including the licensing of shooters under a common national system; a practical test of firearm knowledge and safety for gun licence applicants; a uniform permit to purchase system requiring gun buyers to justify the reasons for buying guns; and the establishment of a national firearms register enabling jurisdictions to cross reference applications for firearm purchases. I am taking part in those discussions and so is Mr John Brown, because of the implications for the Australian Capital Territory. We hope that these discussions will prove useful in bringing about a situation where, without unduly interfering with farmers and recreational shooters in the pursuit of their necessary recreational interests, the occurrence I have referred to will not become as common as apparently it is.

—Does the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs have any information on reports that a caretaker government is to be formed in Fiji?

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Collins Sen R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Justice--

QUESTION.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—It relates to Aboriginal deaths in custody-I wish there were a few deaths in here. I refer the Minister to the meeting in Melbourne on 10 September of Ministers for Police, Corrective Services and Aboriginal Affairs which discussed the issue of Aboriginal deaths in custody. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will answer the question not only in my capacity as Minister representing the Attorney-General but also as Minister for Justice, because in fact the convening of that meeting on 10 September in Melbourne was undertaken as a result of a joint initiative by both me and the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Gerry Hand. Honourable senators will recall that in announcing the establishment of a royal commission of inquiry into the circumstances surrounding certain Aboriginal deaths in custody since 1980, the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, also announced that there would be a meeting aimed at preventing future deaths in custody. The meeting needed to be convened in a timely, even urgent, way in order to share the common experiences of Police and Corrective Services Ministers so as to attempt-as I say, in a timely and even urgent way-to prevent the recurrence of the tragedy of Aboriginal deaths in custody, of which at that stage there had been quite a number in the preceding months.

ANSWER.PARA: That meeting having been convened, I believe that the sharing of experiences and the sheer making of Ministers such as me aware of the difficulties and the circumstances surrounding the question of taking Aboriginal persons into custody-all that sharing of information-were extremely valuable. Those of us in southern urban areas, certainly myself, do not have the same degree of experience of these matters as, for example, the Northern Territory and Queensland Ministers, and their experiences were made available to that meeting. For example, whereas penal reformers have always talked of the desirability of having single prisoner cells with extreme privacy for most prisoners, in fact it became apparent that in many instances multiple prisoner cells were much more desirable as far as Aboriginals were concerned so that they could be accompanied by fellow Aboriginals in that situation. Indeed, it would lessen the sense of isolation that can be experienced and which can lead to such deep despair that it might possibly lead to suicide.

It was matters such as this that proved the value of that meeting. All Ministers at the meeting supported the concept of using divisionary facilities so that Aboriginals might perhaps be put in the care of Aboriginal community groups as an alternative to detention in cells. There was also general agreement on the need for better liaison between police and Aboriginal communities. We actually had reports that a considerable amount of liaison work was very successfully undertaken, and Ministers were able to transfer the better experiences for use in other jurisdictions.

One of the most positive results from the meeting was a reference to the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General (SCAG) of two matters-the removal of intoxication as an offence and a review of bail laws. I understand that at the SCAG meeting last week that matter was put on the agenda for February of next year and it is being looked at by its officials.

This meeting involved only very preliminary discussions on a matter of great concern, the averting of these tragedies, and I believe that, as we are at an early stage, we can look forward perhaps to the end of November, when we have the scheduled meeting of Police and Corrective Services Ministers, for a time when those Ministers will be able, in a more formal way, perhaps, to come to enough common agreement to promulgate a common set of national guidelines relating to the taking of Aboriginal persons into custody. That will require a good deal of consultation beforehand, and both I and the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs believe that it is important that we consult with Aboriginal people who are involved on a day to day basis in the criminal justice system and allow them to participate in the formulation of the procedures and processes that ought to be put in place. In this respect, the National Aboriginal and Islander Legal Service Secretariat, along with other Aboriginal groups, will attend a conference in October to be funded by the Commonwealth to discuss and evaluate such a code. I believe that with such input and further very helpful discussions between Ministers of all jurisdictions, by about the end of November we will be able to promulgate such a code which will help in preventing future tragedies of this type.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General and it follows the question asked by Senator Stone which Senator Ryan was not able to answer. I remind the Minister representing the Attorney-General that Senator Stone's question referred to the fact that the key operational clauses of the Australia Card legislation, clauses 40 to 54, can come into effect only after the first relevant day and second relevant day specified in clause 32 (1) of the Bill when they are fixed by regulation. If I may, by way of further preface, I will read a paragraph from a memorandum on the Australia Card Bill and its possible effectiveness. It says:

QUESTION.PARA: Thus all the main offences are completely dependent on there being such a relevant day. See, for example, clauses 40-54, which all provide for offences if the Card has not been produced on or after the first (or second) relevant day. If there is, as a matter of law, no such day, then the main provisions of the Act will collapse-they cannot be enforced.
Still further by way of preface, I would also briefly quote the following paragraph of the memorandum:
The conclusion is that regulations fixing the first and second relevant days are open to disallowance and the disallowance would be effective to make the Australia card Act wholly ineffective.

I ask the Minister: Will he examine the proposition which has been put before him and the memorandum which I am about to seek leave to table and have incorporated in Hansard? Will he advise the Senate of whether the Australia Card Act could be effective in the event of the disallowance of those regulations? Will he seek the advice of his Government as to whether in these circumstances the Government will proceed with this legislation which is causing such strong opposition in the Australian community?
Mr President, I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard this Opposition memorandum on the operation of the Bill, which is 2 1/4 pages, and to table it.
Leave granted.
The memorandum read as follows-
AUSTRALIA CARD BILL
Disallowance of Regulations fixing ``first relevant day'' and ``second relevant day''

The Australia Card Bill provides, in clause 2, that it is to come into operation on such day as is, or on such respective days as are, fixed by Proclamation. But the real operation of the Bill is dependent on there being a ``first relevant day'' and thereafter ``a second relevant day''.

Thus all the main offences are completely dependent on there being such a relevant day. See, for example, clauses 40-54, which all provide for offences if the Card has not been produced on or after the first (or second) relevant day. If there is, as a matter of law, no such day, then the main provisions of the Act will collapse-they cannot be enforced.

The meaning of the ``first relevant day'' (and the second such day) is to be found in clause 32 (1). ``First relevant day'' is there defined as ``a day declared by the regulations to be the first relevant day for the purposes of this Part, not being a day that is earlier than 1 March, 1989''.
Suppose regulations were made fixing 1 April, 1989 as the first relevant day. These regulations could, in accordance with s.48 of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901, be disallowed by the Senate.

Under sub-section (6) of s.48, the disallowance has the same effect as a repeal of the regulations. There would therefore cease to be any law identifying the ``first relevant day'', and the vital operative provisions of the Australia Card Act would be brought to nought. Hence, if this view is correct, the Act would be wholly defeated-there would be no obligation on banks, other financial institutions, brokers, or any other persons (whether corporate or not) to comply with its provisions.
Precisely the same considerations apply to the fixing of the ``second relevant day''.

The only question that seems to arise is whether what is in effect a repeal (Acts Interpretation Act, s.48 (6)) deprives the once-fixed day (by the regulations that are disallowed) of all future operation. The question arises because a repeal does not wipe out the regulations from the time it was enacted, but from the time of the repeal (or disallowance). Section 48 (6) does not provide for the repeal to be retrospective, as if the regulation had never been made, and for good reason. Some time may have gone by and things lawfully done under it need to be kept as valid. However, at the particular time when an offence would be sought to be shown to have occurred, there would be no ``day declared by the regulations to be the first relevant day'' as the regulations had been repealed! And why were regulations chosen as the vehicle of fixing such a date, if it was not to allow for subsequent ease of extending, by alteration, that date. It could have been provided for by Proclamation, or by executive act, which would not be disallowable. Having chosen the means, the consequences flow.
The conclusion is that regulations fixing the first and second relevant days are open to disallowance and the disallowance would be effective to make the Australia Card Act wholly ineffective.

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that I have received the following letter, dated 23 September, from Senator McLean:

INTERJECT.PARA: In accordance with Standing Order 64, I intend to move today-That in the opinion of the Senate the following is a matter of urgency:

The requirement for the Government to acknowledge and rectify the inadequacies of the Evatt Royal Commission into the effects of Agent Orange, in order to accord with the spirit of the imminent ``Welcome Home'' march for Vietnam Veterans and to restore confidence in the processes of public inquiry which have been seriously damaged.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

The requirement for the Government to acknowledge and rectify the inadequacies of the Evatt Royal Commission into the effects of Agent Orange, in order to accord with the spirit of the imminent `Welcome Home' march for Vietnam Veterans and to restore confidence in the processes of public inquiry which have been seriously damaged.

Before developing the Australian Democrats' case for this proposition, I wish to place on record my pleasure at having been assigned the shadow portfolio of veterans' affairs as it provides me with an opportunity to serve a constituency with which I have a strong affiliation. My first contacts with the responsible Minister, the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, the Hon. Ben Humphreys, and his senior departmental staff have been courteous, positive and very professional and I thank them for the thoroughness and the manner of their briefings in recent days.

I turn now to the proposition before the chamber. This being my first urgency motion, I naturally turned to Odgers. I am satisfied, as you are, Mr Acting Deputy President, that it is clearly in order and that it is indeed a matter of urgency. I quote from page 292 of Australian Senate Practice where Odgers states:
. . . the Urgency Motion provides a unique opportunity for bringing the Government to account for its administration, which is Parliament's duty.

That is exactly what we wish to do here-to bring the Government to account for its administration. The Australian Democrats and the Vietnam Veterans Association of Australia are seeking the support of honourable senators in gaining from the Government an important acknowledgment-an acknowledgment that the royal commission appointed to investigate the effects of exposure to agent orange and other toxic substances on those who served in Vietnam failed the Government, failed the Australian people in general and failed the Vietnam veterans in particular. That royal commission, the Evatt Royal Commission on the Use and Effects of Chemical Agents on Australian Personnel in Vietnam, failed us not because of the conclusions it reached but in the manner in which it reached those conclusions.

We, the Australian Democrats, hopefully supported by other senators, argue that it is imperative that the Government should publicly and clearly reject the findings and the methods of the Commission so that the true needs of Vietnam veterans may be acknowledged and attended to and so that confidence may be restored in the processes of public inquiry in this country. I will briefly sketch in the background and then justify our criticisms of the Commission. As Australian Democrat senators we are sincerely convinced that we are justified in seeking the support of all honourable senators in this motion. Our examination of the report and credible evaluations of it leave us in no doubt that we are justified in this plea. Because of the imminent `Welcome Home' marches on 2, 3 and 4 October, it is urgent that we all support this motion now and that the Government give effect to it. One cannot underestimate the significance of these `Welcome Home' marches. After 15 years Australians will finally declare their pride in these men and women. We will salute them and acknowledge their proud place in our history by saying to them, `thank you; well served under the most difficult of circumstances'.

Of course, the Government is to be congratulated on supporting these events with financial assistance of $50,000 and the offer of a range of supporting services such as the transport of veterans and their relatives. However, that is not good enough because at the same time as the Government is apparently being so supportive, it continues to accept the findings of a grossly flawed process of public inquiry-a public inquiry which was vital to the rendering of justice to many Australian servicemen and women.

The Evatt Royal Commission was merely one among several recent inquiries which denigrated and gravely damaged the credibility of the process of public inquiry in this country. It will assist if we look briefly at the dimensions of Australia's involvement in the Vietnam war. Let us remind ourselves of the magnitude of the sacrifices that were made by Vietnam veterans.

You will be aware, Mr Acting Deputy President, that Australia first became involved in the Vietnam conflict in May 1962, that, as a result of this involvement, national service was introduced in Australia, that it was a lottery system of national service and that national servicemen were posted to Vietnam for the first time in May 1965. For almost 10 years national servicemen and regular servicemen served in that theatre of war until the process of withdrawal began in October 1971 and was completed in December 1972.

During that period, 45 females and 40,000 males served in Vietnam. Almost 17,000 of them were national servicemen. Sadly, 414 Australians died in the conflict. I suppose that, alongside the 53,000, nearly 54,000, who died in World War I and the 19,000 who died in World War II, the figure of 414 may seem relatively insignificant. Two hundred and seventy-seven Australians died in Korea. Subsequent to their service, and sacrifice in many cases, by June 1982, 17,000 Vietnam veterans had lodged claims with the Repatriation Commission and of these, almost 11,000 had succeeded in obtaining disability assistance and 7,000 had been awarded some form of pension. Approximately 400-this is a significant figure-out of the 1,000 claims based on herbicide exposure have been acknowledged and granted. So we are suggesting that there are 400 precedents in this country alone for the granting of repatriation benefits relating to herbicide exposure.

We now sense a dimension which we did not anticipate. Who could have anticipated the use of enormous quantities of toxic substances, the effects of which were unknown at the time and, many would argue, are still substantially unknown? So, years after the event the controversy still rages. Scientific and medical questions remain unsolved. In all, 27 different chemicals were used, only some of which have proven toxicity. The real troublemakers were those chemicals assigned colour-coded names or designations, such as agent orange, agent blue and agent white.

I am not a technical or scientific expert but I have access to them. On my left sits my colleague Senator Dr John Coulter, who is an eminent researcher in this area. I have had considerable discussion with him in relation to this matter. So, as one who is not technically knowledgeable but who has access to advice, I prefer to keep it simple. The greatest troublemaker, as I am advised, is agent orange, which contains dioxin, the most toxic substance known to man. It is claimed, scientifically and otherwise, that these are two profound long term effects of exposure to dioxin. The first is that, because dioxin is a highly carcinogenic substance, exposure to it will lead to a substantially heightened risk of cancers. The second claim is that it may give rise to genetic birth defects in the offspring of veterans. Not only dioxin is cited as being carcinogenic. The evidence in support of these claims was considerable and was sufficient for the Government to establish the Evatt Commission. Here is the nub of the problem. The Vietnam Veterans Association completely rejects the findings of the Evatt Commission, but especially its methods and dispositions or, perhaps more correctly, its predispositions. Furthermore, the Association argues that since the Commission tabled its conclusions in August 1985 more significant findings have been made which support its position and deny further the conclusions which were reached by the Commission and accepted by the Government.

The Australian Democrats support the claims of the Vietnam Veterans Association of Australia. We are convinced that its concern is justified. I remind honourable senators of the sequence of events. In August 1985 the Government accepted the findings of the Evatt Commission, namely and in summary, that there was insufficient evidence of a link between toxic substances used in Vietnam and subsequent illnesses. That was a general statement of the findings. In November 1985 the Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats, Senator Michael Macklin, tabled the Vietnam Veterans Association's reactions and substantially supported its expressed doubts.

In May 1986 the then Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Senator Gietzelt, gave an assurance that the Government would investigate the claims of bias and plagiarism which were beginning to emerge. In May of this year, presumably in order to investigate those claims, the Minister announced the appointment of Mr Bob Hogg as special consultant to the Government to report on the adequacy of the Evatt Commission. It is anticipated that Mr Hogg will report to the Cabinet in October this year. Most recently, and probably most controversially, the Vietnam Veterans Association has claimed that Mr Hogg has been restricted in his terms of reference and that, in essence, he has been directed to be uncritical of the Commission's methods and predispositions. This claim has been specifically denied to me as recently as yesterday by the responsible Minister, Mr Humphreys.

I would like to cite the extent and nature of the dissatisfaction with the Commission's methods. I quote from an article which appeared in the Sydney Morning Herald on 5 May 1986. Mr Rick Haines, the National Secretary of the Vietnam Veterans Association of Australia, is quoted as saying:

[the] commission placed too much emphasis on material supplied by the manufacturers and distributors of Agent Orange, Monsanto Australia Ltd, and that the commission's report in part contained word-for-word material from the companies which defended the use of the chemical. . . .
The association had identified 360 pages of the report that caused it concern, most to do with the evaluation of evidence from the chemical company side.
Two further experts who expressed their grave concern were quoted in the same article:

. . . two of the commission's scientific witnesses, the Swedish physicians Dr Olav Axelson and Dr Lennart Hardell, accused the commission of producing a questionable document by `suppressing and distorting' information. . . .

According to Dr Axelson, Professor of Occupational Medicine at the University of Linkoping in Sweden, the report `had serious flaws as a result of the commission's misquotations of published work, distortions and falsifications of the facts.
Dr Hardell said he had `never had an agency or commission handle data so carelessly and make so many wrong conclusions'.
The physicists sent letters to the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, and the Governor-General, Sir Ninian Stephen, calling for a fresh inquiry.

Obviously, they were totally disgusted and disillusioned with the status of the report. Dr Clyde Maxwell, a Fellow of the American Association for the Advancement of Science writing in the Medical Journal of Australia, said:

1. It should be recognised that the Evatt Royal Commission did not conform to the norms of scientific and medical research and that, thus, its conclusions on scientific and medical matters should be ignored.
2. The issues raised in regard to allegations of plagiarism and the hostile treatment of witnesses should be referred to the Office of the Attorney-General.

Kenneth Maddoch, Associate Professor of Anthropology at the Macquarie University, in a comprehensive paper of 12 January this year, referring to submissions by the Vietnam Veterans Association of Australia said:

In conclusion, I believe that your charges of bias and plagiarism are well-founded and that they are deeply disturbing . . . The fact that evidence is continuing to come forward of possible links between cancer and chemicals of the sort used in Vietnam makes the position even more unsatisfactory.

As evidence of the degree of dissatisfaction and disillusionment with the status of this report, I quote Dr Ben Selinger of the Australian National University, as reported in the Law Journal of Australia early this year:

It is ironic that the Royal Commissions epilogue consists of a scathing attack on scientists and publicists arguing that Agent Orange was a causative agent, when the Commission itself obviously understood little of the scientific philosophy of its own experts.

That is documented rejection of the status of the Evatt Commission report. Sadly, the Evatt Commission drew the conclusion that no findings meant no danger. A scientifically more honest thing to say would have been that we know that we are dealing with extremely potent toxic substances and that there is a higher probability of the dangerous links hypothesised, but that it is not possible, because of lack of control data, to prove them statistically. The scientific realities are that where records are grossly inadequate, no conclusions whatsoever can be drawn, and in this case records are totally inadequate. So the pursuit of scientific research in this regard is bound to lead to insubstantial evidence.

A new controversial accusation is the suggestion that the Government, by imposing restrictions on Mr Hogg-this is the nub of the proposition before the chamber-is even now sustaining what amounts to a blatant whitewash, despite the fact that Senator Gietzelt, the then Minister, gave assurances to the contrary. The Vietnam Veterans Association has no doubt at all as to Mr Hogg's present situation. The National President of the Vietnam Veterans Association, Mr Tim McCombe, when he wrote to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) earlier this month, said:
I wish to express this association's concern that restrictions have been placed on Mr Bob Hogg, consultant to Cabinet on the Evatt Royal Commission, without prior consultation with this association.

The instruction to Mr Hogg that he should not criticise Justice Evatt in his report to Cabinet in fact raises serious questions about the government's commitment to properly investigating Mr Justice Evatt's findings.
I re-emphasise that as recently as yesterday the responsible Minister, Mr Ben Humphreys, denied such restrictions on Mr Hogg's terms of reference.

In conclusion, the Australian Democrats urge honourable senators, at this critical time, only days before the welcome home march, to support this urgent appeal to the Government on behalf of this worthy group of Australians who have already sacrificed, but some of whom may yet have the worst to come. Shoddy and inadequate processes of inquiry deserve to be disowned, not sustained and furthered. Therefore, let us collectively call upon the Government to disown and correct them now before the first weekend in October. I commend the motion to honourable senators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Most honourable senators and, indeed, most Australians will remember full well the period of the late 1960s and early 1970s, known generally as the Vietnam war era. I think most Australians would acknowledge that the soldiers who answered the call of their nation and served in forces in Vietnam, some 50,000 of them, did a marvellous job for Australia and maintained Australia's military tradition. There is no doubt that our troops were regarded by the United States troops, the Koreans and the Filipinos, who also served as our allies in Vietnam, as the finest of all the services whose members gave their services and in some cases their lives on the fields in Vietnam. That is the first thing to be acknowledged about what occurred during that period. The many feats of battle undertaken by our soldiers are well known. I recall the battle of Long Tan--
—You recall the bottle all right. You are pretty good on that, I am told.

—The Minister might take this matter more seriously by attending the march on 3 October. This is of pretty serious concern to most Australians, if not to him. Feats of arms, such as the battle of Long Tan, particularly, and the clearance of the Viet Cong from virtually the whole of the province of Phuoc Tuy during that period, amounted to an enormous victory for Australian troops. SPEECH.PARA: Bearing that in mind, I bring to the attention of the Senate the lack of taste and the untimeliness of this motion, having been moved in the fashion that it has by the Australian Democrats today. We have now introduced an element of politics into a situation from which we should be seeking to get rid of that element, which has too often and for too long dogged the history of the repatriation of the Vietnam veteran. For that reason, the Opposition will not be supporting the Democrats' motion. Indeed, I will be moving an amendment, which I hope will have the support of other senators and become the final recognised resolution of the Senate in this matter.

I think it is a sorry thing at this late stage, so close to the Vietnam welcome home march on 3 October, that we should seek to inject into this matter an element of such political controversy as surrounded the whole agent orange question from the late 1970s to now. But, that matter having been raised, we must as senators start to examine some of the events of that period and to place on public record the inquiries undertaken by governments of both persuasions into the problems of agent orange. I mention in passing, since the Democrats have seen fit to raise such a political matter, that during the period in which I was Minister for Veterans' Affairs-from late 1980 to the early part of 1983-I waited in vain for the matter to be raised in debate by the Australian Democrats but not once was a motion brought forward by them for debate in this place. That also applied to the then Opposition, the now Labor Government.

When I became Minister for Veterans' Affairs back in 1980, I found fairly quickly that there was need for a conclusive scientific examination of the effects of agent orange and other chemicals on our soldiers in Vietnam. The procedure that had been followed up to that time was to seek to establish any scientific link between chemicals and the ill effects of service in Vietnam. None have been found. Indeed, at that time there was a total lack of any scientific evidence of any kind of link.

The Fraser Government established an epidemiological study of the 50,000 veterans who had returned and that was well under way at the end of 1980. However, it soon became evident that that task was not going to provide quick enough or adequate enough results. Consequently, as Minister I decided to establish at that time rather shorter inquiries which could be undertaken and finalised in a much shorter time frame, with very useful and, I think, significant results. At that point that major epidemiological study was discarded and shorter inquiries into the relationship of agent orange to birth defects, the mortality of veterans and morbidity were established. The reports on those studies were received progressively from 1982 through to 1984, when the present Government was in power.

The one thing we have to acknowledge is that the reports established no connection between chemical exposures and any illness among veterans. The Senate also established in 1982 a Senate committee inquiry into these matters. That committee came down with much the same report as all of the other inquiries which have subsequently reported.

These results coincide very broadly with other inquiries that have been undertaken by United States Government agencies. For instance, an investigation through the so-called Operation Ranchhand in San Antonio, Texas, revealed that there were no registrable ill effects amongst Air Force personnel who were in direct contact with chemicals. Only recently we have heard that the Centre for Disease Control in Atlanta, Georgia, which I visited I think in 1981 to discover what progress had been made in its inquiries, has revealed that in fact chemicals did not cause any birth defects in children fathered by Vietnam veterans, and that there was not a far heavier increase in mortality amongst Vietnam veterans than there was in the ordinary population. This consequently confirms again the results of our inquiries in this country.

A recent study in the United States into cancers amongst Vietnam veterans has thrown up a rather errant result in that one particular group of veterans, namely those who served in the United States Marine Corps, have in fact, for some reason or other, developed cancers to a greater extent than either their comrades who served in the general infantry forces and other forces in Vietnam or the general population. Nobody has been able to explain why the marines have been so afflicted and why there is that difference. Nevertheless, the overall result of that inquiry has proven to be much the same as all the other inquiries-that there is very little difference between those who served in Vietnam and may have contracted cancer and the general population.

Notwithstanding all of this, the fact remains that the Government, the Opposition prior to the 1983 election, promised that it would set up a royal commission to examine the linkage between chemical exposure and the health of Vietnam veterans. That was notwithstanding the fact that there was plenty of scientific evidence around the place at that time denying that there was any connection and the unlikely chance of the inquiry turning up results that had not been established by the other inquiries that had been held before. Nevertheless, the present Labor Government set up that inquiry on coming to office. In the middle of 1985 that inquiry reported much along the lines of all of the other inquiries that had been conducted. It stated that no scientific link could be established between the exposure of veterans to chemicals and their health.

The point about this is simply that the Government sought to establish that inquiry notwithstanding all the evidence at the time that there was no link. At the time that seemed to be a rather silly procedure, but the Government persisted with it. Having done that, having now received the results of that inquiry and having built up the hopes of Vietnam veterans that that inquiry would produce results that were somewhat different from those of all other inquiries, the Government has failed since the middle of 1985 to investigate properly the complaints which have been put down in writing and which certainly have received a lot of media exposure. Those complaints have been made by veterans who have been exposed to chemicals in the Vietnam war and who feel that they have suffered ill effects. The fact is that the Government has built up the hopes of those people and it has failed to deliver on those hopes.

There is some evidence that leads us to suspect that the Government is failing to examine properly the report of the Evatt Royal Commission on the Use and Effects of Chemical Agents on Australia Personnel in Vietnam. Indeed, Mr Hogg, who I understand has been appointed investigator of this matter, has not yet brought down a further report to the Government. As I say, there has been no action on this matter since the Evatt report came down almost two years ago. What this seems to indicate is that the Government is lacking in resolve to help Vietnam veterans who consider themselves to be the subject of ill effects of chemical exposure. The Government, having established that it believes there is a possibility of exposure by denying that previous reports were valid, now fails to take further action in that regard. Consequently, I believe that the Government has a case to answer here and should act as soon as possible to ensure that it allays the fears and concerns of Vietnam veterans, who have been very vocal on this matter for some time.

The issues that have been raised by veterans concerning the Evatt report are pretty well known and I think Senator McLean referred to some of the concerns when he talked of the apparent bias of members of the Evatt Royal Commission and its counsel. He also talked about plagiarism and the Monsanto submission. It would seem rather odd to me if a commission hearing evidence provided by one of the companies directly concerned with this matter, that is Monsanto, did not then quote that as part of the reason for it having formed an opinion about the outcome of its inquiry. That can hardly amount to plagiarism of that particular submission. Nevertheless, notwithstanding all of that, the fact is that these fears and concerns do exist, and I think that is where the Government has failed. Consequently, it ought to seek to investigate these matters in a far more diligent and expedient fashion than it has to date.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is dragging its feet.

—It is dragging its feet, as Senator Newman says, and consequently it needs to be stirred up a little bit. This is probably the most that can be said for the Democrat motion in this respect. Notwithstanding the other arguments that they have introduced into this matter, I wish to reiterate that point: we have here an attempt to politicise what is almost a sacred time-a period in which we, as a nation, can reflect upon the aims, deeds and great feats on the battlefield of our soldiers in Vietnam. This is a matter of great concern to the Liberal and National parties. We believe that our soldiers performed absolutely brilliantly, very bravely and courageously and served their country well in Vietnam. We believe that all Australians should acknowledge that during the march in Sydney on 3 October. Many Liberal and National members of parliament, both Federal and State, will be attending that march in Sydney to show their respect for our magnificent troops who served in Vietnam.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Leave out all words after `urgency', insert:

The need to acknowledge the concerns of Vietnam veterans regarding the outcome of the Evatt Royal Commission which continue, notwithstanding successive inquiries, both private and public, culminating in that Commission, by providing appropriate repatriation benefits for those veterans who gave service to their country at great personal sacrifice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government opposes the motion moved by the Australian Democrats. We will support the amendment moved by the Opposition for the very reasons that I wish to outline to the Senate. In fact, the Senate has had the opportunity on numerous occasions to examine both its own report in 1982 and another report on the case control study of congenital anomalies and Vietnam service birth defects study which was presented by the previous Government in January 1983. Then, of course, we had the mortality study which I presented to the Senate in October 1984. No member of this Government has been unsympathetic to the problems of the Vietnam veterans. No Minister of this Government has been unsympathetic to the general view that exists amongst Vietnam veterans, as well as the community at large and in particular the media, about the problems of Australia's involvement in Vietnam and the effects on the health of those who served there. Certainly, no Minister for Veterans' Affairs has shown more interest than I when I held that position for some 4 1/2 years and had to handle, deal and contend with the conflicting scientific evidence and views that existed about the use of chemical agents in Vietnam. When I retired from the job of Minister for Veterans' Affairs I kept and maintain in my present office one particular group of files which deal with this very issue of pesticides, herbicides and chemical agents in Vietnam.

SPEECH.PARA: I am most sympathetic to the difficulties that some Vietnam veterans have experienced and feel in relation to their service in that war. In my first administrative act as a Minister I set in train the Evatt Royal Commission. I negotiated the terms of reference with ministerial colleagues and with members of the Vietnam Veterans Association. Finally, of course, the Royal Commission was appointed. This Government not only established it but also provided sums in excess of $600,000 to the Vietnam Veterans Association for the purpose of their having the capacity to participate and to call scientific evidence and persons to put their case before the Royal Commission. In addition to that resource which the Government provided, I and my office were `friends in court' if I could use that expression. Without any doubt there was a very harmonious and friendly relationship between the Vietnam Veterans Association, myself and my personal staff. As a result of the request from the Vietnam Veterans Association extensions were given to the Commission to carry out its work. Instead of reporting, as was anticipated, within a year, the Royal Commission went on for some two years. It was not until July 1985 that the Commission was able to complete its work and hand down its findings.

It is true that misgivings and concerns still exist amongst various members of the Services who served in Vietnam. The Government acknowledges that. Therefore, despite the fact that it appointed an umpire-that is what a royal commissioner is-to sift the evidence and come to a conclusion, the Government was very careful in the way it reached its conclusions on the Evatt findings. Nevertheless, having regard to so many of the findings and recommendations that were made by the Royal Commissioner, the Government saw fit to refer the matter back to the Department of Veterans' Affairs and the Department of Defence for the purpose of further examining the issues that were raised in that Royal Commission.

The Government is aware of the genuine concerns that exist. One may come to the conclusion that there is nothing finite in the area of science and health; one cannot be dogmatic in these matters. My personal view is that I still have a degree of doubt, having regard to the evidence that has been referred to in the debate by both the Democrats and the Opposition. Nevertheless, there is sufficient doubt to say that the matter requires further examination. As I replied to Senator Newman and Senator Lewis when I was Minister in the earlier part of this year, I took the matter to the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) for his comments on the concerns which have been amplified today by Senator McLean. On the basis of that report I then referred the matter back to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) with a recommendation that Mr Hogg be appointed to further examine the issues that were raised by the Vietnam Veterans Association and its officers with whom I have very close personal relationships. I include the late Phil Thompson, who was one of the prime movers for the establishment of the Royal Commission with a view to reconciling and resolving those concerns that had been expressed. The Government is still sympathetic to the claims of the Vietnam veterans. That is why the new Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Mr Humphreys, recently reappointed Mr Hogg whose consultancy concluded at the dissolution of Parliament. He is required to report to the Government within the next few weeks. One can have a view about the Monsanto evidence, about the extravagant language that was used in the report and about the concerns that have not been resolved by the four reports that have been presented. One has only to read the American Press to be aware that the United States Government and the American people, including US scientists, and scientists worldwide, have still unresolved views on the use of chemical agents in wartime, particularly those used in Vietnam.

If any criticism is to be levelled at all, it is that the previous Government sent the troops to Vietnam, involved them in an unwinnable war and then allowed them to be brought back to Australia without providing sufficient psychological adjustment programs. I lay some blame for that at the door of the armed services chiefs in that they did not understand the essential readjustments that were needed by those who were sent away to Vietnam, a third of whom were national service conscripts. There was no understanding at top levels in the armed services of what was needed when people were brought back to a community that was so heavily divided over our involvement in that war.

What has the Government done? It appointed the Commission, it provided financial resources, and it provided human resources in a friendly Minister and his staff. We established the joint venture scheme, which has proved to be a very important initiative. We also established a half-way house in Brisbane where the emotional problems and other difficulties suffered by Vietnam veterans are able to be ventilated with people who understand those problems. This Government has extended the pilot scheme, the Vietnam Veterans Counselling Service, which was established by the previous Government, and nine agencies are now operating throughout Australia. Some 5,000 Vietnam veterans have participated in the counselling service. This Government brought in the domestic allowance and the majority of Vietnam widows have profited from that provision. In the Veterans' Entitlements Act the Government extended free treatment to all Vietnam veterans, regardless of their capacity to show that their state of health was due to service in Vietnam. We have extended the range of benefits to those who served in the supply ships-benefits which were denied by the previous Government. We took that action on the basis that we believed that those who were involved in the Jeparit, the Boonaroo and the Sydney should become entitled to benefits under the Veterans' Entitlement Act.

Let us look at what the Government has done since then. The Government acted from the first day that the concept of the Welcome Home came to light. Indeed, I was the first person approached and I immediately made available $15,000 for that venture. I wrote to each State Premier following an approach that was made to me by Mr Unsworth, the Premier of New South Wales. Each State gave the Welcome Home organisers a donation of $10,000. Not only have all States participated, but the Premier of South Australia has also provided leave without pay to enable Vietnam veterans to come to Sydney on the holiday weekend in a couple of weeks time.

It has been asserted by Senator McLean that Mr Hogg has been restricted in his work and his consultancy project. The terms of Mr Hogg's consultancy were established clearly at the time of his engagement. He is to co-ordinate the Government's response to the report of the Royal Commission on the Use and Effects of Chemical Agents on Australian Personnel in Vietnam. The task involves drawing together the issues, but not seeking to reopen them or the work already done by various departments or inquiries. It would be absurd to suggest that the Senate, Mr Hogg or any other person should sit in judgment on a royal commission whose task it was to evaluate the evidence. Whether one likes the judgment of a royal commission, whether it be in the Chamberlain case or in other areas of public inquiry, the Government is obliged to accept the findings, unless it is said that there is no confidence in the way in which the inquiry has carried out its work. That is not the position. The Government has ensured, as the figures prove, that the Vietnam veterans are now getting access to the repatriation system at the same level as all the other personnel who served in World War I and World War II. There is no discrimination at all. I am satisfied beyond any reasonable doubt that there is no longer any need for Vietnam veterans to believe that the Repatriation Commission is not conscious of its responsibilities to apply fairly and equitably the terms and benefits that are available under the various pieces of repatriation legislation.

It is true, as Senator Messner suggested, that a case study has been made in the United States which suggests that there is still some evidence that goes beyond what is normal-that certain groups of United States Vietnam veterans have suffered health problems to a greater extent than have other sections of the armed forces. Whatever can be said about the problem with which we are confronted, it must be said that this Government since its election in 1983 has been sympathetic on this subject. Therefore, we cannot support the motion, despite the vehemence with which it has been put forward by the Australian Democrats. We will support the Opposition's amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the motion and speak against the amendment. I am concerned at some of the hogwash the Senate has heard this afternoon on the so-called scientific evidence. I wish to make a few comments in order to correct statements which have been made. Before I do so, I point to the claim made by Senator Messner that the Australian Democrats are raising this as a political matter. I have been on record for a long time as being opposed to the sending of Australian troops to Vietnam. Nonetheless, I support the claim made by the Vietnam veterans as to exposure to agent orange, and I do so for very good reason. Recently concern has been expressed over very low levels of pesticide in Australian meat exported to the United States of America, and questions have been raised as to the possibility that organochlorine pesticides can cause cancer and birth defects. That is the basis of the concern expressed in that area.

SPEECH.PARA: The dioxin which was present in the 2,4,5-T used in Vietnam is the most potent organochlorine substance known in terms of its mutagenic and carcinogenic activity. Two things need to be noted about these substances. First, when a substance has been shown to be mutagenic, around the world all scientific authorities recognise that the relationship between the dose, the level of exposure and the incidence of adverse effects, such as mutations and cancer, are linear and without threshold. In other words the risk rises lineally with exposure. That risk disappears only when there is no further exposure. In other words, any exposure carries some risk and the level of risk rises with the level of exposure.

The second point I make is that when people try in epidemiological studies to find an increase in cancers or birth defects they do so against a substantial background of naturally occurring cancers and birth defects. It is extremely difficult to establish from epidemiological studies that increases have occurred. For example, if I were to take a coin and toss it 100 times, I would expect that on average I would get 50 heads and 50 tails. But if it came down 51 heads and 49 tails I would not necessarily suspect that the coin was biased. I could even get 48 heads and 52 tails or 47 and 53. The question is: at what point do we say that there is a reasonable possibility that the coin is biased? In fact we need to get down to about 37 heads and 63 tails before there is a one in 20 chance that the coin has a bias, and we presume there is bias in the coin. There may not necessarily be one, but there is a one in 20 chance that there is. But for purely arbitrary mathematical reasons we call that the level of significance, and that principle is followed in epidemiological studies.

Among the Vietnam veterans, or among any group in Western society, we expect about 25 per cent of the population to get cancer at some stage in their life. Australian statistics show that about 19 per cent of the Australian population will die from cancer. It is against that background that we are trying to pick up relatively small changes in the incidence of cancer and birth defects. From epidemiological evidence we would not expect to be able to prove that Vietnam veterans were suffering from a higher than normal incidence of cancer or birth defects in their children, so we were not surprised when that was not found. But that is not proof that there was not an increase in either cancer or birth defects. We are forced, from all the evidence, to believe that we are dealing with a substance which is a potent mutagen and a potent carcinogen and which was present in very large amounts in agent orange. I would remind the Senate that the level of dioxin allowed in 2,4,5-T in Australia is 0.1 parts per million, whereas the average level of 2,4,5-T used in Vietnam was 1.8 parts per million. Some of the levels went much higher than that. Therefore we would expect some level of birth defects and some level of cancers to have occurred in that population.

It would be very useful if the Senate were to look at the report of the Evatt Royal Commission on the Use and Effects of Chemical Agents on Australian Personnel in Vietnam and compare it with the way in which the inquiry into the incident of cancer and birth defects at Maralinga looked at the same sort of evidence; in the latter case in relation to exposure to radiation. But again, one would not have expected to find epidemiological evidence among people who were exposed to radiation at Maralinga. Nonetheless, in the case of the Maralinga inquiry, there was a clear recognition that those men may well have experienced some damage. That is the sort of result which I think the Evatt inquiry should honestly have come forward with. It is the sort of result which I believe the Vietnam veterans are looking for.

I think it is quite specious of both the Government and the Opposition to attempt to distort this motion by way of amendment, to make the matter very bland and to fail to recognise the essential point. The veterans want redress and recognition that in this case they were indeed exposed to a dangerous substance. The value in this lies in the recognition that these substances are hazardous, and that substances such as 2,4,5-T, containing dioxin, should not go into general use in the community just because the Evatt report says that these things are without hazard.

DEBATE.TITLE: PHOSPHATE MINING CORPORATION OF CHRISTMAS ISLAND

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I speak on the financial statements and report of the Phosphate Mining Corporation of Christmas Island for the same reason I gave the other day when I spoke to the report on the rice industry in Australia. I also refer again to the points I made in my maiden speech in relation to a sustainable economy. In the matter of phosphate mining on Christmas Island, we have a very nice example of a resource which has been run almost to extinction and the extraction of which has occasioned very considerable environmental damage. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Phosphate Mining Corporation of Christmas Island is a statutory authority of the Commonwealth Government. I note that the report of the Corporation is made as at 30 June 1986. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the Australia Card Bill 1986 [No. 3] was before the chamber this morning I outlined my view concerning this matter. I attempted to outline my philosophical objection. It previously had been indicated that too often power in our society is being usurped by non-elected cliques to impose on the people their type of social engineering without in any way being responsible or answerable to the people. I indicated how this had occurred particularly in the health portfolio and how the Depo-Provera issue was raised first in this chamber in 1979. Had the Department of Health taken notice of what I said at that time there would not have been the problem in regard to the application of that drug, dangerous as it is, to Aboriginal girls.

SPEECH.PARA: I introduced a Bill in this chamber two years ago to outlaw proposals of certain scientists to undertake destructive non-therapeutic experimentation on human embryos. There are attempts in the Health Department establishment to ensure that this matter of major public policy is not brought to where it belongs and that is before this Parliament. When this Bill was debated in this Parliament, a Senate Select Committee on the Human Embryo Experimentation Bill 1985 was established. When that Senate Select Committee came down with a recommendation that there be a statutory principle banning destructive non-therapeutic experimentation, the self-same members of the health establishment attempted, because of their own ideas about social engineering, to ensure that the Parliament did not have a say.

I have indicated my concern about the establishment of registers of people with genetic disorders and how, if this information found its way on to the identification card, the Australia Card, it could be used in a fashion not dissimilar to the way that the card index of genetic taints was used by the Third Reich in 1934 when many people were brought before secret courts and as a result were sterilised. In this case I have indicated the possibility of those people being required to go through an in-vitro fertilisation program so that their embryos would be DNA probed-not for the purpose of curing the disorder but for the purpose of eliminating those human beings deemed by that non-elected group to be deficient.

What I said some years ago about Depo-Provera was ignored at the time by the health establishment, to their ultimate regret. I sincerely hope that we will not have a similar situation in 10 years time. I hope that the warnings I am now giving on the question of human embryo experimentation-and, indeed, more importantly, what the Senate Select Committee said about it-have been taken note of. Otherwise, this will pose grave problems for the whole of mankind.

As I come from the trade union movement, I had indicated the problem that the ID card would pose for persons seeking jobs. I had indicated the very real possibility of the cash economy flourishing. I indicated also that whilst the Government creates the impression that application for the Australia Card is voluntary, in fact, the Australian people are to be invited to take the Australia Card, but the invitation cannot be declined. Application for the card cannot be voluntary because failure to volunteer carries with it a penalty. The penalty is banishment from the sphere of everyday life. Furthermore, a non-registering citizen risks a $20,000 fine for being unable to present his card upon demand by the Commissioner of Taxation pursuant to his legal responsibilities. The point here is that people will be penalised for not having committed any fraud against the public purse but merely for having failed to register.

In other words, the ID card will be obligatory. It will be a crime not to have a card. In addition, the occasions on which the card must be presented are so numerous and the risks of losing it so great, including a $500 fine for failure to notify loss of the card, that pressure will be put on the citizen to carry the card continually. Thus the Government comes into possession of a unique tool for the exercising of control over the people. A society trained to carry and present a card is one easily disposed to accept incremental expansions of the circumstances in which that card must be used. A people thus anaesthetised to the increase of state intervention into the sphere of private and family life is one highly susceptible to losing altogether its civil and political rights. I support this measure being sent for determination and report by a committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to contribute to this debate on the Australia Card Bill 1986 [No. 3]. In an article in the Australian newspaper a week or two ago the distinguished author Morris West reminded me of the words of Woodrow Wilson:

SPEECH.PARA: Liberty has never come from the government. Liberty has always come from the subjects of it. The history of liberty is the history of resistance. The history of liberty is a history of limitations of governmental power, not the increase of it.

That is my starting point in this debate. My politics are the politics of those on this side of the chamber-to eye suspiciously the growth of government authority over the individual.
