That is why I am a member of the Liberal Party of Australia-to protect the freedoms of the individual against the ever-encroaching authority of government and to promote the concept that the state exists for the benefit of the individual, not that the individual exists for the benefit of the state. So I make no apology for the fact that, when a proposal such as this comes to me-which involves the building by government of a massive databank on the lives of people, the accessing of that information by the bureaucracy, the numbering of people to provide more orderly and effective management of that information and the obligation to produce an identity card as the link to that databank-I shudder. The step from an orderly society to an ordered society is small. But with that step so much is lost-so much, I suggest, that is precious and so much that distinguishes life in Australia from that in so many other places.

I recognise that respect for individual people to err on the side of individual freedom, is inconsistent with the natural tendency of government, and I mean any government. The natural tendency of government is towards order and regulation. At its most benign it is for ease of administration and at its worst it is for control of individuals-always, of course, in the interests of the majority, as represented by the state. With a socialist government the natural tendency is accelerated. If the individual exists for the benefit of the state, control and regulation is more than a necessary evil. It is the means towards achieving an end. This Government is presumably somewhere in between. Certainly, there has been no critical cost-benefit analysis such as one would expect from any party which would put the interests of the individual and his or her right to privacy and respect ahead of the interests of the state. Of course, there was some criticism from those on the other side but they were silenced by the majority, on pain of expulsion. They have sacrificed their individual freedom to the perceived benefit of the majority. That is exactly what is being asked of individual Australians by this legislation.

It is claimed that by sacrificing one's privacy to the databank and accepting the order and control of a national identity system one would benefit because it would strike down the minority who are tax or social security cheats. That is the argument that is put for the personal losses that we as individuals will be called upon to bear. Of course, a Liberal faced with that proposal would do a cost-benefit analysis. Regret- tably, every day we accept greater regulation of our lives to enable society, that is, the relationship in which we exist together, to function more effectively. Every sitting day in these chambers, in every State parliament and in every local government body, through the many and varied methods of administrative direction and regulation, proclamations, et cetera, we accept greater restriction upon our lives. But we do attempt to assess whether the additional burden or loss of that individual freedom is justified by the benefits that follow.

We all want to fight effectively against fraud and tax evasion. But when we sacrifice freedom and accept invasions of privacy to carry out that fight we want to be sure that the sacrifice is worth while. On the evidence so far before us, that is where I respectfully suggest that this Bill fails. The evidence suggests that the Bill will not achieve the claimed objectives. Experience elsewhere is that ID cards basically have proven ineffective in combating major crime. In major crime, as we know, passports can be and are forged. It will be just as easy to forge an identity card. Most taxation is avoided through cash transactions-the black economy. The identity card will not change that.

In regard to social security abuse, the Department of Social Security has admitted that the ID card will be of little help in reducing welfare fraud because most fraud relates to overpayments as opposed to mistaken identity. I think the figure that was given earlier was 61 per cent for overpayments and less than one per cent for mistaken identity. The card will not help in relation to illegal immigrants. When the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs gave evidence to the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card it could point to no benefit from the introduction of the card. So it would seem that the benefits flowing from the introduction of the card, as they are presently before the public, are marginal at best.

On the other side of the ledger, apart from the loss of privacy and individual freedom, one must weigh the cost in terms of dollars. Although the figures are imprecise, they are mind-boggling. It will require some 2,000 new public servants, a cost to government in dollars of more than $1 billion over a 10-year period, a compliance cost to business estimated to be in excess of $2 billion, plus compliance costs to State and local government and massive expenditure on new computers and software. I remind honourable senators of what Dr Blewett, the architect of this card, said to the South Australian Labor Conference in June 1986-

TALK.START.PARA: —You should not need to read it, Robert.
—The more times honourable senators opposite are reminded of this the better, because the basis of Dr Blewett's philosophy on the card has been adopted by his Party. Dr Blewett said:

SPEECH.PARA: Let me say as a socialist that it is the interests of the community that come before the individual right . . . We shouldn't get too hung up as socialists on privacy because privacy, in many ways, is a bourgeois right that is very much associated with the right to private property.

That clearly delineates a political value system so different from that of those of us on this side of the chamber. Even if we discount the importance of individual freedom, as it is discounted by Dr Blewett, it is still difficult in any objective assessment to get the scales to fall down on the side of the card. We are conscious that once the card is entrenched and over 2,000 employees are in office and the capital has been expended, the difficulties in abandoning the card will be enormous-not impossible, but enormous. The system becomes dependent on it. We are conscious of the example of Sweden, which has one of the most intrusive ID card systems in the world outside the totalitarian states. When Sweden considered abandoning its ID card in 1976 it found that it would cost too much to dismantle. The moral of this story is: do not rush in.

We on this side of the chamber accept new regulations and restrictions on the individual, as I have indicated, every day. But with this proposal the claimed benefits simply do not stack up against the cost. The Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card could not get the benefits to outweigh the costs. According to the opinion polls, Australians are becoming increasingly sceptical. So they should. The Government says that the legislation it has before the chamber will require substantial amendment but we do not have its proposals. We are asked to pass a Bill which the Government acknowledges to be defective. Almost daily the evidence builds of shortcomings in the security system that is being advocated and of additional cost burdens not earlier taken into account.

In such circumstances the Senate, as the House of review, would be failing in its responsibility if it passed this Bill without further detailed analysis. That is what the amendment moved by Senator Puplick to refer the Bill to a Senate committee is designed to do. The Joint Select Committee did not consider the terms of the Bill. I remind the Senate that it simply considered the concept. This Bill clearly requires detailed analysis, particularly considering its acknowledged deficiencies. The costs to the private sector need to be examined further-that is the least of our responsibilities-as does the capacity of the proposed Data Protection Agency adequately to protect the privacy of the individual in the circumstances of alarming breaches elsewhere that we are now reading about in the media every day.

The penalties need further examination. The appropriateness of fines of up to $500 for failing to report the loss of a card, or up to $20,000 for engaging domestics such as baby-sitters and handymen but failing to obtain their ID card numbers and identifying them personally, raises questions as to whether the penalties are appropriate for the offence. There is no better body to consider that question than the Senate through its committee system.

The evidence is there that the Senate must consider whether or not the updated computer systems, particularly in the Australian Taxation office, are now recovering what this Government claimed needed to be recovered under the ID card itself. There is evidence before us to suggest that the Taxation Office is now recovering what the Government said it had to pass this legislation to recover.

Madam Acting Deputy President, as you know Senate committees have a high reputation for their objectivity, their thoroughness and particularly for their bipartisan approach. The time and the cost of the committee examination will be negligible. It is clear that the Australian community is concerned and wants further serious consideration of this Bill before it becomes part of the Australian way of life and, in fact, changes the Australian way of life forever. It is now being recognised that once freedoms are lost they tend to be irretrievably lost. The facts on the public record at this time demand that the Bill be rejected. I, therefore, strongly support the reference of the Bill to a Senate committee for its further consideration.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise, after a long list of speakers from the Opposition side, to oppose yet again the infamous ID card and to support Senator Puplick's amendment to refer the legislation to a committee. It is significant that of the 37 speakers on the Australia Card Bill 1986 there have been only 10 Labor speakers in this, the third time the legislation has come before the Senate. Where was Senator Cooney, a great upholder of human rights? Where was Senator Bolkus? Where was Senator Childs? Where was Senator McKiernan, who is sitting in this chamber now? The list goes on. They betray themselves by their absence from the debate. They are opposed to this horrific legislation but know that if they adhere to their principles and vote according to them they will be expelled from their own Labor Party. That is what happened to Senator Georges.

SPEECH.PARA: Few senators who were present when Senator Georges made his emotional speech on 10 December were not touched by the supreme sacrifice he was prepared to make because of his beliefs. Senator Georges pointed out that he strongly believed in the rights of the individual to exist without unnecessary bureaucratic interference by the state, that privacy was the right of every individual, that to destroy the privacy of the individual would be to destroy society, and that the ID card would be a licence to exist. That is exactly what this ID card will be. It will be no more or less than a licence to exist. He pointed out that it would become a weapon for social pacification and that when all information was gathered, it would indicate not only a person's financial position but also his social position and his social behaviour.

Those are some of the words of former Senator Georges, and every Labor senator and member who agrees with him should be squirming with shame that he or she did not have the same intestinal fortitude to make a similar stand. Senator McKiernan on the other side should be squirming in his seat right now. I will be very interested to see what Senator Burns does if this matter comes to a vote in a joint sitting. As everyone knows, Senator Georges was the mentor of Senator Burns, from whom we heard some pious words in his maiden speech. What will he do when it comes to the serious vote on the Australia Card?

We in the Liberal Party knew that when we opposed this draconian legislation for the second time, we would be providing an opportunistic Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) with a trigger for a double dissolution, notwithstanding his promises over and over again that he would go his full term. He had broken so many other promises to the Australian people that we ignored this promise as well; so we knew we were running that risk. When the Medicare card was introduced the Government denied that it would lead to a national ID system. So much for that assurance! We felt so strongly about the consequences of this legislation that, despite pragmatic political considerations, we had no option but to oppose it. As honourable senators know, we could well have let the legislation go through and committed ourselves to repealing it on re-election to the Government benches. We decided that we could not do that because of the principles involved-principles which those on the Labor side quite obviously know absolutely nothing about. Senator McKiernan need not blush.

No sensible person supports tax evaders or social security fraud. It has been shown quite clearly by my colleagues that the ID card will not touch the cash or black economy-by far the most extensive form of tax evasion; everybody knows that. It will not touch social security fraud. The Department of Social Security itself has conceded that false names account for only 0.6 per cent of social security fraud. The major means of fraud is false information, and the ID card cannot and will not touch those indulging in that type of fraudulence.

Penalties for misuse of the ID card will be savage. It will be an offence to require someone to produce the card as a means of identification, with a penalty of $5,000, but requests for the card will not attract a penalty. A fine of $500 will be applicable if the card is lost or stolen and not reported within 21 days. Honourable senators may have seen, for instance, in today's Australian Financial Review under the heading `Australian Graffiti', that in the last 12 months over 30,000 Medicare cards were reported lost or stolen. There will be a fine of $20,000 for employing an ironing lady, cleaner or baby-sitter without identifying that person personally and obtaining his or her ID number. There will be a fine of $5,000 or two years imprisonment for making false statements or altering or defacing a card. There will be fines of up to $1,000 for individuals and $5,000 for companies not properly reporting all prescribed transactions of more than $10,000. There will be fines of up to $100,000 for businesses not registering new accounts or for failing to register all existing accounts within two years of the legislation's introduction.

If one reads the legislation, one finds that people will be invited to have a card. Everyone knows that the idea is to call it an Australia Card to appeal to our sense of nationalism, which is a dreadful thing to do. I suppose the card will be green and gold. Recently the Minister responsible for the ID card, Senator Ryan, on a talk-back line, was asked the simple question, `How do you get an ID card?'. We were told that every individual in Australia will have to present himself or herself to a public servant. That is to understate it. She said that there will be a 10-minute interview. We should not have to wait any more than another 10 minutes, and when all the required information is recorded and we have proved who we are-as if we did not know-we will eventually get an ID card.

The simple fact of the matter is that it is not an invitation to have a card; if we do not apply, we cannot exist. It was pointed out to Senator Ryan the other day in Question Time that if a person who did not have an ID card paid a cheque to someone to whom he owed money, that cheque could bounce because a bank will not be able to clear a cheque from a person who does not have the ID card. When we are being paid by somebody for goods or services rendered, we will have to make sure, if we do not want the cheque to bounce, that that person has an ID card recorded with the bank.

Many people representing diverse interests who oppose the ID card have been quoted in this debate. Senator Ryan has been known to call it selective quoting. There is, however, hardly any group in society, irrespective of political persuasion, which does not oppose this card, this numbering system of individuals now called in the legislation not `Australians' but `card subjects'. It sounds like something out of George Orwell's Nineteen Eighty-Four. All of us on this side, and I am sure those on the other side too, have been inundated with letters, votergrams and petitions far in excess of anything else I have encountered during my time in the Senate. There is a revolt in the community, and the Prime Minister and the Minister responsible for the ID card, Senator Ryan, will ignore it at their peril. Public wrath is coming down on ministerial heads, and they deserve it.

My colleagues have quoted people representing every group in society. I would like to quote, even though my colleague Senator Stone mentioned him yesterday, Mr Ewart Smith, who has a singular background. He was, until he recently retired, Deputy Secretary of the Attorney-General's Department and served on the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. He was a most dedicated public servant and he has never been a member of any political party. He stated in his letter to the Australian newspaper of 22 September that if he had an axe to grind it would be the stopping of the fraud of tax and social security cheats. He said:

. . . the time has come to speak out against this evil card. Those of us who served in the Second World War fought for freedom and that freedom must be jealously guarded-and never surrendered. The price of liberty is eternal vigilance and never has our liberty been so threatened as at present.

The 130-page, 189-clause Bill that seeks to enmesh us all on the pretext that it is essential that we be properly identified to prevent tax fraud and social security fraud by a comparatively small proportion of society is an obscenity that must be stopped.

In addition to the arguments that have been cogently put as to the security of the information database, and privacy, I regard the most vital factor as the immense change in the Australian way of life that the card would bring to us all.
There are many ways to attack tax and social security fraud. That is being done presently with outstanding success. All that is needed is more of the same, not the imposition of a card on us all.
Even viewed in the most optimistic light, the card would do absolutely nothing to curtail tax fraud or social security fraud that does not depend on identity, for example, the cash economy.
I have already pointed this out. He continued:
The all-pervasive nature of the card system, apparent from a study of the Bill . . ., will bring needless complication to all our lives and fear and worry to countless citizens (especially migrants)-
including those who came to us from Eastern bloc countries-
while sprinkling offences around like a fish-and-chips proprietor would with the salt.
He went on:
And it would be an administrative nightmare, engulfing more and more public servants to service its growing needs.
There are so many points to make against the legislation, but in the interest of brevity I think it can all be summed up by simply calling the card `the un-Australian Card'.
That is from a man of absolute integrity, a man who devoted his life to the Public Service of this country and who knows the possible effects of what will happen if we allow this card to go through.

Senator Ryan will wind up this debate shortly. It is interesting to note that on both previous occasions on which this Bill was brought into this chamber Senator Ryan did not say a word. In fact, she spoke on the ID card for the first time in the Senate only last week. That scarcely denotes a sound and interested Minister. The handing of this task to her is the action of a Prime Minister who thinks he may know that he is beaten.

I understand that it is expected that this legislation will be referred to a committee. Subsequently, I suppose, if the Prime Minister continues with his madness to get this legislation through, there will be a Joint Sitting. It will be very interesting to see at that Joint Sitting just what those people on the other side, with their high-minded principles, are going to do. Senator Puplick said in his address that the problem with the left wing of the Labor Party is that it has a tendency to be honest. Honest, maybe; but intestinal fortitude, we will see. The legislation will be passed at the Joint Sitting if we assume that all of the little yes men on the Government side vote in favour of it and give the Government a majority of 14.

But having got that far, we find today that there is a distinct possibility that the card itself will be totally and utterly inoperative. Maybe this is the out that the Prime Minister and the members of his Party will take. I do not know whether that will happen; we will see. It came to light today during Question Time that the relevant date as outlined in the Bill will be set by regulation and that regulation must come before this Senate for passing.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could we do it at the Joint Sitting?

—I am pleased to acknowledge Senator McKiernan's interjection because we know that he has principles. He comes from a place where people are most concerned about the infringement of liberties. What would he do if there were such a card in his old country and he could be picked up for the nefarious things that he may have done over there? The honourable senator asked what we will do in respect of the card. Of course, we will continue to oppose it.

SPEECH.PARA: In closing I would just like to reaffirm that I support the amendment moved by Senator Puplick to have the Australian Card Bill referred to a committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have the honour to be the last Opposition speaker in this debate on the ID card. This is the third occasion on which the Senate has debated this issue which has now gained the disapproval of a majority of Australians. The ID card is the most discussed political topic in Australia at the moment. The Opposition is resolutely and totally opposed to the arguments that have been put forward by the Government and to this legislation. My colleague Senator Puplick, who is leading for the Opposition, has moved a comprehensive amendment to refer this legislation to a Senate committee. That inquiry will take up all the matters that are set out in the committee's proposed terms of reference, which cover some 18 or so areas, as well all the matters that have been raised by honourable senators in this debate.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not wish to repeat the speech that I gave on 2 April, the last time the Senate debated this legislation. Following the debate on that occasion, the Senate voted against the legislation. This gave the Government the double dissolution trigger which was the technical foundation for calling the last election. However, I refer the Senate to three of the major points that I made on 2 April. I said that the card would not be cost effective, that it was a gross intrusion on the privacy of individual Australians, and that in its operation or practical form it would not be effective.

I remind the Senate that some seven reasons have emerged from the lips of many people and in thousands of letters and petitions that have been received by senators for opposing this ID card. I have summarised the points made in the letters and petitions that have come to my office and divided them into seven great big heaps. Firstly, it is argued that the ID card will not end tax fraud, that there are cheaper and less intrusive means of dealing with this problem, such as improving the efficiency of the Australian Taxation Office. This has been the subject of various inquiries into the tax area. Secondly, public criticism of this legislation points out that it will not solve the problem of welfare fraud. Even the Government's own Department of Social Security has admitted this in public evidence to the parliamentary inquiry into this matter.

Thirdly, it is argued that the Australia Card will not solve the problem of illegal immigration. The Government has admitted this and has said that the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs will not have access to the card or to the card's number. The fourth group of letters mostly stress that the card will be a gross intrusion into the lives of 16 million individual Australians. Fifthly, it is argued that the data held on the Australia Card Register will not be adequately protected. It will be possible for sensitive personal information to be sold, stolen or inadvertently given out. I will come back to that matter a little later in my remarks.

The sixth group of letters stress the enormously heavy penalties that are attached to offences, even inadvertent offences, related to the card. The legislation before us provides for fines of $500 for just failing to report the loss of the card and fines of $20,000 if an employer does not sight the card and record its number before employing somebody, even on a casual basis. These heavy penalties seem out of kilter and quite unreasonable in comparison with any other legislation or requirement of government. The seventh group of letters to me demonstrates again and again the point that I made in my speech here in April, namely, that the card will not be cost effective. It is for these sorts of reasons that we have all received so many letters from the public encouraging the Opposition to oppose the legislation.
Senator Jenkins, a Western Australian senator, has just reminded me that two hours ago in Perth there was a massive crowd of 20,000 people--

TALK.START.PARA: —Thirty thousand.

—It was in excess of 20,000. I am told that 30,000 people marched from The Esplanade to the State Parliament House in Perth. This was the largest crowd of people demonstrating against a government decision that has been seen in that city for years and years, perhaps since the demonstrations against the Whitlam Government. Bishop Challen, who has been a forthright leader in this debate in the community, was one of the speakers at the rally, as were Liberal and National Party parliamentarians Hassell, MacKinnon, Hendy, Cowan and others. The Premier, Mr Burke, refused to speak to this rally and instead he offered one of his colleagues, a Mr Parker, a Minister in the State Labor Government. However, the crowd did not want to hear Mr Parker. They wanted to hear from the Premier and they rejected overwhelmingly his lack of courage in not facing up to that crowd and giving an account of himself.

SPEECH.PARA: We have yet to see whether the State of Western Australia will co-operate with this legislation in terms of the issuing of records, such as birth certificates and so on. In my own State of South Australia, the Bannon Labor Government has yet to make a commitment to have anything to do with the Australia Card. I understand that is also the case in the Northern Territory and in Tasmania. It seems that a majority of States and Territories in Australia will not co-operate by handing over information on births, deaths and marriages, yet this Government's ID card project seems to rely on that information.

I return to my remarks about the Perth rally. Every kind of person was involved in that march of 30,000 people-young, old, persons variously dressed, students, business people, housewives and even school children who were away from school. They were all demonstrating against an intrusive Government decision that they regard as a blight on individual freedom and their own lives. The ID card is rejected by Australia, it is rejected by the Opposition and it is rejected for all the reasons that have been debated here and put forward by the Opposition.
In the South Australian Parliament, a colleague, the Hon. Diana Laidlaw, moved a motion in the Legislative Council in the following terms:

That this Parliament registers its strong opposition to the introduction of a national identification system incorporating the Australia card and, if the legislation passes the Federal Parliament, calls on the State Government not to co-operate in the establishment of a national identification system incorporating the Australia Card.

I received a letter from Diana Laidlaw this week informing me that the motion was passed without dissent in the Legislative Council of my State Parliament. Obviously it was sponsored by the Liberal Party and supported by the Australian Democrats in that chamber, but there was not one Labor member who was prepared to show any kind of dissent which would have led to a division. We can only record that in the South Australia Legislative Council this motion was adopted without dissent and has been passed on to the House of Assembly.

There have also been rallies against the card in Adelaide. Last Friday there was a very large rally, based on Victoria Square, which was very similar to that which occurred today in Perth. That rally was addressed by John Olsen, the Leader of the Liberal Party in South Australia and a number of other speakers. In the University of New South Wales the biggest student gathering seen for more than a decade occurred to protest against the Australia Card. It was addressed by Peter Garrett and a number of other speakers.

I would like now to note references to costs and savings that Government members have referred to during this debate. The Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett), the Minister responsible for the Australia Card in the other chamber, continues to maintain that there will be $5.4 billion of savings-that is, of gain to Government revenue-arising from the implementation of the ID card over a 10-year period. He notes that the cost of setting up the program in the first year will amount to some $750 million to $1 billion and that there will be a net amount of about $4 billion over a 10-year period. That is the official view that is put forward by the responsible Minister. However, in the debate here Senator Maguire gave a lesser amount when he tried to estimate what this figure would be. Mr Keating gave a very global reference in his Budget speech in which he said that the ID card would return up to $1 billion per annum in revenue. Do we take Dr Blewett's view, Senator Maguire's view or Mr Keating's view-they are all different-as each one of them is only an estimate? Certainly, they are only confined to the initial estimate of cost in setting up the system. We know that there will be 2,000 extra public servants employed and that the cost of setting up the system will be about $1 billion, but the estimate of gains arising from the ID card is in doubt because none of those summaries has tried to take stock of the cost to private enterprise, the banking system, industry and to all employers of the implementation of the ID card's requirements. An official cost impact assessment by an official advisory committee of the Government has estimated that the cost to private enterprise, to industry and to employers in setting up the apparatus for the ID card will be twice as much as the cost to the Government. This is reasonable and no one has argued against the estimation that it will cost $2 billion to private employers and $1 billion to the Government. It is only on the `hope-so', the most favourable estimate, that we are going to see some gains to revenue.

I wish to press on towards the fact that over the past 12 months, while we have been debating this ID card and since the idea was first introduced at the Tax Summit, or shortly before it, as an initiative of the Australian Taxation Office-when it was first proposed to gain about $500 million a year-there have been quite a number of happily achieved reforms within the Tax Office. Those reforms have meant that there has been a greater efficiency in collecting due tax. Some of the estimated amount accruing from this scheme is already to hand. I note that $850 million in additional tax revenue was gained from internal reforms within the Australian Taxation Office, in particular, from more comprehensive auditing activities and a much more systematic and sophisticated computer matching of data supplied by financial institutions and companies on taxpayers' interest and share earnings. This increased by $460m in this year's Budget compared with the previous financial year. Ironically, the revenue gains from the reforms in 1986-87-$460m-were about the same as the amount the Government believed could be recouped by using the ID card. I have already acknowledged that the Treasurer has now doubled his estimate of what the revenue might be to $1 billion a year. In the first stages of this debate it was estimated that we would raise about $500m. That is what the gain has been through the measures that the Tax Office has already undertaken. What slack is left? What tax avoidance will this ID card now uncover which the new, reformed methods of the Australian Taxation Office-methods which do not require legislation but which require the Taxation Office to act more efficiently with the powers it already contains-will not uncover? I can only conclude, as have all Opposition speakers who have referred to costs and savings, that there is the most hazy estimate of any fresh savings that will accrue if this legislation is passed that will not be otherwise gained by the advances in efficiency and prosecution that the Taxation Office is already achieving.

One decidedly new aspect which has emerged in this debate is whether the communication links between the computer systems, the databases, held in the three departments and in the Health Insurance Commission, which is responsible for the ID card, will be secure. In answer to questions in the Senate, Senator Ryan has said that there will be secure landlines, that the links between the computer systems will not be by telephone but by secure landlines. My constituents have expressed many fears and anxieties over the proposed legislation, particularly in this respect. It has been one of the most persistent concerns that the system of security and protection of personal information stored on government computers is not as safe as the Government claims.

In a statement issued on 18 September, Senator Ryan, the Minister responsible for the ID card, made several bold claims relating to the security of the proposed Australia Card computer system. She said that the system would incorporate the very best in security and safeguards. She said that it would be impossible for computer hackers to gain access to the system through the telephone system because information would be conveyed, not by telephone link but along a dedicated network of communications, that is along landlines. Senator Ryan said that information carried along this dedicated network would be encrypted, compressed and segmented. So if any outsider were able to break into the system, he would have no chance of being able to read or make sense of the information.

Senator Ryan did admit, however, that it was theoretically possible to tap information from a transmission line. She claimed that such an effort would have to be extremely sophisticated, very expensive and that it would be detectable. In addition to these claims, Senator Ryan argued that the card register would contain only basic identifying data and that there would be comprehensive safeguards restricting and recording all access to the register. All well and good, one might say, but over the past few months computer and information systems experts have raised a number of matters which place Senator Ryan's assurances in considerable doubt. There are several areas where these experts have raised sufficient doubt to justify sending this legislation to a Senate committee to make a thorough examination and to bring back a report to the Senate. We need to know the cost implications of establishing this heightened security. Already we know that it is a large part of the $1 billion cost of setting up the ID card system.

The technical director of Eracom Pty Ltd, Mr William Caelli, told a recent conference that it is possible to provide a level of security equal to that of banks and finance organisations, but he said that that level of security was `going to cost a lost of money'. Mr Caelli also expressed concern about the Government's track record on the security of existing data stored in Commonwealth departments. He said:

Government systems have been some of the worst offenders when it comes to security. It is only a few years ago that in government computer requirements, security was down on the list at about number six in importance, at best.

He also said that as a result of conversations with government employees, he understood that the Government was falling behind in cryptographic protection of datalines and work stations. The New South Wales branch of the Australian Computer Society set up an investigative group to look at the Australia Card. Its report noted:

The data will be held in centralised databases which will be accessible from all over Australia. It will be almost impossible to ensure network security because even if dedicated lines are used these can be identified and tapped.

In the Australian Capital Territory a senior computer teacher at Erindale College, Mr Alan Brooke, was quoted in the Canberra Times of 7 September as saying that all landlines are vulnerable to tapping as they are all routed through telephone exchanges. He said that had Senator Ryan been taught computer awareness she might have been aware that all cables carrying data, whether spoken or coded, give off electromagnetic emanations and that these also can be tapped. Mr Brooke is also reported as saying:

Senator Ryan might also have been aware that most abuses of such systems are not from outside an organisation but from within and because the Australia Card system is to have some 2,000 terminals, the system overall is going to be a great deal less than totally secure.
I quoted Roger Clarke in my speech in April. He is a computer expert, an academic at the Australian National University, and he also has said that the system will not be sufficiently protected.

In the past fortnight I have been in contact with computer experts who have advised me that there are several points where landlines are not secure and it has been demonstrated that it was possible for individuals to break into the database that was held on the last census in the Australian Bureau of Statistics, and retrieve every item relating to themselves or to friends. They got away with it and it can be done. We have yet to hear whether the Government's claims that this system will be secure will make it more secure than the database in the Australian Bureau of Statistics. I also understand that encryption, compression and segmentation of messages pose no serious problem to those with a good working knowledge of computer systems. It is a fact that all encrypted information can be decrypted. Currently I understand that many companies and other organisations involved in the transfer of sensitive computer information now no longer favour encryption as a security measure.

Senator Ryan also mentioned compression and the breaking up of information as a further security measure. This involves the elimination of gaps and certain unnecessary characters in messages as well as breaking up information into jumbled segments. But every time there is such a change or jumbling, a flag or indicator is inserted to tell the system how to put the information back together again. A determined and competent interceptor has merely to find the flags to be well on the way to restoring the message to its original form. But the dangers from without to the security of the computer system are far surpassed by the dangers from within. The graver risks arise from those personnel who have access to the computer terminals. They are not only those public servants who work with the ID card database. There are technicians-hundreds of them-engineers and training consultants who also will know how to use the system. The problem is that these people will not necessarily be employed by the relevant responsible department. We have yet to hear any kind of detailed argument that gives a credible guarantee that with all these variables and dangers from without and within the database will be secure.

I turn in the remaining few minutes at my disposal to concentrate on some political questions associated with the ID card. One profession by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is that he has a mandate to go ahead with this legislation, despite the fact that his Party did not gain the greatest number of votes either in the House of Representatives or in the Senate, and despite the fact that in this chamber a majority of members are decidedly opposed to it. I note that Senator Ray disagrees with the Prime Minister. He says that he has not got any solid sense of mandate and he does not know what the concept means; all he knows is who has the numbers when there is a joint sitting. I think that is a healthy factual approach to this matter. But whatever any government may claim as a mandate, we have to recognise that the last double dissolution election was based upon this legislation being twice refused and hence providing the trigger for the Prime Minister to advise the Governor-General of the need for a double dissolution.

Does anyone seriously believe that that was the top priority issue in the last election? Certainly the Prime Minister did not claim so. In fact it was the eighth, ninth or tenth priority that was given by all candidates on both sides to this issue, because of other matters that were more directly flowing from who was to gain government after the last election. This only puts into perspective what happened in February 1983, when Malcolm Fraser used a double dissolution trigger-most of us here forget what the issue was, but he had a technical trigger in constitutional terms to call a double dissolution then-as did the present Prime Minister on 5 June of this year. I think there should be no more nonsense claimed by government speakers that there is some mandate.

I expect that after Senator Ryan's summing up remarks in the next few minutes we will proceed to a vote and that a Senate committee inquiry will be established. I thoroughly commend, as have my colleagues in the Opposition, each item in the terms of reference that will guide that committee in its inquiries over the coming months. Vital matters need to be publicised not only in this Parliament but also in the public arena.

It would be very surprising if, after hearing the evidence given to that committee, anyone of my colleagues in the Opposition were to be sufficiently persuaded to adopt this legislation. I cannot think of anyone who would be more led to accept this legislation after the Senate committee inquiry. It is quite possible that when the committee reports, the Senate will meet in February to vote again against the legislation, which will trigger a joint sitting in the House of Representatives chamber. But I ask honourable senators opposite what that will gain, even if there is a majority in favour of the legislation? We already know that it is defective and that it cannot operate without regulations that are yet to be passed. It can then be disallowed by a majority, which we have in the Senate. The public is opposed to the legislation.

I make the prediction now that this Government will lose its nerve and will respond to the overwhelming opposition of the public, expressed here by the Opposition, and that it will pull out. I predict that in April next year this Government will decide that it has heard the message from Australia. I predict that the Hawke Labor Government, impressed by what we have said in the Opposition, will abandon the ID card, and in so doing will serve us all much to the better, and stop this step which we find so totally offensive.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understood that Senator Knowles was going to precede me, but I will press on. The Senate is debating for the third time the Australia Card Bill 1986 [No. 3]. I am not sure exactly how many speakers we have suffered and endured on the three occasions that this Bill has been debated in this place. Quite honestly this debate has gone far beyond what a debate should be, because on many occasions individual senators from the other side-not the new ones-virtually read verbatim from their previous contributions. That has not enthused us and indeed it did not even enthuse the people on the other side who read their previous speeches.
—Are you not Irish?
—No, Senator McGauran, I am Australian and Australians wear green, as the honourable senator can see.
—And I am Irish!

—I certainly do not want to talk like Senator Crichton-Browne. I am proud of my heritage and I hope honourable senators opposite are too. While we are talking about that, I think Senator Parer mentioned that when we do get the Australia Card-if indeed we do get it-it will be printed in green and gold. I hope there will probably be a little bit more green than gold, although I have no aversion to those colours. Senator McGauran, in asking me what my nationality was, reminded me that the colours of the country of my birth are indeed green and gold. They are sometimes referred to as green and orange, but that is a different matter for debate.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I was diverted by the interjections-I am not answering any more interjections at the moment-I mentioned how the debate had deteriorated. Quite honestly, if debates are to be conducted merely be repetition-one person repeating what he or she said in February and that in turn being a repetition of what he said in December-that really does not add a great deal of thought and intellect to a debate on a very crucial and important matter. I do not begrudge the Senate giving this amount of time to this very important issue, which is causing consternation throughout the Australian community. It is also causing consternation among members of the party to which I belong, the Australian Labor Party. Honourable senators opposite may or may not know that there is a degree of opposition by sections of the party to which I belong and work with to the implementation of the Australia Card.

Unfortunately the debate has deteriorated somewhat. I am not only reflecting on what has happened in this chamber over time but I am also reflecting on what has happened in the community. The previous speaker, Senator Teague, mentioned that a great number of letters have been received by senators and members on this issue. Some of the letters that are coming into my office-I can speak only for the letters I have received-I believe are from people with genuine fears about the possibilities of what the Australia Card could be used for by the present Government or by any future government of whatever political colour or calibre. I think that is a very real fear. But mixed up with those letters from genuine, caring and concerned people have been a number of letters which I can describe only as ratbag letters. They begin by taking a religious stance and condemning the Bill as being Stalinist, Nazi and fascist. Obviously we can see that letters like that come from people who have a deep understanding of politics and the various spheres of politics in this country, in countries in Europe and countries in the rest of the world.

Various references have also been made in this debate to the protection of civil rights. Indeed the stance of my friend, the ex-Senator Georges, not the late Senator Georges, on the Australia Card, and his contribution to the debate last December, have been quoted on a number of occasions by people in this chamber. But I think some people have taken that out of context. It was alleged on some occasions that Senator Georges was kicked out of the Australian Labor Party because of his stance. He actually resigned from the Australian Labor Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —He was going to be expelled.
—Well, Senator Short, maybe due to the machinery of the Party, the Party did not get an opportunity to make a decision.
—He would have been expelled.
—Can I pre-empt things, Senator Short? Would Senator Short's party do it?
—No.

—That is the discipline of the Australian Labor Party. Indeed, the Liberal Party of Australia has also been talking in recent weeks and months about its own discipline. One of the reasons why the Liberals lost the last election was their internal faction fighting and their weak leadership-matters within their own party. Their President, John Valder, had quite a number of things to say on that matter. I am not sure how many of the Opposition senators here at the moment actually attend the national meetings of their Party. But that is their problem. They have disciplinary problems as does the Australian Labor Party. We handle it a little better from time to time, and sometimes we make a blue. But that is life as we live it. We have to have some rules and some order of things--
—And settle it with a punch-up?

—I hear Senator McGauran again. It was Senator McGauran who got me somewhat irate this morning when he mentioned Vietnam and the Vietnam veterans parade that is on a week next Saturday in Sydney. It was not the Australian Labor Party that deprived young Australian of their lives by sending them, at the mere drop of a marble, to that place to fight in a hopeless, useless war. It is unfortunate that the issue has been brought into a debate such as this. I think the Australia Card is much too important for the debate to be used simply to score points using a matter which is very important to those people who have been to Vietnam, who lost friends there and who came back. I think this matter is above politics and perhaps in a little time, after Senator McGauran has had the rough edges knocked off him, he will not use this issue in that way. I do not think that it was offensive in the sense that one ought to ask him outside to settle things. But I think it was perhaps ill-considered just at this particular point in time, because memories will be going back in these 10 days or so leading up to Saturday week when those people celebrate their return and remember the people that they left behind.

SPEECH.PARA: We have heard a fair amount of talk about civil liberties. Many people around Australia listening to the debate would think that honourable senators opposite, in particular, had some concern about civil liberties. In Australia the deprivation of civil liberties is not unknown, and it is something that must be addressed in talking about the Australia Card. But we can look back in recent history and ask: Where were the people who are standing up now talking about deprivation and loss of civil liberties during the Vietnam moratorium marches? Where was their political party at that particular point in time?

TALK.START.PARA: —I will tell you where I was.

—And who was the Minister responsible for sending them over? I know we all make mistakes in our lives from day to day and week to week. But I think a travesty was made when we sent our people over there and deprived those people of their civil liberties.
—I was supporting the Vietnam veterans.
—I thank Senator Walters. I accept what she says and I recognise her contribution.
—I was marching in an anti-moratorium march under the Australian flag supporting our troops where they were, and I still support them.

—The honourable senator still supports the Australian involvement in that awful war. Never mind; let us move on and continue with the Australia Card. Just eight years ago in Western Australia an infamous section of the Police Act known as section 54b was used. That Act deprived individuals of the right to gather in groups of more than three people to meet and discuss a matter of common purpose. The Act was not established by a Labor government, a socialist government or a neo-fascist government. It was not done by us. But it was used against the trade union movement. It was used to arrest and hold people because they had the audacity to stand up and defend their rights on things. Where were the great civil libertarians who are now protesting about the Australia Card and defending civil liberties? Where were they in 1979 when that occurred? Where were the people who are now defending civil liberties in respect of the Australia Card when there were demonstrations against the ban on marches in Queensland? That is not so many years ago.

SPEECH.PARA: Probably one of the greatest civil liberties we have is the right to vote-and the right of one vote one value. I challenge the civil libertarians on the other side of the chamber and out there in the community-including those who stand on the stages addressing demonstrations-to open their mouths and say something about the gerrymander that exists now in the state of Queensland.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have done that, Senator.
—I recognise that. I thank Senator Jenkins for it and I wish her well in continuing to do it.

—Why don't you complain about the fact that each State has equal representation in the Senate despite their populations? Why don't you complain about Tasmania having the same number of senators as New South Wales?
—Don't you dare.
—Order! There are too many interjections on my left.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I suggest that Senator Walters and Senator Crichton-Browne sort that out themselves by leaving the chamber and discussing it outside-or perhaps we could deal with it on another day.

SPEECH.PARA: A lot has also been said about the mandate that the Hawke Labor Government got out of the last election. Like Senator Robert Ray-I refer to his excellent contribution here this morning-I have some difficulties with what `mandate' means. I have been disillusioned by some of the acts of the previous Hawke Labor Government in respect of promises that were made when going to the polls and the Government, including myself, carrying out those promises. We had a mandate and a commitment to do things; we should have done them. But some things we did not do and some things we did differently. I am a bit confused about what a mandate is. It has been argued that because we did not get more than 50 per cent of the vote in the last election, we do not have a mandate for the Australia Card. I do know, however, that, as far as I was concerned, the Australia Card was an election matter in the last Federal election campaign over the days and weeks leading up to 11 July. It was raised with me at meetings and through personal representations by people, and I could do nothing other than to repeat the Party's policies on the Australia Card. The matter was discussed in the election campaign. It was the subject of the first advertisement the Labor Party published following the dissolution of the Parliament and the calling of the election. It was a full-page advertisement placed in all of the major daily newspapers around Australia. That is not to say that it was the only issue that would be discussed throughout the whole of the election campaign, and it is not to say that that is the only thing we have to take action on in the life of this Hawke Labor Government. But, if a mandate means that the issue was raised in a campaign, we have a mandate to implement the Australia Card in whatever form because we did raise it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish!

—Senator Walters, in her contribution to the debate-I think it was on Monday, or probably Tuesday-mentioned that she had made a number of attempts to get the matter of the Australia Card raised with the media. She said that she got a number of knockbacks in trying to get the Australia Card discussed. I do not dispute that that happened. But it did not become the central issue of the election campaign. What really became the issue in the election campaign was the question of numeracy-or to put it simply, for those of us who did not have the benefit of a university education, adding up. A great number of figures were put out during the campaign, and a lot of promises were made that just did not add up. A strange issue, which I have still not worked out, involves an admission made by the Leader of the Liberal Party that his figures were wrong in the middle, but the end result was said to be still the same. I still have not been able to come to grips with that one. But maybe I am of a superior intellect, having being born in Ireland. I do not know that some of the things that made the headlines in the election campaign were what seemed to be a continual spate of Press releases emanating from the Opposition leadership saying that its Press releases were not being used. I thought at the time, `Isn't this funny'. If the Opposition can put out Press releases that say that its Press releases are not being used, what are they putting Press releases out about? The Opposition was getting coverage. It may have been negative coverage, but it was coverage. I think that the honourable senators opposite, including Senator Puplick who is with us in the chamber at the moment, ought to examine their methods of electioneering when they front the next general election-whenever that will be.
—That is a good idea.

—I thank the honourable senator. The one thing it would do would be to provide us with a little bit of a challenge. Although it was a long and hard campaign, it was perhaps a little too easy. When things come too easy, one tends to take things for granted. We should really be challenged for the position we hold. We should be challenged as a Party and offered some resistance. In that regard I am very pleased to see that Senator Puplick is here and sitting on the front bench opposite. He is one of those people who were left to flounder on the back benches. It is the sartorial elegance that I really admire rather than the intellectual wit. I hope the honourable senator uses those bits of paper--
—Don't forget the glasses.

—The glasses are another thing. Another point I wish to raise before I conclude relates to the National Party of Australia. I think all National Party senators have spoken in this debate. Some have spoken better than others. They and their Party are in opposition to the Australia Card. They probably are in opposition today, but were they in opposition when Charles Blunt made his statement in support of an Australia Card? Were they in opposition to an Australia Card when Ray Braithwaite, one of their senior members, made his statements in support of an Australia Card? I really do not know the answers to those questions. That is the difficulty of a debate on this highly emotional and most important question.

SPEECH.PARA: The introduction of an Australia Card deserves more than we have been treated to in the last weeks and months in this chamber, in the other place and in the community. It is too important a subject matter to be left to the ratbag elements of our society which are out there. I hope that all parties in this House agree that there are certain ratbag elements in society who seek to grab a platform which in not necessarily theirs. But because it is there they seek to jump on the platform to make it theirs. The implementation of a national identity system is deserving of more than that. It is also deserving of more than what we have had in this chamber in the last few days in the repetitious speeches. There have been a number of good contributions from the other side of the chamber. I will not mention any names or select any people because I might get labelled. If one gets labelled one might have problems in advancement. I may even lose my whip. I think this is the appropriate time to conclude my contribution.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I find this debate quite amazing because it was meant to finish after your contribution, Mr Acting Deputy President. But after the contribution from one of my colleagues this morning, Senator Tambling, who highlighted to the Parliament that the members of the left wing of the Australian Labor Party have been very sparse with their contributions to the debate, they have all sprung to life. I believe that there will now be a succession of left wingers who will speak. But what they are going to speak about, we are not too sure. My friend Senator McKiernan had a wonderful time talking about the Vietnam war but spoke little about the Australia Card Bill 1986 [No. 3] that is before us.
—Which way will he vote?

—That is a very good question. I know the way he would like to vote and that is against the card, but the way in which he is entitled to vote without risking expulsion from the Party, of course, will ensure that he fronts up on that side of the chamber. This is the third time that this Australia Card Bill has come before the Senate. The evidence against it is stronger than it has ever been. We continually hear smug defiance from the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) downwards that the ALP Government has a popular mandate for this Bill. Even Senator McKiernan, who spoke before me, spoke about the mandate for this Bill. Whatever legal rights honourable senators opposite may have, it is a farce to claim, in defiance of all the evidence, that the people of Australia now support the ID card. It is all very well for the Government to say that it ran the first advertisements on the ID card. That is right, but it also happened to be its last because it found out that it was a sheer and utter disaster. More and more people were finding out about the ID card.

SPEECH.PARA: As public criticism has mounted against this proposal, those groups opposing it have been called the ratbag elements of society. Senator McKiernan mentioned the ratbag elements of society. We all get called many names in this chamber from time to time, but it is a great tragedy that people outside this Parliament-decent, honest citizens of Australia-are being called ratbag elements of society simply because they want to preserve the freedoms and the liberties that they have grown to accept in a wonderful country such as this. Equally, it is a farce to claim that the action of the Australian people last July in returning the Hawke Government constituted an endorsement of this Bill, a Bill that the Government is so anxious to conceal from the public that it prevented at one stage the printing and distribution of any further copies of it. No one in this country could get a copy of this Bill for three or four weeks. That is a disgrace because it is the right of every Australian citizen to have access to any piece of legislation that is going through the Parliament. But this was not so. The printing of this Bill was stopped. Some speakers on the Government side have mentioned that there are people from our side of the Parliament who were originally in favour of such a proposition. It happens to be a matter of record that some of those people originally said that a system that was supposedly going to catch welfare frauds and tax cheats, and people of that kind, would be a good idea. I add that that was well and truly before the colour of the legislation was seen and any detail of the Bill was put down. It is a matter of record that the Liberal Party of Australia has consistently warned of the dangers of the national identification system and opposed this Bill once it saw it; even when the public opinion polls suggested that this was an electorally unpopular course. In our election campaign we stated that we would examine the possibility of giving the electors the right to veto Bills carried by this Parliament.

The Australia Card, cutting across some traditional political allegiances and threatening to overturn the whole basis of the citizen's relationship with the state, is a prime example of where such a course would be appropriate. As I have said, this much vaunted mandate looks even thinner when we remember that in the Senate 712,000 more Australians voted for parties and candidates who opposed the ID card than voted for the Government. In Western Australian seven out of the 12 elected senators stand opposed to the Australia Card. Some of the voters who elected them would have cast only a preferred vote for the ALP in the House of Representatives. Under what logic can such voters be claimed as having given the ID card a mandate at the ballot box? It was interesting that last night even Senator Beahan, responding to an interjection from Senator Short, said:

If the honourable senator can separate the issues in any election and say, `For that, you have a mandate, for that you haven't; for this you have, and for that you haven't', he is a better man than I am.

He even admits that he cannot declare that the Government has a mandate. But he rabbited on incessantly about hysterical arguments that were being put against the card. It is a great shame that Government senators are calling people hysterical, irrational and all the other adjectives that they can think of, purely and simply because their opinions do not agree with those of Government senators.

The actions of this Government throughout the saga of the ID card have been less than straightforward. Despite admitted reservations about the protection of civil liberties, no amendments have been made. Why is that so? Last December we saw several ALP senators, including Senator McKiernan, express the need for the Bill to be amended before it was reintroduced. On 6 February, the then Minister for Health, now the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett), was reported in the Press as saying that amendments would be made, clarifying safeguards, and that account would be taken of legitimate suggestions.

What do we have now? Many honourable senators in this chamber have said that the legislation should be amended. The Minister for Community Services and Health has said that it should be amended. The Special Minister of State, Senator Ryan, has said that it should be amended. The Prime Minister has said that it should be amended. Barrie Unsworth, the Premier of New South Wales, has said that it should be amended. Yet the Bill comes back into the Senate in exactly the same form in which it has been presented on two previous occasions. But, oh no, it is all right to bring it back because Senator Ryan, the Prime Minister and non-medical Dr Blewett have all admitted that they will amend it after it has been passed by the Parliament. That too is absolutely and utterly improper. If amendments are to be made, those amendments should be presented to the Parliament. This Parliament has the right to see the colour of any amendments before making any decision-not that we would ever give in to a numbering system that last night Senator Beahan could not even see was some form of dog-tagging or tattooing. Sadly, like all the Government speakers-there have been very few of them, I might add-he was completely unable to mount any campaign in support of the ID card. All Government senators have done is stand up and abuse anybody who dares to oppose it. That tells the story in itself.

No matter how often the Special Minister of State and other spokesmen stress that the card is limited and pragmatic, we recall the statement of the Minister for Health in July of last year that socialists should not be too concerned as to individual rights or the bourgeois right of privacy so closely associated with private property. I am sure that non-medical Dr Blewett's remarks have caused the Labor Party great embarrassment, as have many of the other remarks by Labor Party members on this issue. Some of them have the courage to say that they do not believe in some thing. But the tragedy is that they do not have the courage to go out and oppose it.

There is one other thing that I want to raise in this debate, and that is the cost to business. The cost to business of complying with the ID card may be as high as $10 billion over the next 10 years. I will tell honourable senators how I have come to that figure. The Government's own Business Regulation Review Unit has determined that new red tape generally costs business 10 times the cost incurred by the Government. The Government has already estimated that the ID card will cost as much as $1 billion over the next 10 years. Therefore, that means that the cost to business of compliance could be as high as $10 billion. I do not think that businesses deserve that type of imposition. They have had quite enough from this Government in years gone by; every imposition of a taxation nature that could possibly be contemplated has been thrown at the business community. It is about time that the Government gave business the opportunity to be productive, to create more employment and to be buoyant at a time when this country should be going forwards instead of backwards.

Of course, many lies have been spread around about the Australia Card by the proponents of it. One of them is that it is the only way to stop tax and welfare cheats. That is absolutely, blatantly untrue. The Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card found that it would not stop the tax cheating, it would not stop welfare fraud, it would not stop illegal immigration and that it would in fact be a boon to crime, the cash economy and everything else that is wrong in our society.

Last night Senator Beahan said that the Joint Select Committee agreed on everything. He said that it agreed that there was tax evasion, that there was welfare fraud and that there was a lack of a proper process of identification. He went on with a whole lot of other things about which the Committee agreed. The one thing that he did not say was that the Committee agreed that an ID card would not work. That was in the majority report. The question that many of us have been asking the Government for so long and to which we cannot get an answer is why the Government chose to adopt the minority report from the Joint Select Committee in preference to the majority report. The saga goes on and on.

The next lie that we hear is that if one has nothing to hide, one has nothing to fear. We will have a lot to fear once everything about us is put into a centralised computer base. People have the naivety to believe that hackers will not get into computer terminals. They should go and talk to the 15-year-old computer whizz-kids and see how quickly they can get into computer terminals. They should see how easy it is for anyone who has any sophisticated knowledge of computers to get into the terminals and have access, in this case to the most private of information.

It is an absolute fallacy to say that only one's name, birth date, address and photograph will be on it. Why, if that is the case, must it be produced for everything that one does? I still think it is a great untruth for the Government to say that we do not have to carry the card with us. That is all very well if we do not want to do anything. But we simply have to carry the card with us if we want to have a bank account, if we want to have any shares and if we want to buy any property. The list goes on and on.

Of course, one of the most outrageous lies of all in this debate right from the word go is that it is only another piece of plastic like one's Bankcard, MasterCard, library card or whatever. Nobody in his right mind would ever buy that story. One's MasterCard, Bankcard, library card or driver's licence-all admittedly with numbers on them-do not carry the same number which goes into the same computer terminal to which all those organisations have access. We are constantly told not to worry because the ID card will be the same as those other cards. Of course, we are also told that many other countries have an ID card, so it must be all right. But no other country has a card similar to that being proposed by this Hawke socialist Government. I am sure that people will start to understand-as they have already indicated, given the rising numbers in opinion polls-that that is just not so. No other country has such an ID card. Even a country such as the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics does not have a card similar to this.

We are also told that the Australia Card cannot be forged. As I have said in previous debates on this legislation, that is absolute 100 per cent rot. Only last year we heard of a prison in New South Wales that was a one-stop shop for every piece of forged material one could wish for. If one wanted a new birth certificate, death certificate, marriage certificate, drivers licence, passport-or even if one wanted a bit of money-one could just go to the one prison, which was a one-stop shop. The Government is saying to us that that will not be the case with an ID card. The intrinsic value of the card will make it worth forging. A nice little business will be set up on it-make no mistake about it.

The Government shows little originality in its current attempts to justify this Bill. We are treated to variations on the theme that, as I said before, honest people have nothing to hide, forgetting that most honest people have nothing to hide from the police but would object in the strongest possible terms to police raids on their homes without a warrant. We are also told from time to time that the social security cards in Canada and the United States are similar to the Australia Card. That is not so. Whereas it will be quite impossible to function in society without an ID card, the Bill gives no absolute guarantee that we will get one. Clause 16 of the Bill requires the Authority to explain its reasons for refusal of an application for the card but does not mention any right of appeal. Clause 20 of the Bill allows for regulations governing the issue of replacement cards, but says nothing as to any time limit by which a card must be issued. While a business person could be seriously inconvenienced by delays in replacing a lost ID card, a pensioner could easily delay reporting a loss and thus incur a $500 fine under section 179 for failing to make a report within 21 days. Let us be honest about this. If people lose something they do not know when they lost it. Who is going to decide whether it is 21 or 22 days since the card was lost? The whole proposition is absolutely and utterly outrageous. The list of penalties under this Bill goes on and on.

In Western Australia we have just seen the ALP Premier, who strongly supports the Australia Card, reveal the private financial dealings of a citizen whose single offence is to be the State President of the Liberal Party. How useful will a central databank be to people such as Premier Burke? He did not give two hoots about the privacy of someone's financial dealings but just blew them out of the water in the middle of the Parliament.

The inconvenience to individuals is another thing. The level of inconvenience imposed by this card is an infringement of all civil liberties in itself. Let me run through a list of inconveniences that will be attached to this card. The card must be produced when dealing with banks and financial institutions, initiating investments, instigating transactions with trusts or cash management funds, for primary producers transactions involving stock agents and marketing authorities, for foreign remittances, for land transactions, to use safety deposit boxes, for investment in share and public companies, for transactions relating to futures contracts, for employment-starting a new job an so forth-for transactions under the prescribed payments system, when required by the Australian Taxation Office, in claims for cash Medicare benefits, for admission to hospital and for dealings with social security departments, and the list goes on. To cap it off, the penalty for non-compliance is between $20,000 and $100,000. So beware! That is the catch.

The card will bring the greatest intrusion into individual privacy ever contemplated by any government in Australia's history. I do not think that is anything of which this Government or this Parliament could be proud. We must fight and continue to fight as hard as we possibly can to make sure that the legislation is rejected.

The number of petitions that have been flood-ing into both Houses of this Parliament has been absolutely unprecedented. The people who have approached me personally to present petitions-which number over 23,000 signatures, and there are many more to come-are not what the Government calls the ratbags of this society. They are genuinely concerned citizens who have vigorously gone out and asked the Australian public to make sure that they are aware of what this legislation contains. No one has been forced to sign a petition but I believe that the number of signatures on petitions coming into the Senate alone is fast approaching 100,000, if it has not already passed that number. It is very sad that these people are being called the ratbags of our society.

Access to the Register will be limited to one inspection a year, a qualified right to say the least, as false information may have been added and then deleted over the previous eleven months. How do we know about it? Evidently, one can pay to have another peek at what should be one's right to see without having to pay. But the citizen has no right to sue the Authority for wrongful data that may have resulted in embarrassment or monetary loss. Should we try to gain access to the Register in addition to our one free look, we will encounter the barriers so carefully constructed to deter queries under the Freedom of Information Act last year. A person on a low wage, or relying on social security for that matter, might hesitate to run the gauntlet of the $30 application fee, the $15 an hour search fee and the $20 an hour decision making fee. Yet the Government says that we can have a peek at what is our right to peek at at any time. That is not so. One can do it only once a year or one has to pay for it. More and more we are getting from this Government the attitude: `If you want something, pay for it'. That is reasonable if it does not concern one's own privacy. One's privacy and a check on one's privacy should not be charged for.

Whilst this legislation poses great dangers to honest Australians from computer error to the compiling of secret dossiers, it fails to provide proper safeguards against dishonesty. People could put information into the computer about which one does not know and which one is unlikely to find out about in many cases. Australians simply do not want a national ID system that puts them at the mercy of computer error, inquisitive social engineers and closet authoritarians within the government system. They do not want to live so many steps further towards a controlled society. They have a healthy gut feeling that being reduced to `card subjects', as this legislation calls them-not people; not Australian citizens-by the government they elected is a big departure from the Australia we have all known.

Australians are reserved people who cherish privacy. The Minister for Community Services and Health was never so wrong as when he implied that only the affluent care about privacy because it allows them to protect property. History teaches that privacy and private property are guarantees of the liberty of all people against the threat of the collectivist, all powerful state.
