History also teaches that those with less property have a greater need for privacy to sustain their essential dignity against the social planners who always seem to find the poor easier to get at. They deserve better than a number from the cradle to the grave. We must fight this ID card right to the end.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —At Question Time in this chamber today certain questions were asked by Senator John Stone and then by Senator Fred Chaney. They were launched on a rather unsuspecting chamber, and, when completely understood in their ramifications, they can have a very profound effect on the constitutional arrangements of this nation and on the very deliberations normally undertaken by this chamber. I want to make it very clear that as far as the Government is concerned the implications behind those seemingly innocuous questions are so profound that we will require from the Senate chamber an indication that what was suggested in those questions does not, in fact, meet with the concurrence and approval of a majority of senators in this place. For that reason I wish to move an amendment to Senator Powell's proposed amendment No. (1) to Senator Puplick's amendment. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of words proposed to be inserted, add:

`but the Senate affirms that it will, consequent upon the passage of the Australia Card Bill at a joint sitting of the Houses, secure the effective operation of the legislation by not disallowing regulations made pursuant to sub-section 32 (1) providing for the `first relevant day' and the `second relevant day','.

Some members of the Opposition have signalled an intention to frustrate the implementation of the will of the Parliament as it would emerge from a joint sitting of the elected representatives of the Australian people assembled together rather than in their separate chambers, as is provided under the Constitution. If that joint sitting should pass the legislation, it would be an expression of the will of the people of Australia, as mediated by their elected representatives assembled in that joint sitting, that that legislation be part of the law of Australia.

The Opposition seems to be signalling the intention to frustrate the clear intention of the Constitution, provided for under section 57, that the will of the Parliament be carried into practical effect. It would be a nonsense, of course, simply to pass legislation which had no particular effect.

As far as section 57 is concerned, we know that the visit to the Governor-General at Yarralumla on 5 June was undertaken to secure a double dissolution in order that the processes could be put into play for an election which, having been held, would allow the convening of a joint sitting so that the majority of the elected representatives of the Australian people, in the assembly of that joint sitting, could pass this legislation. To attempt, as certain segments of the Opposition are indicating they will, to frustrate the carrying through into practical effect of the legislation passed by that joint sitting would be to undo, I believe, the whole constitutional process properly provided for in section 57.

I put it very seriously to those in this chamber, as senators, that it is not only the constitutional dimension which I believe ought to be considered. The fact is that the traditional surveillance and supervision quite properly undertaken by this chamber of the whole regulation-making process undertaken by the Executive is being put in peril. We have in this chamber, having had the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances in operation for many decades and having set up the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills only four or five years ago, an acceptance, concurred in by governments of all political persuasions, that regulations ought to be made with great care and that this chamber ought to be able to disallow them, particularly if they interfere with the civil liberties of the citizens of Australia or in some way constitute an abuse of the regulation-making power. The Scrutiny of Bills Committee has examined this legislation twice. On both occasions that Committee, using the criteria set down by this chamber which would justify the disallowance of a regulation, has made no comment whatsoever on the regulation-making power that we are discussing. That Committee, comprising as it does senators from all political parties, has seen in the regulation-making power provided for in the Australia Card Bill a very ordinary exercise of Executive power to implement legislation which obviously expresses the will of the elected representatives of the Australian people.

This move by the Opposition will lead to a situation in which no government can safely issue drafting instructions to have within the body of any piece of legislation a simple, common form regulation-making power designed to carry that legislation into practical effect. We will have to try to do this by some form of Executive action falling short of regulation-making. That will lead to an impasse because, obviously, the Scrutiny of Bills Committee will say, `This is not on'. The fact of the matter is that no government of either persuasion-this Government while it remained in office or, God forbid, those on the other side if they ever came to government-would be able safely to put in its legislation a regulation-making power which simply, ordinarily and in common form provided for the implementation, the carrying into practical effect, of the will of the people as expressed in the main body of legislation. There is nothing in this regulation-making power which has raised any question whatsoever in the minds of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee, comprising, as I said, members of all political parties from all parts of the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a policy dis- agreement.

—We then come, as Senator Macklin says, to the crux of the matter: this is a simple policy disagreement. It is simply a question of bare political vandalism undermining what will be in effect the will expressed at a parliamentary joint sitting, of the elected representatives of the Australian people.

SPEECH.PARA: There are those on the other side of the chamber who themselves have been in government from time to time. They should recognise the very serious implications to which I am pointing for the passage of many ordinary Bills, many ordinary parts of the legislative process-many dozens of Bills that pass through this chamber year in, year out. But it is the political mind that is revealed in relation to the constitutional process on which we are embarked which I think requires more particular attention.

The Leader of the Opposition, Mr John Howard, who has very kindly come to listen to me and perhaps, sitting in the gallery, to be persuaded, said in the other place that the Liberal and National parties in the Senate would reject any new Bill designed to repair this defect-if, indeed, it is a defect. But, more importantly, he said that when the necessary regulations were made, they would move to disallow them in the Senate. This reveals the utter bad faith of the Opposition parties in sending this Bill to a committee of the Senate. It is quite clearly revealed in that statement of intention by the Leader of the Opposition, concurred in no doubt by the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Sinclair) in the other place-and certainly concurred in by the Leader of the National Party in the Senate (Senator Stone) and the Leader of the Liberal Party of Australia in the Senate (Senator Chaney)-that the committee process upon which we are about to vote is to be an absolute sham, an absolute farce of no substance whatsoever. At the end of the day, what is to be undertaken in that committee process is not deliberation on this Bill, not the ordinary legislative, mature, calm consideration of this legislation, but a process of sheer frustration in order to stave off the evil day when the constitutionally appointed processes initiated by the Governor-General on 5 June and concurred in by the Australian people on 11 July have their natural fruition in the joint sitting passage of this legislation.

The fact is that the sending of this legislation to a committee would not be part of the deliberative processes which are quite properly recognised by the High Court of Australia as being part of what is required for the passage of legislation. What is going on amounts in my view to elements of a failure to pass the legislation. The fact is that the amendment which I have moved to the various amendments proposed in relation to the second reading is required in order that the Government can clarify whether this chamber is prepared to allow the will of the people, as mediated by a majority of their elected representatives, assembled in a joint sitting as provided for under the Constitution, to be implemented in practical effect.

If it is the intention of those opposite, as has been signalled, simply to frustrate that will, the defeat of this motion will clearly indicate that the sending of this Bill to a committee of the Senate is an absolute sham, an absolute farce and part of the frustration of this legislation-part of putting off the evil day, as they see it, of the Joint Sitting and having nothing to do with the ordinary deliberative processes which this chamber normally proudly undertakes in the sittings of its select and standing committees. I believe that it is essential that the chamber pass the amendment I have proposed in order that the will of the people be carried into practical effect.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Aulich and Senator Collins, in the course of their remarks, were kind enough to refer to me as Shakespearian. Let me say in the best of Shakespearian moulds that right at the moment members of the Opposition come to bury Blewett, not to praise him. This card will now be buried. It will be buried comprehensively and we will see an end to this attempt to deceive the people of Australia about the Government's intentions.

SPEECH.PARA: What Senator Tate had to say to the chamber this afternoon is most interesting. He said three or four things of great importance. Firstly, he said that this Parliament and, indeed, if necessary, a joint sitting of this Parliament, should pass a piece of legislation which again it has been admitted is defective. He told us that the attitude of the Australian Labor Party towards this chamber, towards this Parliament, is simply this: Caucus has decided and, therefore, the will of the people expressed in this chamber as much as in any other part of the Parliament should be set to one side. We are to be required to betray the oath which we take to pass legislation which is in the interest of the people of Australia. We are to set that to one side and pass defective and bodgie legislation in order to get the Government off the hook-the hook of its own making, of its own sloppy draftsmanship. All of the committees and all of the little bureaucrats in the Attorney-General's Department and elsewhere who thought they were on Easy Street with the passage of this legislation will have to think again.

The second thing Senator Tate said is that in exercising the proper control which this Senate has over delegated legislation it should prefer at all times the will of the Executive to the will of the chamber. It has to be remembered that people sit in this chamber only because they have been elected to this place by the people of the States and the Territories of the Commonwealth of Australia. As far as frustrating the will of the people type of argument is concerned, let me remind Senator Tate what Senator Robert Ray had to say the other day about mandate theory. Finally, Senator Tate said that to proceed with the reference to a committee would somehow constitute a sham and a fraud. All we say in response to that is quite simply this: here is a piece of legislation which is worthy of examination. Presumably, if the Government's case is strong enough the committee will be persuaded to come back and tell everybody that we should pass the legislation. If, of course, the Labor Party is honest about wanting to improve the legislation, it undoubtedly will participate in the work of the committee. Undoubtedly it will be persuaded by the evidence which can be put on the record before the committee.

I want to indicate very briefly the response that the Opposition parties-the Liberal and National parties-will make to the Australian Democrat amendments. I will do so now rather than rising again to indicate what that response is. I indicate that we will support the reference of the Australia Card Bill to the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs. I indicate that we will support the Democrats' amendment to paragraphs (f) and (j) of our terms of reference. Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I move:

``(ia) examine the issues raised regarding the physical security of dedicated landlines and other data transmission facilities involved in the Australia Card programme.''

``(l) examine and, where appropriate, take evidence from overseas experts as to the experience of other countries with identity card systems; and''.

I conclude by indicating the extent to which, in an unreserved and unapologetic fashion, the Opposition regards this as a day of triumph. We regard this as the culmination of a campaign which we have individually and collectively waged since the Australia Card legislation was first mooted. We have said throughout that we would take all proper, legitimate parliamentary avenues open to us to defeat this legislation. We will do so with a great deal of pride. The only people who will be seen smiling more broadly than members of the Opposition are members of the left wing faction of the Labor Party, who are equally delighted to see the defeat of this card. One can see the smiles on all their faces. Once can see quite clearly the extent to which they are pleased that the Liberal Party of Australia, the National Party of Australia and the Australian Democrats have allowed the perpetration of a system of social organisation of which they heartily approve. We will not be persuaded by the argument that we should pass defective legislation, that we should be negligent in our duties so far as subordinate legislation is concerned or that we should deny a Senate committee the capacity to look at this matter in a proper fashion. As I said when I opened the debate on the Australia Card legislation last Friday, Senator Ryan has been condemned like Simon of Cyrene to carry the cross for the last few paces. It is a pleasure to announce that she has at last arrived at Calvary.

In the whole course of the debate, from the time the Liberal and National parties discovered that there was something wrong with the legislation, from the time they decided to jump on the Peter Garrett band-wagon, from the very recent discovery that there was something wrong with the legislation, from that very recent time which, of course, post-dated the election campaign during which these points could have been made daily and were not, from that very recent time that they decided that Peter Garrett was getting on television a lot and they wanted to get on the publicity band-wagon, we have accused them of hypocrisy in relation to this issue. SPEECH.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr Deputy President: This is an important debate-
—What is your point of order, Senator Collins?
—This is an important debate.
—I am aware of that. What is your point of order?
—This matter has suddenly become extremely important and I would like to listen to the arguments.

—The ultimate in opportunism and hypocrisy is realised.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There is continued interjection from the Opposition benches. Senator Ryan is entitled to be heard in silence.

—The ultimate in opportunism and hypocrisy is presented in the tactic that has emerged today. What is all this Senate committee business about? What are honest citizens to believe? Citizens will be invited to talk to the committee about civil liberties, computer security or whatever. What is all that about, other than an extended example of grandstanding, an extended opportunity for extravagant grandstanding, if they have made up their minds to use this minor regulatory power to frustrate the program at a late stage?

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition is flying in the face of section 57 of the Constitution. Section 57 specifically provides mechanisms to resolve a deadlock between the two Houses. We have honestly and thoroughly fulfilled all the constitutional requirements for the breaking of a deadlock, as it is our responsibility in government to do. The Senate refused to pass the legislation twice; we went to the people. What could be more open and democratic than that? We went to the people precisely on the second refusal of the Senate to pass this most important measure of tax and welfare system reform. Opposition members remained silent; they gave the electorate no hint of their current stance during that campaign. What happened? Unlike the Opposition, which has all kinds of hidden agendas and which remains silent, hiding under stones on this issue, including Senator Stone--
Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —What did Senator Stone say about the Australia Card during the eight weeks of the election when he was pretending to the people of Queensland that he suddenly had an interest in representing them in the Senate?
—He needed a card to prove he was a Queenslander first.

—I understand he does not even have a Queensland driving licence. —I remind the Senate of the consequences of this trick should it come to fruition. It would simply deny the Australian Government legislation which section 57 of the Constitution entitles it to and deny the people of Australia the opportunity to have fair and decent tax and welfare systems. The Opposition is prepared to call into question the whole of the conventions of the operations of the Senate and the Senate committees, as my colleague Senator Tate, has pointed out. The Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills found nothing wrong with the legislation. Should the regulation that the Opposition now threatens to sabotage go to the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances it would not be recommended for disallowance. Of course it would not.
—How do you know?

—Because there is nothing wrong with it. Senator Vanstone probably does not know what the Senate Regulations and Ordinances Committee does or what criteria it applies to regulations. There would be no way in which the Regulations and Ordinances Committee could reject this. The Opposition is flying in the face of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee and flying in the face in anticipation of the decisions by the Senate Regulations and Ordinances Committee. It is flying in the face of section 57 of the Constitution. It is doing all of this in total contrast to its total silence during the election campaign that was called precisely on this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: John Howard has often been asked by journalists why he did not say anything about this legislation during the election campaign. Members of the Opposition in this place have also been asked that question. They have no answer. I think the answer is that they were not game to raise it because they believed that the Government had a popular measure, which indeed it did. They were then prepared to join in in the greatest campaign of misinformation, of deliberate misleading of the public about the provisions of the legislation and the operation of the system that we have ever witnessed in Australia. And we have witnessed some shocking campaigns of misrepresentation, such as in the Human Rights Bill. This is the greatest period of misinformation, distortions and contradictions that we have ever seen. We have contradictions such as the Australian Democrats saying that we cannot have this system because it numbers people, but on the other hand they want a tax number system. People have been jumping up and down shouting about numbers taking away our freedom, when they are perfectly happy to use their Medicare number, which numbers every Australian citizen, to get their Medicare benefits.

We have heard the most dishonest, contradictory, ludicrous series of claims, but those opposite were not game to carry on with such ludicrous misrepresentation at a time when it might have been proper from their political perspective to do so, during the election campaign. But there was not a peep. John Howard on television many a times a day could easily have raised the matter. He could easily have said, `We are fighting the Government because it is about to introduce the greatest threat to civil liberties the world has ever seen' or `It will return Australia to convict days', which was said in an outstanding contribution from Senator Puplick the last time he spoke on this matter, or `We believe that any system that gives someone a number is tantamount to putting them in a concentration camp'. All the spurious arguments which the Opposition has been confusing the public with lately they were not game to raise in the eight weeks of the election campaign. Opposition members should hang their heads in shame for having been so silent about something on which they have suddenly become so dreadfully noisy. The technical trick with which Opposition senators have decided to threaten the Government and the people of Australia is the worst example of opportunism in a whole sorry saga of hypocrisy, opportunism, distortion and attempts to destroy the intent of the Constitution. I urge honourable senators to support Senator Tate's amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —It will turn it into a farce.

—It will not be a farce; it will be a very important inquiry. It will establish a whole range of issues on the record with regard to the Government's legislation which it will be important to have on the record. SPEECH.PARA: With regard to Senator Tate's observation that somehow it is a piece of vandalism on the part of the Senate to say that it will use its powers to disallow regulations to prevent this legislation, I make it very clear to Senator Ryan, who got mixed up in this exercise, what will happen when the Government goes to its Joint Sitting, as I presume it still intends to do: the legislation will pass; it will be signed by the Governor-General and will become law. The Senate will then exercise its right with regard to regulations made under the Act. It will not be abusing any constitutional power or anything else. It will be using its constitutional power to deny regulations.

The substance of Senator Tate's contribution, which was important, was to draw a distinction between policy items. He maintained a very narrow interpretation of the Constitution-that is, that we knock back regulations in this chamber only when they run against the references given to the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, or the type of references which we give to the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances. That is false. We do knock back other regulations-they are not the majority of those we knock back and I accept that-but there were occasions in the last Parliament as there are in every Parliament when this chamber disallowed regulations on policy items alone.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is right.

—Senator Boswell interjects on this matter because he instigated one of those in relation to the Northern Prawn Fishery management. That might not be an important matter to some honourable senators here, but it is important to Queenslanders. It was knocked back as a policy item alone, and for no other reasons. It was purely a policy disagreement. The Northern Prawn Fishery was saved because the Senate denied that regulation.
—We should have gone to the people on that, should we?

—Senator Aulich should not interject too loudly because that was accepted by his Minister, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin). When the Government is on a sticky wicket it serves up Senator Tate to get it out of trouble. But it will not be able to enforce the legislation because there will be no regulation. We intend to do that-that is on the record. Our vote against the Government's amendment will register in this chamber our firm intention to do that at any time in the future when the Government brings that legislation in.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not wish to canvass the matters that have just been raised, nor to go over the questions that I raised during the second reading debate in expressing my opposition to the Australia Card Bill 1986 [No. 3]. But I wish to address the amendment moved by Senator Tate. There is an additional reason why the Senate should reject that amendment. In my view the amendment is either out of order or very close to being out of order. According to Odgers Australian Senate Practice, the second reading debate is a debate in which the Minister explains the principles and purposes of the Bill. Then, upon the conclusion of the Minister's second reading speech, a member of the Opposition usually moves for the adjournment of the debate. It is interesting that Odgers states:

SPEECH.PARA: The second reading is the most important stage of a Bill. It is then that the principle of the Bill is debated and affirmed, or rejected, as the case may be. But the close examination of all the clauses intended to give effect to the principle of the Bill is left to the Committee stage.

What is this amendment all about? It is all about a clause intended to give effect to the principle of the Bill; and that specifically, according to Odgers, should be dealt with at the committee stage. Therefore, in my view, Senator Tate's amendment is out of order. I am not going to ask the President whether he thinks it is out of order, but I think that is certainly a reason for anybody to vote against Senator Tate's proposal. Therefore, if anybody chooses to vote against it on that basis, they need not necessarily go to the question of constitutional propriety. Not only does Senator Tate's motion deal with a question which ought to be determined in the Committee of the Whole, but it ought to be determined in the committee stage of the Joint Sitting and not in the stage which the principal motion-that is, that the Bill be read a second time-is designed to effect.

I indicate simply that I will be voting against Senator Tate's amendment on the basis that it is not relevant to the question that is before the House and, furthermore, that it anticipates debate, which is also out of order.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. —I was making a point about this most recent episode in the Opposition's attempt to grandstand, to fear-monger and to be opportunistic about this most serious piece of legislation. I think we had about another 15 hours available to debate it in this chamber, following upon the 40 hours or so of debate that the legislation received in its first two passages through both Houses. Instead of choosing, as one might have hoped in order to give some cover of respectability to the Opposition's opportunistic tactics, to address themselves to the principles of the legislation, to explain why it was that they were not prepared to pass a piece of legislation designed to recoup billions of dollars for the Government on behalf of the taxpayers from those people who we all know are engaging in tax evasion on a dramatic scale-a dreadful scale-to recoup money from those people who we know are claiming welfare benefits that they have no entitlement to--
—It is 0.6 of one per cent; less than one per cent.

—If Senator Teague really believes that less than one per cent of social security recipients are engaged in some sort of fraud, he is the only person in Australia who believes that. I do not think that any unfortunate member of the public who might be listening to this travesty that the Opposition parties are foisting upon us would believe that less than one per cent of people currently taking social security payments are not entitled to them. Unfortunately, the fact is that there has arisen in our community in recent years a very distressing willingness on the part of some people in the population to believe that if they can get away with ripping off the system it is okay. There has been a decline in public morality. I do not think that any senator in this place who has read the documentation prepared for the Government's National Taxation Summit or who is familiar with the work of Frank Costigan and his Royal Commission on the activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union-an inquiry into crime, fraud, corruption, and so on-could say anything other than that there has been a dreadful decline in public morality in recent years in Australia, to the point where we just do not have a minor problem of a few people getting a benefit which they are not entitled to, or a few people disguising their taxation responsibilities; we have a massive problem of fraud. We have a massive problem of corruption of the taxation system. We have a problem that goes beyond our own shores.

SPEECH.PARA: Many Opposition senators argued that we have no need in Australia for an identification system. Although democratically elected governments in western Europe, Canada and the United States of America believe that it is necessary to have an identification system-that is self-evident-the Opposition parties said that we do not need that sort of thing in Australia. We do need that. Australia is no longer a country town cut off from what is happening in international corruption, the international drug trade and so on. Australia, tragically, has been drawn into international crime, corruption and the drug trade. There are people in Australia who are making millions of dollars out of the drug trade. They are getting away with it because they are able to conceal that money by having false bank accounts, by buying property in false names, by sending money out of the country in another name. We know that we have a massive problem concerning our taxation system. We know that because of the decline in public morality, a large number of Australians, tragically in my view, believe that it is their right to rip off the system. So we have a massive problem.

TALK.START.PARA: —The majority of Australians are good, decent people. You are a disgrace.
—Senator Walters, will you withdraw that comment please.
—I am sorry, Mr President, I do not understand. I said that the majority of Australians--

—Thank you, Senator Walters.

—It is a very sad thing for the people of Australia who need to rely on their governments to do certain things for them that they cannot do for themselves that we have an Opposition that is totally unwilling to co-operate with a democratically elected government-a government with an historic majority, a government that has just been re-elected by the people-in the very important exercise of bringing to an end the massive corruption of our taxation system and the serious corruption of our welfare system. Those two tasks, one would have hoped, were serious enough to cut across the petty boundaries of party politics, how many times people can get themselves on television and how many petitions they can bring into the place. One would have thought, after all of the evidence that the Australian people and the Parliament have had available to them, with the massive problems we are confronting, that a government-our government-that has gone to enormous pains to find a system to restore decency and integrity to the taxation system, restore a sense of public morality, would be able to say to the young people of Australia: `This is not a country in which we are inviting you to get away with anything you can get away with. This is a country where we want welfare for the genuinely needy. We want a responsible attitude to the payment of taxation'. After all, we are a country that offers a very high standard of living, that offers a sound and relatively generous welfare system to the genuinely needy. We are not a mean country. We are not a country without compassion. We want to offer these things to people but we need a system to stop the corruption, to stop the crime, to stop the rip-offs, to stop the fraud.

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate will remember that we first raised this issue at the Taxation Summit in 1985. There was lengthy debate on these issues. One would have hoped that if there was anything the Opposition could co-operate with the government on, if there was any issue on which it could show that it was not just representatives of the Liberal Party or the National Party but representatives of the Australian people-members of the Australian Parliament-this would have been the issue. TALK.START.PARA: —As I was saying, it is a very sad thing for the Australian people that the Government appears to be unable to get the co-operation of the Opposition parties in the Senate in this immensely important task that we have undertaken. The principles of the Bill are sound. The system set out for ensuring that Australians have a secure identity and that their identities are not forged or defrauded by other people is very sound. The Data Protection Agency provided for in the legislation provides for the first time in Australia real protections for privacy against the misuse of data.

SPEECH.PARA: I cannot conclude this phase of the exercise without pointing out that we brought forward legislation which has the strongest, most progressive provisions for the protection of the individual against the misuse of data held about him or her by government, and to some extent by the private sector, that Australia has ever seen. There has never been protection of this kind before. We brought it in in the context that many supporters of the Bill in the public and in the media had pointed out the immensity of data of the sensitive and private kind held about individuals by the private sector through the operation of credit cards, banks, other lending institutions and the like, for which there is no protection whatsoever.

For the first time we are offering the Australian people strong, firm, secure mechanisms for protection of the very limited data that will be held about them in the Australia Card database. But, for reasons of rank opportunism, Opposition members are not prepared to allow Australians to have this protection. Having set all these hares running about privacy, computers and data and so forth, what are they doing? They are doing nothing. They are saying, `Let the situation prevail where a great deal of sensitive information is kept about individuals in government agencies. We will not let you have the new protection that this Bill will provide'. There is an enormity of information used and misused about individuals in the private sector, but the Opposition says, `We will not worry about that, it is the private sector. Opposition members ignore all the problems they try to point to in their opposition to our legislation and attempt to throw away a major piece of progress in terms of the civil liberties of all Australians.

Senator Richardson is reported in the Australian of 13 September to have said that he would release in two weeks time a plan of the jobs that would be available and the compensation that would be paid, which will have a great bearing on the lives of people in north Queensland. When will he release it? Secondly-this is the most important issue that I want to raise with Senator Richardson-when will the logging be stopped? When will the Minister proclaim north Queensland rainforests free from further logging?

These questions must be answered. The people of north Queensland are living on a knife's edge. I am sure Senator Richardson can appreciate the concern of those who do not have a lot of future there. They are trained foresters who are very proud of their occupation, and they do not want to be reduced to being road workers or tourist guides. A number of them have been in the timber industries all their lives. They are looking tonight for some information on which to base decisions affecting their lives-whether to sell their houses now or to hang on in the hope of better times ahead.

I have also had inquiries from some of the shire councils. One of their main concerns is the land that is to be placed on the World Heritage List. Will compensation be paid to the 12-odd shire councils in the area for land that will not be of any use to anyone as it will not be productive and no money will be made from it? Does the Government intend to pay any compensation to the shire councils to help them provide services to the area?
I look forward to debating this matter in the Senate, but tonight I would like some answers from Senator Richardson so that I may pass them on to the people of north Queensland.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a matter that is causing me great concern as a member of the Council of the National Library of Australia appointed by this Senate. What I am concerned about-I am pleased that the Minister for the Environment and the Arts (Senator Richardson) is here tonight to hear my concern-is the substantial and continuing erosion of the capacity of the Library to purchase books and serials and thus maintain its collections and meet its national responsibilities. This erosion has come about because the Government's funding has not kept pace with the increasing costs of books and serials-a cost which is increasing, I understand, at the rate of about 10 and 15 per cent respectively-and because the Government has not taken into account the loss of purchasing capacity caused by the depreciation of the Australian dollar.

SPEECH.PARA: It is important to bear in mind that about 87 per cent of the books purchased by the Library are purchased overseas and in recent years the Australian dollar has depreciated by about 40 per cent. The effect has been a program of cancellations. Since 1980-81-therefore, this goes back before the Hawke Government, but unfortunately, in some ways, it has accelerated during the period of this Government-nearly 4,000 serial titles have been cancelled by the National Library. In 1986, 637 serials were cancelled. The result was an actual decline in current titles held by the Library during 1986-87. Cancellations have been in the areas of medicine, chemistry, psychology, overseas newspapers, law journals and loose-leaf law services as well as in other areas.

I bring this to the attention of the Senate as obviously a continuation can only lead to an undermining of the integrity of the nation's premier library and a decline in the information base that is publicly available. The economies, which presumably the Government sees itself as pursuing in relation to the National Library, are false and will be regretted in the future. In a picture of generally declining funding for other libraries, the effect will be that many serials or books are not held anywhere in Australia on a publicly available basis. The National Library has a national responsibility to provide a resource upon which other libraries may call. The holdings of the National Library must be seen as a national resource and a first resort library in document delivery for the nation.

The sums of money involved to return the book vote of the Library to the capacity it held back in about 1980-81 in fact are not very great, relative to the national Government's expenditure. In 1984-85 it would have taken about an extra $1m; in 1985-86, $1.7m; in 1986-87, 2.3m; and in 1987-88, $3.2m. I have calculated those amounts taking into account both inflation and depreciation. So, as I said, the sums are not great. Nevertheless, as I have indicated, in order that the National Library may meet its national responsibilities and maintain the integrity of its collection, I urge upon the new Minister that he now is presented with an opportunity-certainly not in this Budget but in the next Budget-to do something that is most worthwhile in the best interests of the nation. I ask him to take into consideration the matters that I have raised tonight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have much to say in response to Senator Boswell's complaints. As far as the Strahan post office is concerned, I inform Senator Harradine that I will make sure that the environmental considerations in respect of that 80-year-old building are taken into account. I shall talk to the relevant Minister about them.
—Have you ever been there?
—I have been to Strahan.
—It is a matter of convenience to the people.

—Their convenience, as always, will be paramount in our minds. Senator Boswell asked a great many questions. I am not sure that I was able to write them all down as I do not take shorthand, but I will do my best to reply. If I miss any, he can remind me of them tomorrow. Nonetheless, he expressed the worry, concern, anguish and anxiety of many people in north Queensland who are faced with a world heritage decision and fear for their future. He mentioned that he has been to Ravenshoe. I went to Ravenshoe a few weeks ago to try to talk to the people there about their worries, anguish and anxieties and to see what I could do to make them understand what we were doing and what we could do for them as a result of the decisions we are taking. I was not heard on that occasion. However, I am sure that when I go back I will be heard. Senator Boswell was correct when he said that I had said that I would go back on 13 September, two weeks later. The dates that I have been able to work out for my return visit are 6 and 7 October. I will be going to Cairns, I think Port Douglas, Ravenshoe and anywhere else that I can fit in in the time available to me.

SPEECH.PARA: When I visit that area I will be making public the Government's plans, or at least some proposed plans that we hope to put on the table for discussion, on the future of the area listed for world heritage. Senator Boswell would know better than me that it is very difficult for this Government to come up with all the solutions on its own. It needs the information that can be provided, in the first instance, only by the Queensland Government. Of course, the Premier of Queensland and the Queensland Government are playing no speakies on the issue at the moment. The Federal Government requires the co-operation of the industry to give it the figures on how many people are involved and in what circumstances they find themselves. Industry has been bludgeoned by the Queensland Government into not co-operating. Local government is under a similar threat and is not co-operating at all. Without the co-operation of those three tiers, if you like, it is very difficult for the national Government to make detailed plans. However, to start the discussion off, given that we cannot do it in private yet, I point out that on 6 and 7 October we will put forward publicly what we believe to be a realistic employment program for those affected and also a regional development plan to show to local government in the area what we have in mind, at least for discussion.

We must remember at all times that land use and land management primarily have always been the responsibilities of the States and remain so. In this case, therefore, we have to set up a management authority for the area to be listed. On 6 and 7 October I will try to provide a draft for the sort management authority that we would envisage. There are two working models at which we can look. One is adjacent to this area; that is, the Great Barrier Marine Park Authority, which has worked well in co-operation with the Queensland Government. I see no reason why this one should be any different. The second similar authority is in South West Tasmania. Drawing from those two models we intend to produce a draft for a management authority and a management plan for the area.

To get to some of the specifics, the real reason for listing is to save rainforest. That is what the concept is there for. Most land uses will not be affected; the land use that will be affected is logging. The purpose of the exercise is to stop logging in the wet tropics rainforest. However, as Senator Boswell correctly pointed out, there are a great many private landholders. We are having difficulty in establishing exactly how many because some of the councils are not co-operating in telling us. I am in the process of writing to as many private landowners as we can identify in an attempt to set out the situation for them.

As I have the opportunity, perhaps I should answer some of the main queries which have been raised by private landowners. The first is, `I have bought a block of land. You have now listed it for world heritage so I cannot build my house'. That is a vision promoted by some Queensland Ministers and it is not true. If private citizens who own private land within the area wish to build houses, they will be permitted to do so. We will not stop them from either building a house or, obviously, providing access to it. What we are against is wholesale clearance of rainforest. But in the circumstances that Senator Boswell mentioned there is no problem whatsoever. Quite a number of people graze cattle or have small orchards. A number of different land use activities are carried on in the heritage area. They will not be affected at all by our decision. They will continue. We have no intention of trying to stop them. It seems that no matter how often I repeat that, the difficulty is getting people to accept it. I think that when I have released a draft management plan and a draft plan for an authority, some of those fears will disappear.

The real problem occurs with those people who feel that their livelihoods are affected by the decision. A couple of weeks ago I saw a headline from the local paper in Ravenshoe. It carried a screaming banner headline which said, `Ravenshoe under threat'. However, the newspaper article was not about the World Heritage listing and the headline did not refer to me. It referred to the Queensland Government's decision to reduce by more than half the quota allowed to be taken from the forests, which worried all the mills. Some of those mills closed but Ravenshoe kept going. It is the Government's firm view that because of the number of people whom we can re-employ, the towns will do so also. That being the case, I doubt whether too many people, outside those directly affected, will need compensation. However, the Government is prepared to look at any claim that is put in. I have advised a number of small businessmen in Ravenshoe and other towns that if they have concerns now is the time to put them forward to us.

In the next couple of days the Government will announce the appointment of consultants whose task it will be to look at a socio-economic study and to make sure that before any submission is made to Cabinet on the question of compensation for financial packages, the Government has before it as much information as we can possibly get. The only way we can get that information is by the co-operation of the people for whom Senator Boswell says he speaks.

The most common complaint that one gets in Ravenshoe when one listens to the people-it was easy for me to listen to them because they made a lot of noise; there was just some difficulty in responding-is from people who have worked in the forests all their lives. They say, `I cannot do anything else; you cannot put a cummerbund on me and make me a waiter. I do not want to wear a bow tie. I have my occupation, I am proud of it and I want to stay in it'. It is the Government's intention that the vast majority of those people who make such complaints and establish such concerns will continue to work in the forests or in activities related to them. In looking at plantation establishment and maintenance and park management, we intend to employ a great many of the people of whom Senator Boswell speaks. There are a number of ways in which they can be employed-for example, in the construction of visitor facilities, walking trails, sign-posting, roads and fences. If one is to preserve the forests, one must make sure not only that future generations can get to see them, but also that people from Australia and all around the world can get to see them now. The only way that can happen is by making sure that more and more of that magnificent forest is accessible. In park management there is also weed control and rehabilitation, nursery work, the closure and rehabilitation of logging roads and fire management and maintenance. There is a whole host of different areas and hundreds of jobs can be found for people in the industry there.

On the question of exactly how many jobs can be made available, at the meeting on 6 and 7 October I will have a stab at putting forward the numbers that we think might be employed in that way. We must always remember that without the co-operation of the three tiers that I mentioned earlier, it is very difficult for me to give a hard and fast figure; but I will give the best estimates that my Department can make.

On the question of tourism, I point out that one does not always have to be employed as a waiter. That is the most common complaint. There are interpretive facilities and other infrastructure facilities for tourists which do not involve putting on a cummerbund. There will be a great many such opportunities in this World Heritage listing area. We believe a great many people can be employed there. Let us look at public works. Any regional development plan which I look at in draft form between now and 6 and 7 October will involve the construction of roads and community facilities in co-operation with local councils. I think that 12 or 13 local councils are involved in the area and we will talk to them again on 6 and 7 October. I have already had a number of meetings with them but hopefully, with this draft regional development plan, I can give them some idea of what the national Government will have in mind for them.

I have been asked also to talk about the details of retraining and re-employment schemes. I think that I have covered the re-employment aspects as best I can at the moment. Obviously, I will be filling in more detail on 6 and 7 October. The Government is serious in its commitment to retraining, as it is with all the things about which I am speaking. After the consultants have identified the areas in which we can see people being employed and, after, I hope, we have received submissions from the people themselves, because that is what we are really seeking, we shall be in a position to develop a plan for retraining. Included in any submission that I make to Cabinet, there must be some plan for helping people through any adjustment period, and there will be.

I can say to Senator Boswell that I, as the son of a trade union official, would not be able to sleep too easily at night if I were able, at the stroke of a pen, to sign away anybody's rights. I will not do that, and it will be my intention to make sure that, as far as possible, we can employ everybody in the area. No doubt, some will miss out and some will opt to miss out in the new regime. Some will decide that they do not want to be involved in reafforestation and the like. The Department is in the process of looking at thousands of hectares that we can put under plantation schemes over the next five or six years. That will also be announced on 6 and 7 October. Again, it will involve the employment of hundreds of people.

Through all those schemes, I am confident that we shall get the great majority of people re-employed in constructive employment in which they will be happy because it will still involve the forest and forest-related industries. If some miss out, I must have a financial package for them, and it is a matter of finding out enough information from the people on the ground to make sure that that package is sufficient. That is the commitment of the Government, and I think that, by the end of the exercise, the people of Ravenshoe and the surrounding area will understand the depth of our commitment. We will have to put our money where our mouth is.

TALK.START.PARA: —When are you going to proclaim the area that is stockpiled?

—We have not issued any proclamations at this stage of the game. I hope that, as a result of negotiations with the companies over the next few weeks, that will not be necessary. I am sure that, once we talk to the companies and the workers, they will understand the value of co-operating with the Government. At this stage I am not anticipating having to get into a fight over the necessity for a proclamation. Most of the mills have three to four months up their sleeves in terms of stock on hand. That has been checked with pretty well all of them and it is true. Therefore, I do not anticipate that there needs to be a great deal more logging. With the wet season approaching, there will not be anyway, and I think that we can, without proclamations, satisfy the environmental and employment concerns of those involved. If I have missed out any points, perhaps Senator Boswell will take them up with me tomorrow and I will be happy to answer him in writing or, if he wants to ask a question at Question Time, I will answer him then.

SPEECH.PARA: We also had the contribution of Senator Hill concerning the National Library. I was at the National Library last night for the launch of the national poetry awards for the Bicentenary, and in the speech I made there I congratulated the Library not only on the preservation of what my colleague the honourable member for Brisbane, Mr Manfred Cross, called the dusty tomes but on the information provision role which the Library has developed so rapidly and so skilfully over the past years. Senator Hill referred to the substantial and continual erosion of the Library's capacity to purchase. Undoubtedly, the main reason for that in the past couple of years has not been any reduction in Government funding-although I concede that in the past couple of years of restraint we have not maintained the level-but a loss of the purchasing power of the dollar, which has dropped dramatically and made life difficult for the Library.

During this week I had a meeting with the Library's Chairman and Director and we discussed these matters. I hope that in the next Budget the Government can announce something better for the Library. Right across the environment and the arts, as with every other government portfolio, in a time of restraint everyone suffers. Though we have tried to apportion the suffering on an equal basis, I must concede that the reason the Government was able to achieve a deficit as low as it was, and the reason why the Budget was as good as it was, was that some important parts of the portfolio had to suffer. Having said that, the record of funding for the National Library in the 4 1/2 years of the Hawke Government more than matches that of the Fraser Government in its seven years in office. All I can say is that I will make it better over time.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 8.20 p.m.
